PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 3 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As has become traditional over some time, the House is again debating a Budget that was cobbled together without any particular effort to go in any particular direction. This has been happening for a considerable period under this Labor Government. Unfortunately, any credibility that this Budget may have had disappeared yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, one of the major cost-cutting initiatives--the Medicare charge--was thrown out by Caucus. I see the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is smiling his head off. Apparently he was one of those who thought that that was a good idea. But it flies absolutely in the face of the Government's criticism of the Opposition when it, for quite proper reasons, defended the rights of families and people with children when the Government tried to rip away from them the family allowance through the asset test.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You never produced a health policy in all those years. You failed.
—-I produced a health policy----
—-Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.

—-If the Government had chosen to use that policy, it would not be in the trouble it is in today and pensioners would not be waiting two years to get into hospital. I am proud of my policy. The fact that I did not get a chance to deliver it is another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this Budget. This Government commenced office with a commitment to deficit Budgets, after which everything else has happened by accident. Deficits, surplus, deficits--whatever the numbers come out to when the Government considers all the claims of everyone, that is what happens. There is no planning, purpose or vision and, of course, no ability and now, after yesterday, there is no credibility.

The only thing the Government seems to have been good at--and even that appears to have failed in recent times--is self-congratulation. If there were one competent or successful businessman on the Government benches he would tell the Government about the bottom line. In this Budget the bottom line is an admitted--and I underline the word admitted because the figure is greater than this--$4,700m deficit, a stagnant economy and one million unemployed people. Again, that is the recorded number of unemployed; those who are out of work but who have not registered would make that number even higher.

The total individual tax payments as recorded in these Budget Papers are down $4,000m on the estimate for last year's collections. Company tax collections are down $2,000m on the estimate. Withholding tax is down $150m. Sales tax is down a massive $1,300m. Payments to the unemployed are up $2,000m on the estimate--39 per cent higher than the previous year and 80 per cent higher than the previous two years. If that is not an indication of an economy in serious decline and collapse, I do not know what is.

This is after the 1980 decade of international financial boom when the Government should have been putting the acorns away so that we could address the inevitable cyclical downturn of an international nature. But for the last 10 years Australia has been taking its own economic action and has no longer been affected by circumstances around the world. While the economies of overseas countries were booming, we were getting into trouble. Who is to blame for that? It is this Government. Where we should have had economic decision making we have just had a reactionary process.

I want to take honourable members back to the situation as I saw it. It has now been recognised that what I was saying years ago, that everything was being done incorrectly and at the wrong time, was right. The first Keating Budgets brought in an $8,000 billion deficit, which was stupidly blamed on the previous Government. The reality is that that overinflated the economy, as did the additional amounts which took deficit spending in the first four Budgets up to $26 billion. The economy was recovering on its own because it had rained.

That was the first problem. Then we had all of these deregulatory decisions of the financial markets which were in themselves not wrong but they were wrong because the Government looked at only half of the situation. It left our tariff regime in place; it left our regulated labour market in place; and it left regulated commodity trading in place. These factors totally distorted the economy and, as such, the economy could not possibly work. We had deregulation of financial markets but no consideration was given to the ability of those markets to handle that change at that time. It was a correct decision taken without proper consideration.

We also had the floating of the dollar without any recognition that a currency like Australia's, with its relative certainty and safety, would become Monopoly money for the major speculators around the world. We now have a situation where we have 500 billion Australian dollars turned over on Australian foreign exchange markets every month. Of that amount, $8 billion is required to finance our normal economic activities. In other words, there are substantially more Aussie dollars played with than are needed. Those speculators decide almost entirely the value of our dollar. It no longer is a recognition of our financial circumstances. They have got our money, they have got the Aussie paper, and they are determined to retain its value.

Who pays for that? Australian exporters. The dollar is grossly overvalued, as was admitted by one Labor member yesterday when he called for its devaluation. The reality is that the Australian Reserve Bank is simply not large enough to conduct its role of establishing the correct value for the Australian dollar in the international market. We have seen time and time again that, when it has attempted to force the dollar down by selling it, it has been taken on by the major institutions and given a hiding. The simple fact is that some of those major financial institutions around the world turn over more money than Australia does. They are now dictating the value of our currency. Of course, that is very damaging to our economic future.

We had a cloistered Canberra bureaucracy, an arrogant Treasurer and a hypnotised press gallery which all combined to damage the Australian economy and bring it to its knees in a mere eight years. The bottom line--which I refer to again--is $133 billion of international debt. If those opposite do not think that has an effect on everything from here on in, they do not understand the fundamentals of business. The tragedy of that situation is that most of that $133 billion was borrowed for fun and games, for corporate play, the doubling of values of assets that produce nothing extra. That was the tragedy in that period. The simple rule in the business rule book is that if one borrows money one must invest it in income producing assets.

Anybody--be it a family or anyone else--who goes out and borrows money to have a good time with it, ends up in a tragic situation, and that is what has happened to Australia. The blame can be levelled all over the place, but while we have a government, the buck stops there. We are the regulators; we do take the final responsibility, and we have just got to look at that.

We have been told that we are going to have a housing led recovery and that interest rates have been dropped another one per cent to achieve it. If we had any local savings left, they would be used to lower that foreign debt of $133,000m, and that is not happening. When we get this debt led recovery, which we are going to have for the second time around apparently, where is the money going to come from? It can only come from the savings of people living overseas. Housing is 95 per cent debt. That is the way housing is being funded today. It is going to come from overseas.

What is the Government going to do when the deficit starts to blow out, when the overseas funds start rolling in and there is a rapid increase in foreign debt? The Government has only got one way of stopping it--to put interest rates up again. What happens to all the poor devils who borrow this month to build a house? What happens to all the small businessmen who think that now is the time with interest rates falling to buy a new truck or a new bit of machinery? None of them can borrow at fixed interest rates.

It is interesting that, at the instruction of the Reserve Bank, short term money fell yesterday and long term rates went up. That is the true market assessment. I have been watching it very closely because I, too, am a businessman. The message still is to borrow long; in fact, the long term interest rate market went up yesterday because the market says that this cannot last. It cannot last because if people are encouraged to borrow money, there is only one place that Australia can get it from--overseas.

Mr Stutchbury, along with Professor Pickford, told us today that overseas debt does not matter. They, too, are academics. In the real business world, debt matters at all times because it has to be serviced. The biggest component of our trade deficit at the moment is the interest bill. Unless we are producing things in this country, we cannot pay the interest bill. Fundamentally, we continue to borrow to pay it. We are now told that we are going to have a recovery by getting people to borrow money and build houses. That would be fine if the savings existed within Australia. They do not.

Where do we go from here? The Government has a couple of solutions. It is going to impose superannuation on the people. There is absolutely nothing wrong with the concept of telling Australians that they have to start providing for their own retirement income. That is an excellent procedure. However, the Government just happens to have chosen the worst vehicle. The only thing in favour of superannuation as a retirement investment is convenience. It is otherwise a lousy investment.

If honourable members go back to their electorates and ask the recently retired who have private insurance superannuation investment how much they are getting by way of a lump sum they will see that it would be $60,000 or $70,000 and, if they are lucky, $100,000. When they signed up for it 30 years ago, they could buy three or four houses with that amount of money. They really thought it was a fortune. What can they buy with it today? Not one house. The reason it is a lousy investment is the inflation component. The Government should look at that. That cannot be managed because the investments that are safe enough for those types of institutions pay very low dividends. Over the decades, people have learnt that if they chase the top interest rate, it is probable that when they go to get their money back, it will not be there. We have seen it in Western Australia; we have seen it all around Australia. Every time institutions pay one per cent or two per cent above the market, they fall over.

Those institutions are going to have to deal in safe securities and are going to have to take money offshore. They are going to have to do all sorts of things to try to get a return that, in most cases, will not keep up with inflation. That is the first reason.

Now that the Government will make this compulsory, will people still be committed to trade union funds? The Government has not explained that. Trade unionists run the Australian Labor Party. In Western Australia and Victoria we have seen what good money managers they are. How would people like to have those blokes handling their dough? The Government's past Treasurer went down to a trade union conference once and told it, `Do not leave the money with the money managers. Take it over yourself. Have the financial muscle--your industrial muscle is disappearing'.

I would hate to think of any of my employees' retirement future residing in the hands of people like Mr Parker, for example--a one-time leading trade union official. How would anyone like him running his or her financial retirement money? This is what is being proposed--unless the Government is going to tell us that that is not on and that there will be no trade union involvement and trade union rake-off.

A third point that worries me is that the Government tells people to invest in their retirement, but the first person to get his hands into it is the tax man, who takes 15 per cent of it. He does not wait for it any more at the point of retirement; he wants it up front. That is an initiative of this Government.

The trade union wants its dollar a week. I do not know what it does for the money. Then there is the fund manager. When we read of 30 per cent, 10 per cent, 5 per cent and minus 3 per cent returns on investments by the fund manager, those returns are after all of this other money has come out. People are not getting 30 per cent, 5 per cent or minus 3 per cent--which I think is the current rate--on what the employer puts in; they are only getting those returns on what is left. I have had people send me documents as to how their vocational union superannuation is going. In most cases, the current net worth of their policy is substantially less than employer contributions. I guess that over time that might grow; but it is a pretty slow process.

Why cannot people have some options? Why cannot ordinary Australians go out and buy a unit of accommodation which will have the appropriate value in time and use that as their retirement investment? Why can we not give them incentives to do that? They will spread their investments. I reckon we could have a redistribution argument outside, because I think the economy is pretty important.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I agree.

—-Yes. I reckon redistribution is a matter for the corridors. When we get down to this situation and the final point, people should be able to make their own choices. We are telling small businessmen who are battling, who have not been able to afford even a $3,000 a year contribution, which is a deduction, for their own superannuation, that under this arrangement they have to find 3 per cent or 5 per cent of their total wages outlay. Little business has got to give it to big business, because when the superannuation funds get it, they will not invest in small business. There are 760,000 small employers keeping this country going. It is silly. It should not happen. It is one of the things that really worry me. It is wrong and I will oppose it at every step. It is a good idea with the wrong solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we need Australians to invest in their retirement. But is it not interesting that this is what we say to Australians today, `Do not worry about health, the Government will fix that; do not worry about your kids' education, the Government will fix that; do not really worry about retirement, the Government will fix that--but we would like you to save some money.'? We then say, `We have taken half your income away, 40 per cent at least, to enable us to give all these handouts. You have not got much left, but we think you should save some'. If people were left with some of those problems that I have just referred to and with the money that is taken from them, I think most people would save it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How would you encourage them?

—-I would tell them honestly the facts. I think the facts are irrefutable. I think the fact is that there could be, in 20 years time, an anti-pensions party. It is a terrible thing to contemplate, but I think there will be a time when the workers who are left will revolt and say, `We will not pay this money'. That will be a tragedy for the people who have not provided for themselves. I cannot see why for a period--say, for 10 years; not a long time--the family home is not a deductible investment for retirement. Nobody gets along very well without his or her own private home in retirement; it is a necessary part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: We should look a lot more widely at investment opportunities for people, and we should encourage them. If people want to buy a little factory, let some other small business go into it, make some money and pay some taxes, it sounds a lot better than giving it all to two or three major fund managers who, by prudential requirements, cannot take the risk on the little guy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I agree with you. How do you encourage them though?

—-People should understand that pensions could be substantially less than they are today. That is what we should be selling Australians. We should say, `You had better start doing something for yourself, but here is some incentive'. We should not just drag funds out of small business employers, because it will send them broke. That would be a tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not get very far this morning with all the advice I have for Australia. That particular issue was an important one. I will no doubt get some other opportunities at a later date to talk about some of the other issues. There is only so much money in Australia. If the Government wants to take it all and spend it--which governments of any political colour generally do not do very well--then the private sector cannot spend it. I do not know why we do not just leave the money with the private sector and let it get on with the job. It will make mistakes but they will be a lot of little ones. When government makes a mistake it is usually a very large one.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Alan Bond. There is a whole string of them.

—-He is not a little guy; I am talking about giving the little guys a break. They are the ones who pay the taxes that the Government imposes. It is a funny thing but the big guys do not seem to pay much tax--so why help them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to talk about one of the highlights in this year's Budget--the preparedness of the Commonwealth Government to look again at problems of urban development in Australia through the building better cities program. Today I will concentrate my remarks on that facet of the appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that most surveys of international living conditions rate Australian cities very highly. The last one that I was able to rake up, which was published in November of last year, had Sydney and Melbourne in the top three. This is against the fact that the residents of other cities in Australia would regard living conditions in Melbourne and Sydney as somewhat worse than their own. By international standards we have cities that are very well serviced for the people who live in them. Honourable members might ask why we intend to spend more money on improving them yet again.

The good urban environments that we have in this country are the result of four or five generations of Australians being prepared to plough the economic surplus generated by our very efficient primary exporting sector into the urban environments and to protect them and their industries by various subsidies, tariffs and other government subventions. In the 1990s and beyond, that kind of policy will not be possible and we will have to address some other aspects of urban development, including the efficiency of our cities and equity of access to our facilities.

Firstly, in relation to access and equity, the distribution of urban lifestyles, and the pleasures of them, is not equal. On the one hand, we have areas in the outer fringe suburbs that develop and receive much of the new housing stock, and have done over the last few decades, but they have been distant from the job market and from many cultural facilities and they have been late receiving education opportunities, child-care places, public hospitals, public transport and so on. We have the paradox that these outer suburban areas are expensive to develop, are inefficient and receive community resources only late after their development. In the late 1960s I bought a new house in such an outer suburban development and experienced this process.

At the same time we have inner city areas that are showing evidence of urban decay resulting from the simultaneous movement of industries away from them and flight of population to outer suburban areas. Honourable members might say that rectifying these situations is not the province of the Commonwealth government. But to the extent that the government is responsible for improving the efficiency of the Australian economy and the equity of access to social facilities and opportunities for Australians, it is clear that we need to get involved in the developing demographic structure of our major cities. Since these cities hold somewhere between 60 and 70 per cent of our population, they also hold well over half of our economy.

The Labor Party has long had an interest in urban development. The latest program that we have put together in this Budget results from the initiative of the Special Premiers Conference in October of last year which was convened to bring micro-economic reform to the system of government itself and to improve its efficiency. A resulting report, the report of the working group on patterns of urban settlement, was presented to the next Special Premiers Conference in July 1991 and sought to suggest ways in which urban development could be improved, made more equitable and made more efficient.

The report points to the relative decline in government urban infrastructure expenditure over the past 20 years, while at the same time private demand, particularly for low density urban housing in the outer suburban areas, has increased, with resultant poor linkages between employment and housing, labour market inflexibility, high journey to work costs, traffic congestion, pollution and so on. It suggested essentially three ways in which to do something about the matter.

The first is urban consolidation, to encourage a range of approaches, including medium density infill and urban containment in the outer fringes of our cities, the essential point being to limit the growth of the geographic spread of our cities while filling in land that is presently not settled. Secondly, it suggests that infrastructure financing should be placed on a more commercial basis by public authorities to avoid the excessive subsidies going to urban sprawl, which has been a feature of past government infrastructure funding. Thirdly, it suggests the establishment of better government coordination mechanisms, to ensure that the impact of Commonwealth policies on State and local governments, and vice versa, can be more clearly assessed.

The Budget has taken up these ideas, as the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has put it, by establishing the aim of a new partnership between Federal, State and local governments, so that our cities and the quality of life of the people who live in them can be improved. To this end, $800m has been allocated over the next five years, with $56m of it to be spent during the coming financial year.

We need to put in context what this is trying to deal with. If the present growth rate of population continues, during the next 10 years we will need to put more than 1.2 million dwellings into our cities to provide for the population growth, and 700,000 of those at present would be built on the fringes of our cities, with the billions of dollars in urban infrastructure expenditure resting on the public purse. This better cities program is designed to alter the emphasis of development but it will vary from place to place, in accord with State and local government suggestions and needs.

The Commonwealth will try to encourage the matching of new housing to job opportunities, to public services and to transport. This process will be undertaken through the States. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) have already written to the State governments to ask them to nominate a Minister each who will be involved in this process. They, in turn, will be asked to nominate suitable developments and, if necessary, to determine those in conjunction with local government authorities. Again I need to emphasise that the cost of the present system of development is such that public funds subsidise outer suburban blocks to the tune of $19,000 each in the Adelaide area, and much more in the larger cities. We are trying to deal with a redeployment of those facilities.

The important question that we now face is: how can this work on the ground? I want to spend most of my remaining time dealing with how I feel this could appropriately be applied to the metropolitan area of Adelaide. It is true that Adelaide does not face the problems of urban sprawl development and inner urban decay in quite the same form or proportions as Sydney and Melbourne, because it is a slower growing city and it does have vacant land; nonetheless, it is facing the same general process of having the most affordable low density housing in the northern and southern extremities of the metropolitan area. Public funds, as I have said, have been used to provide increasing infrastructure for these outer suburban developments, but people are still left with lower access to job opportunities and social support systems.

What are the options? In the metropolitan area of Adelaide there is land that can be used for urban consolidation and for other processes of the kind that the better cities program is designed to deal with. I have spoken in this chamber before about the Northfield development project, which is such a development. With the Northfield development it is envisaged that up to 10,000 people will be located on what is presently largely vacant land in the north-east inner suburbs. This land will be vacated by the redeployment of two hospitals and the moving of a dairy research farm from the area. This will enable a very large urban consolidation project to take place.

There are other kinds of urban consolidation which are rather different in the western suburbs. If we envisage the metropolitan area of Adelaide, we find that there is a strip that runs from Anzac Highway to the west of the central business district, from Anzac Highway northwards, a couple of miles wide, until it reaches the proposed MFP site, which is in itself a form of urban consolidation about which I have spoken before but which has its own opportunities and has different forms of commitment from the Commonwealth Government, which has accepted it as a national program.

Immediately to the south of the MFP site there is a strip of land which is very appropriate for urban consolidation and for the building better cities program. Most of the land is presently run by the local councils of Port Adelaide, Enfield, Hindmarsh, Thebarton and West Torrens. I would like to say most about Hindmarsh because I have had most to do with members of that local council over the last couple of weeks.

Hindmarsh developed as a settlement separate from Adelaide during the later nineteenth century. During the early part of this century it became a very significant industrial area. After the Second World War there was a boom in the development of light secondary industry, behind the tariff wall and with the subventions of the kind that were then the way in which we carried out our industrial development. As a result, its residential population actually declined as its industrial base increased. But, of course, the social amenities, like schools, public transport, some parklands and so on, which had been developed during the previous period of population from the late nineteenth to mid-twentieth century, remained.

During the 1980s, the attractiveness of this area for residential settlement became more evident as people were faced with either moving to the northern or southern fringe suburban development areas or trying to get alternative accommodation closer to the city. The Hindmarsh and surrounding councils started to try to redevelop the suburbs which had been depopulated and industrialised. Suburbs like Bowden and Brompton, which had during the 1950s and 1960s been synonymous with the poorer areas of Adelaide, started to move up market. By the mid-1980s, the plans of these councils for repopulation were starting to pay off. Young middle class families, including one of my sons and his wife, moved into the area. As more people like them moved in, greater demand was generated for facilities, public services, upgrading of community services and so on, but the council did not want to see the total flight of light industry and the jobs which it generated.

Land in this area, unlike that in Northfield and unlike that in the MFP site, is not completely vacant. There are, in other words, pockets of residencies which remain from the earlier period. There are also pockets of industry that remain. So it is not possible to say, `We are going to a greenfield site; this is the development we are going to undertake'. We have to work closely with what exists, with the people who are there and with the resources which are there.

The land in the inner western suburbs is available from a wide range of sources and is not greenfield land. We have redundant industries which have either moved out, been unable to face the rigours of competition or become obsolete owing to the technology or products that they have produced; we have old and inadequate housing stock which is no longer acceptable and is being demolished; we have the old Rowley Park speedway, where stock car racing took place for many years, within a couple of miles of the central business district, which is now not a financially viable proposition; and we have a brickworks which, quite apart from all the pollutant controls that are now in place, was again an uneconomic usage for such an area close to the city.

The local councils have been trying to organise rezoning of these areas in order to maintain a reasonably clean, light industrial base, in order to maintain the community facilities which have already existed from an earlier era, and yet to rezone in such a way as to enable people to move into relatively cheap inner suburban dwellings.

As soon as I heard about the building better cities program, I got onto the people who I thought might be interested in it, including the State housing Minister, Kym Mayes, who expressed a very keen interest in the redevelopment of the inner suburban western suburbs. I also got onto two chief planners of local councils--in particular, John Hunt, who is the chief planner for the Hindmarsh Council, and Andrew Young, who has a similar role to play in the Thebarton Council.

What is interesting is that they already had plans on the board to move in the direction that the building better cities program has in mind--that is, the programs already exist in the minds of forward thinking local government planners and in the minds of State Ministers, and now it is a matter of the Federal Government getting in and providing some direction, some financial assistance and some program assistance to facilitate the redevelopment of these inner city areas as a serious option for people who do not want to move a long way from the central business district into outer suburban areas.

It was very appropriate, I might add, that last week the Prime Minister, who was visiting Adelaide anyway, went to these suburban areas. Let me give an example of the things we looked at. We went to a school in West Croydon that is being amalgamated with another school in a local suburb because of the depopulation of the area. If the area is repopulated, the school system will already be in place. We then went to the Hindmarsh industrial training Skillshare project, which is an instance of an old factory that is being reconverted into a Skillshare project in order to provide industrial training skills in the middle of a light industrial area for the residents of that area.

Of course, we went to the medium density housing project, which is actually being built on the old Rowley Park speedway site. The old Rowley Park site was about 30 feet below the level of the surrounding land, so it had to be filled in and settled, and they are just starting to put the housing up. It is a wonderful example of inner city urban development as an alternative to the suburban block. The blocks are much smaller, the roads are much narrower, the courtyards are smaller, they are two and three storeys, but they are very nice. The demand for them is considerable and they are a cheap, inner suburban option--and of course they are winning prizes for development.

The necessary community infrastructure in this part of the world already exists and has existed, in some instances, for the last 50-100 years. There are public transport systems, there is rail and there are roads, and there are schools and augmented child-care. We went to a very good child-care centre run by the Greek Orthodox community. Aged care programs are being introduced there, and there are already parklands, as a result of the urban plan which was laid down 150-odd years ago. The region is adjacent to the central business district and thereby makes job hunting that much easier; it is adjacent to the MFP, which will provide high-tech job opportunities in the coming 20 or 30 years; and it maintains the traditional light industrial base which is there as a result of developments over the last 100 years.

There are extensive pockets of vacant land in the area. I find it difficult to describe, but I have here a map from the Hindmarsh Council of the available land, some of which is old factory land and some of which is old housing land. There are about 58 hectares of it. Commonwealth planning initiatives are required. We have to get in and say, `This is how you will rezone it; this is how you could do it', and private and public developers will be only too happy to get involved in the process once it becomes known that it is an option for suburban development. For example, next Friday night I am meeting with the Greek Orthodox community, who are the owners of a very large slice of land in that part of the world, and I think with some Commonwealth encouragement they could develop it into the kind of urban consolidation that I am talking about.

The South Australia Gas Co. also has some land which is now surplus to its requirements; ETSA has some land; and companies who used to have factories in the area have land. This is a great opportunity to undertake this kind of process. As I say, it is already under way. All the Commonwealth Government will be doing is providing additional financial and planning incentives in order to encourage it. The old Horwood Bagshaw site near the Hilton Bridge has already been redeveloped. The old brewery site on Railway Terrace has a number of dwellings on it. There is a large barracks at the top of Anzac Highway where there are no soldiers in any number--they are up in Woodside--and I am told this would be capable of taking about 300 dwellings of medium density housing for people who wish to retire close to the city.

The Commonwealth initiative, working through the States and local councils, and with the encouragement of local members of parliament, such as myself, could provide a rejuvenation of inner suburban areas--a rejuvenation of areas that have decayed over the last 20 or 30 years, and a rejuvenation of these areas as an option to the very expensive, for the public purse, and very inefficient development of outer suburban areas.
I do not want to pan outer suburban developments because, as I said, I settled in one myself in the late 1960s and early 1970s, although I now live in a more inner suburban area.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Amongst the workers.

—-Amongst the workers in Prospect, with the sons of the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), who live just up the road. It is important to give young families the option of moving into inner suburban areas and not having to move into outer suburban areas. Over the coming years I look forward very much to working with the three tiers of government in order to ensure in particular that this strip of inner western Adelaide receives the attention and redevelopment that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is the ninth Labor Budget, the third since we had the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) bringing home the bacon. It has been quite a rasher of bacon. As I look around Australia today I see the appalling state of the general economy with unemployment at very high levels. The real level of unemployment is substantially higher than that which is reported. There are many thousands of people who simply have not registered for unemployment benefits throughout Australia. It has not only hit young people where there are very high levels of unemployment, but it has also hit people in their forties and fifties who have been forced out of management positions. Their real chances of re-entering the work force are minimal, especially in the current climate.

SPEECH.PARA: This bringing home the bacon exercise has been roundly bagged by everybody. The ACTU has said that it is not much of a Budget; the Business Council of Australia has said the same. The left wing, of which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) is proudly a member, says it is not much of a Budget. It even had a little Caucus get together the other day and came up with the idea that the Medicare levy is no good.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At least we did not go to Four Corners when we have a Caucus, like you run off to Four Corners and spill your guts and get slapped all over the party room.
—-It is better than running around trying to find a new leader of the Labor Party, as those opposite are, and making the whole of Australia pay for it as a consequence of those actions.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to point out two things that happened overnight in this country. The Treasurer (Mr Kerin) said in the Budget a fortnight ago that he was taking a medium term view of interest rates. To back that up, the Reserve Bank annual report states:

Too rapid a reduction in interest rates, therefore, would risk suggesting to a sceptical public that here was another round of `stop/go' policies. In that event, price expectations would not go lower and the opportunity to achieve a lasting reduction in inflation would be lost.
It continues:
For its part, monetary policy can best contribute to growth and equity by maintaining a clear commitment to medium-term price stability.

In other words, it is clearly saying that interest rates should not be adjusted for political purposes. Yesterday we had the prime example of that, if ever I have seen one. If honourable members do not believe me, they should read the papers today. If they do not believe the papers--and there is a good case for not doing so--they should ask the money market and they will be told exactly the same.

Whilst that debacle was going on, the Left and a few others, including Minister Hand, the talkative fellow at the table, were gathering with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) to tell him that the Medicare levy was not on. So it was shunted off to a committee--this is real Whitlam-day politics--and there it dies.

Who pays now for this better cities program we heard about from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley)? Listening to the Budget, I understood that the moneys raised by charging for Medicare were to be a major contributor over five years towards the housing program. I presume that it will be funded in some other way.

These two examples, which happened only yesterday--a fortnight after the Budget came down--show that the Government has lost its will to govern and has lost its commitment to Australia. It only has one commitment left--the personal survival of a government which can no longer run itself.

I move around a bit and see what goes on. I talk to people in the business world. They have no plans for employment in 1992. I fear for the school leavers who will be affected by that. Many tens of thousands of people will go onto the job market in the new year knowing that the business community has no real plans to engage new labour. It also has no investment plans at this point. The one per cent drop in interest rates will not have an impact until the middle of 1992 and expectations of business activity will not alter in that period.

At the same time, productivity in Australia continues to wobble along. There is no great increase in productivity, and that is reflected in corporate results. With a few notable exceptions, corporate results in Australia--one sees it in every newspaper one picks up--are down by one-third, and some by much more.

On top of that, there are record levels of bankruptcy. Every day mortgagee and possession sales are advertised in the papers. The value of assets in this country has dropped by roughly one-third in the last two years, depending on the circumstances. Along with this there is a general loss of confidence among Australian people and a growing petty crime rate to match it. Australia is in a deplorable state.

While all this has been going on, Australian companies that are still generating profits are not looking to this nation for future development; they are indeed looking overseas in a very big way. Recently I was in South America. In one country I saw nearly $2 billion worth of Australian investment showing good returns. The development of a very substantial mining interest was to the benefit of that particular country and to the company concerned.

That trend will continue because of the nature of the economy bred, particularly in the last two years, by current government policies. As a consequence, people facing the future have very little to cheer for and certainly nothing to thank this Government for in relation to its current policies.

According to the 1986 census my electorate had some fairly high levels of income and household employment. For example, of all the electorates my electorate had the fifth highest level of households containing people with tertiary qualifications; for persons with professional qualifications it ranked tenth; for the number of women in the work force, fifteenth; for the employment ratio, fifteenth; for median family income, fourteenth; and for families with annual income levels of over $40,000, it ranked fourteenth.

Yet that relatively well-off electorate, in terms of qualifications, income and employment levels, suffered the following in my two agencies: in Alderley, which I share with the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), unemployment has risen 76 per cent in the last year; and in Toowong, which is in the middle of Ryan, it has risen by 49 per cent. Those are largely in the categories of young people. Those are depressing statistics from an electorate much better placed than the vast majority of electorates.

One does not really have a great amount of time in these debates, so I picked one other subject relating to the Budget which I thought was important, and that is superannuation. It has been a long held view of mine that superannuation is necessary for all. The concept of having a diversion from income tax gathering every year to provide pensions for all never seemed to me to be a very sound process; therefore, I am a supporter of national superannuation.

However, the way we have gone about it in the current environment is bound to have an adverse effect on employment and future investment, because the proposed concessions for small business will mean that a lot of corporations with either a particular number of employees or a particular level of payment to employees will contract staff to remain within those limits. Those companies in the bigger areas are more likely to consider the payment of superannuation to be a burden, an add-on cost, rather than a benefit for the person concerned or the nation.

Already, add-on costs are probably 40 per cent of a straight wage. This measure will certainly impose a 50 per cent, maybe a 60 per cent, add-on cost factor on any wage payment. The Government should have considered the present economic climate before imposing such a measure. Indeed, Bryan Frith of the Australian said:
. . . the levy will add to unemployment levels and ensure that those who are already unemployed will remain so for longer than otherwise would have been the case.

I subscribe to that view. The timing of the introduction of this measure is very unfortunate and, once again, will be paid for by the Australian work force. It is nothing more than a new type of payroll tax which will add to the costs of employment at a time when very few can afford to pay it. To add to the Labor Party's worries, I quote that great supporter of the Labor Party, Max Walsh, when in one of his articles he says:

One does not need to be a genius at economic management to question the sanity of imposing a compulsory superannuation scheme on a bleeding corporate sector. . . Had Keating brought down this Budget, his reputation as a responsible Treasurer would have been destroyed.

I use that quote for the benefit of the thoughts of honourable members on where this scheme might fit in. The problems of having funds in Australia acquire this huge program of superannuation, which really is conscripted savings, requires the Government to give a lot of consideration to the regulation and management of these funds.

It is not a place where governments should be able to dabble and suggest that there ought to be a contribution to entrepreneurial activities as government wishes, because that is bound to be a flop. However, there is a need to ensure that the management of these funds, which will be enormous, is professional and accords with certain prudential requirements. If not, it certainly leaves open a great avenue for fraud.

I should like the Government to address the problem at the moment where the only authority that has any rule over the raising of funds is the Australian Securities Commission. The only group which has any authority in the management of superannuation is the Insurance Commission. When one looks at the Act which establishes that body and its procedures one realises that it simply does not have the powers to ensure the adequate regulation necessary to supervise acquired funds. Conscripted savings in this form need some clear definition of security, prudential management and the way they will be handled in the future. I hope that the amounts raised are invested without regard to ulterior uses.

It is quite probable that certain funds may be managed by a trade union. A trade union may seek to invest those funds with a disproportionate weighting in a particular industry or in particular companies within an industry to achieve a result which is not in the interests of the holder of the superannuation but is in the interests of the management of that particular union or particular trust. That is one aspect which I think needs to be addressed because the temptation to do that has been demonstrated in the past both in the corporate sense and in the trade union sense. The investor who has been compulsorily required to invest in that fund should be protected from such action. We have seen all sorts of instances in recent times in which innocent investors have been taken to the cleaners because the objectives of management are intended to suit its own purposes and not those of the investors.

I conclude on the matter of the Trade Practices Commission, which for some years has been underfunded. In my view, the requirement imposed upon the Trade Practices Commission to ensure that competition is put into the market place has been left to run in a very haphazard manner. There has been no attempt by the Government to increase funding in this very important area. Unless the Commission is in a position to prosecute cases, there will never be an adequate testing of the trade practices law so that competition can be measured in this nation.

The tests that have been applied in the last 10 years or so of market dominance have never really been tested in the courts, because government has said to commissions, `If you take this court case on, it will cost you X millions'. These cases are very expensive. The fine at the end is minimal. The Commission will not retrieve its costs by taking action, yet the Government has had the gall to tell the Commission, `You take the case at your risk'. Therefore, a lot of commissioners have taken the view that it really is not worth the candle.

I refer not only to the Queensland Wire case but also the case involving Unilever, in which the sheer weight of money that the corporation put up tested the nerve of the Commission to such a degree that with the passage of time it did not prosecute or test the laws that were there to protect competition.

This year there is no increase in the Budget allocation to the Trade Practices Commission. We have a new Chairman of the Commission, who is putting forward a different point of view for the Commission. Whether this will be endorsed by the Government, which would require some change to the Trade Practices Act, is yet to be seen. But change or not, it will not alter the fact that corporations will not be deterred from acting in a collusive sense while penalties are so small and the cost of litigation is so high that the government of the day will not back up the Commission in this particular important area.

This matter is important to the Opposition because with a privatisation program there will need to be a strong Trade Practices Commission, but it is more important for the business community as a whole to know where it stands. It will not be deterred unless fines are substantially higher and it knows that the government of the day will enforce the provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is committed to the expansion of superannuation. I can assure him that many of those constituents whom he is about to inherit from Brisbane and the inner city suburbs share that commitment. Many of them, in fact, do not now receive superannuation. They will be pleased to see his commitment to it transformed into some action.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, superannuation is one of the areas that I wish to touch on, but before I do so I would like to talk about some of the broader questions associated with the Budget. In my view, this Budget provides the foundations for what will be a sustained recovery in the next 18 months. It addresses the problems of unemployment and the recession by injecting some funds into the economy to boost employment and to provide assistance in training and a range of other programs.

Much has been made of the deficit which is contained in this Budget, and speakers on the other side of the House have criticised that deficit. I will come to that shortly. Before I do, I make the observation that I would have thought that those honourable members on the other side of the House accepted the conventional view of economics, which I think is still widely accepted, that in times of difficulty and in times of recession a government's responsibility is not to withdraw funds from the community but in fact to provide some assistance and an injection of funds.

This Budget provides for a modest deficit. The $4.7 billion figure represents only 1.2 per cent of our gross domestic product. However, it indicates a significant turnaround on fiscal policy over the last two years. It represents a turnaround in Government expenditure of some $13 billion in that two-year period. That is a major injection of funds to provide programs, to provide assistance to families, to provide assistance to those who are unemployed through training and helping them gain employment, and to also help those who rely upon pensions and other government payments for their livelihood.

In conjunction with those measures, over the last 12 months the Government has been able to reduce inflation, as the Budget Papers set out, from some 7.7 per cent to an annual figure now of 3.4 per cent. Australia is now in a situation where its inflation rate is less than the OECD average, less than its major trading partners, and in fact at the lowest level that it has been in this country for more than a generation. That is a major achievement, which has also facilitated the opportunity to reduce interest rates. The most recent reduction, and a welcomed one, announced yesterday, was a reduction of a full one per cent.

It is worth exploring the Opposition's view on that point because it is very difficult to pin the Opposition down to a position on not only areas of policy but in fact on the details of economics. In spite of the rhetoric which we have heard from Opposition members, they have on at least three occasions in the last 18 months attacked the Government when interest rates have been reduced. They did it at the end of 1990; they did it at the commencement of 1991; and again they have done it in the last 24 hours.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has danced around the question every time he has been asked, including in the media, about his position on the interest rates cut. It would be refreshing to see any members of the Opposition rise in this debate, or indeed in any other debate, and state clearly their view on interest rate levels. Do they support the reduction that occurred yesterday? The Leader of the Opposition has spent the last 24 hours whipping up the media, complaining about it as a political stunt. Does that mean it was wrong? Does that mean that it should not have occurred? Does that mean that the Opposition, if in government, would not have reduced interest rates, as it did in fact say in 1990 and earlier this year when interest rates were lowered?

The Opposition needs to come clean with the community and the public and honestly put before them not hollow rhetoric but a position which can be assessed. What is the Opposition's policy on the interest rate reduction? Opposition members should have the decency to acknowledge that it was a correct decision, that it was a decision that most commentators in the commercial world not only anticipated and expected but also in fact were advocating in recent weeks. It was a decision taken properly by the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), and it is a welcome one.

Last year when we were debating the Budget the Opposition set out its view that last year we should have reduced expenditure by $3 billion. I remind honourable members that in fact last year the Budget at that time had a planned surplus, so it was a very tight fiscal Budget.

Notwithstanding that fact, the Opposition claimed that we should have reduced the Budget by $3 billion. Having said last year we should take $3 billion off what was a tight Budget, the Opposition then failed to provide any details of where that $3 billion cut should be made.

This year, the Opposition--I suspect having learnt the lesson of its folly 12 months ago--has not made a response to the Budget in detail. We saw the intriguing spectacle of the Leader of the Opposition, in reply to the Budget Speech, not addressing a single word to any alternative policy which he would advance. He has obviously decided that setting out too many policies gets him into hot water. It got the Opposition into hot water over health policy; it is still in hot water over the consumption tax and education vouchers. It would appear, from this side of the House, that the Opposition strategy has been to learn from those mistakes of the last 12 months where it cannot formulate policies and therefore to avoid any policy statements whatsoever.

As best we can analyse the Opposition's view of the Budget deficit, apart from criticising the fact that there is a deficit, the Opposition has said that we should have a balanced Budget. The Leader of the Opposition made that announcement yesterday in a press release. Again, let us put the question to the Opposition Leader. What areas of the Budget does he propose to eliminate? What increases in taxation does the Opposition intend to impose in order that the Budget may be balanced?

Is the Opposition suggesting that the tax cuts which this Government has introduced and which are included in this Budget should not be given? Is it suggesting that we should reduce the family allowance supplement, which has been enhanced and improved in this Budget? Is it saying that we should reduce the payments on Austudy and the advantages of Austudy that have been included in this Budget? There have been significant improvements in Austudy, a program which I regard as critical for the long term future of Australia's economic well-being--but it is not just for our economic well-being; it is for the good of all of our citizens to be able to participate fully in our education system. Is the Opposition saying that the long term unemployed should not get unemployment benefits? We know that is the Opposition's policy, but let us get it on the table and hear where it will make these cuts. Is the Opposition saying that we should cut the job training programs that the Government has increased in this Budget, and so on?

The list of these matters is quite extensive. The Opposition has failed at every opportunity to set out its alternative program and in any way detail the measures it would use to cut expenditure or to increase revenue. It makes the bland statement that we should have a balanced Budget and leaves it at that. That will not wash with the Australian community, not only because of its transparency, but because of the coalition's own record in government.

I commend to the House the table on page 5.15 of Budget Paper No.1, which sets out total outlays and revenue from 1953-54 through to the current time. In the last year in which the coalition was in office, in 1982-83, there was a Budget deficit of 2.6 per cent of GDP. Since 1953-54 the only occasions on which the Commonwealth has run a surplus Budget have been in 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989- 90 and 1990-91. The only occasions on which there have been surplus Budgets have been under this Government, the Hawke Labor Government.

If the truth be known, since the Liberal Party was formed, since Sir Robert Menzies got the idea and created the Party, it has never once in government had a surplus Budget. Opposition members have stood in this Parliament in recent months and attacked the Government because we are going to have a deficit--when every single Budget a Liberal government brought down was a deficit Budget.

I mentioned that the last deficit of a Liberal government in this place was 2.6 per cent of GDP. The deficit proposed in this Budget is 1.2 per cent of GDP--less than half the deficit the coalition left in its last Budget and much less than many of the deficits it managed to accumulate during its period of office in this place.

I want to turn to the question of superannuation because I believe that the Budget initiatives, in providing a superannuation guarantee levy, are to be commended and represent the most significant initiative to provide a high quality of living for our retired Australians since the introduction of the aged pension. It is no secret to honourable members in this place that over the next 20 to 30 years the age distribution within our population will place enormous strains upon any government in providing the sorts of social security benefits for the aged to which we have become accustomed, certainly since the Second World War. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that in 1991 the percentage of our population aged 65 and over is about 11.3 per cent. In the year 2026 that will rise to 20 per cent. Any responsible government is in a position where it must act now if it is going to provide a secure future for our current citizens of working age when they reach retirement in the next century.

In the short term, the Government's measures will affect only those employers who have avoided their obligations under Australian industrial law. In 1986 the industrial commissions of this land introduced award superannuation of 3 per cent. In spite of the fact that that was inserted into every industrial award in this country in the years soon after 1986, some 30 per cent of Australians are currently without any superannuation cover whatsoever. Enterprises with more than $500,000 in payroll payments will be required to provide only 5 per cent from July 1992. For those employers who have been complying with the law to date, that will mean an increase of only 2 per cent because they should already be paying 3 per cent. If the enterprise has a payroll of less than $500,000 per year, it is required to make only the 3 per cent payment anyway.

Effectively, all we are doing is saying to those employers who have not honoured their obligations under Australian industrial law that they will now be required to do so. If they have been paying the 3 per cent award superannuation they are not affected. If they have not paid the 3 per cent superannuation we will require it of them, not only to ensure equity for all Australians but also to provide some equity for the employers.

I have also been out talking to many employers who are struggling in these difficult times. The responsible legitimate employers complain to me, amongst other things, about the irresponsible and unscrupulous operators who are seeking to take advantage of those in less well off positions during this recession and who fail to provide award wages and conditions such as the 3 per cent superannuation. I have had a number of employers in my electorate say to me, `Why don't you do something to make those sharks in our industry pay the correct wages? Why don't you do something to make them pay the superannuation like we are, because we're being responsible employers and yet we are being undercut by these sharks in our own industry?'. The Government's decisions on superannuation provide that guarantee to the honest legitimate employers who have honoured their legal obligations under industrial law.

Some 68 per cent of employees currently receive 3 per cent superannuation or more. The superannuation guarantee levey will not affect those 68 per cent of employees and their employers. There are 35 per cent of employees who receive 5 per cent or more.

I want to turn to the question of the 5 per cent contribution and the plan that these superannuation payments will increase to 9 per cent by the year 2000. Not only is the 3 per cent award superannuation included as a credit for that purpose but so too is other employer funded superannuation. If we take employees in the public sector and many other private sector enterprises, not only would they have been receiving the 3 per cent under award superannuation, but also many of them contribute to a company superannuation scheme to which the employer provides a subsidy. That employer subsidy also counts towards the guarantee levy which this Government is introducing. A large slice of the business community who are good employers and who have been doing the right thing from the outset will not be required to pay one cent more.

The people whom members opposite are seeking to defend are the sharks in industry who are not only eroding decent working conditions but also cutting the throats of decent employers who are trying to do the right thing in building a strong Australia. The Government's decisions will protect legitimate employers from these backyard operators.

In this debate on superannuation, the Opposition has attacked the Government and has sought to conduct a scare campaign, referring to unemployment increases and difficulties that employers will have in making the payment. As I have already indicated, that will not be the case and in fact most employers are already meeting the standard that the Government has set in this Budget. The interesting thing, though, is that I have not heard anyone from the Opposition tell me what it would do if it was in government. Honourable members opposite know as well as we do the demographic problems to which I have referred. Would they remove this guarantee if they were in office?

They should tell the Australian people what their policy is in respect of superannuation. It is not good enough for members opposite to stand up here and say, `Well, yes, we support a national superannuation scheme--but not now'. They have never thought that it was a good time. In 1986, when award superannuation was introduced, they opposed it. They said it would ruin industry, and many of the employers around the country complained as well. In 1986 the economy was booming. There was probably more money in the economy than there should have been and certainly a lot of it was not spent very wisely. However, in those days, which in relative terms were good days, honourable members opposite said, `No, now is not a good time'. It was not the right time when there was plenty of money in the economy and now, when there is not as much money in the economy, it is still not the time.

Members of the Opposition take the view that it is never the time to introduce universal superannuation. I refer specifically to universal superannuation, because we in this place all receive a superannuation benefit, and members on the Opposition benches think that that is pretty good. They have no complaint about superannuation schemes for politicians and they have no complaint about superannuation schemes for public servants, either. Their generosity in this field even extends to the business community. They support not only superannuation schemes in the private sector but also totally employer funded superannuation schemes where the employee pays nothing. Members opposite think that is a good scheme, but as soon as we say that we will give it to everyone, that we will include that 30 per cent for those who should have it but who have been denied it because of unscrupulous employers, they cry, `No, the economy cannot afford it'. Apparently, it is good for politicians, public servants and business executives but it is bad for the 30 per cent of Australians who are ordinary wage and salary earners. If members opposite go to the people with that proposition, which is in fact their true position, if they go to the people with their assessment of superannuation, they will see the Australian people's response to it.

The hypocrisy of members opposite in relation to superannuation reflects their general deceit on budgetary matters. I sat here a couple of weeks ago listening to the debate on defence outlays and the review of the defence forces. I made some comments on how I would like to have seen some increases in defence expenditure. I acknowledged some of the difficulties that the Government has in providing that. Speaker after speaker on the opposite side of the House hopped up and spoke about grand plans for increased defence expenditure, but there was not a word about where the cuts would come from. The Opposition had a policy of a $3 billion cut last year, it has a policy of a balanced Budget this year and it has a policy which says `superannuation, but not now'. Honourable members opposite should get up in this debate, or in any other debate, and provide the details and come clean to the people of Australia. People will not accept the hollow rhetoric of members opposite and, in the end, they will not accept their policies, either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This Budget has now been roundly condemned by economic analysts and recognised for what it is--an exercise in shoring up the position of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) rather than a serious attempt to address the real economic problems that we currently face. This Budget is a culmination of the mismanagement and misreading of the economy for the past eight years. In fact, I get the distinct impression that the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) have thrown their arms up in the air in despair, because they are unable and unwilling to face the economic reality that we are a country riddled with high debt and continuing high interest rates as compared with our overseas trading partners, and that we have massive levels of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: As the architects of this latest excuse for a Budget have thrown their arms up in despair, they have decided to throw millions of dollars towards a building better cities program and to force employers to wear the cost of increasing superannuation, at a time when they can least afford it, in a vain attempt to camouflage the lack of real economic substance in the Budget. The Government has made no attempt to stop the swelling ranks of the unemployed and to show compassion for the almost one million unemployed who have been thrown on the scrap heap as a result of its disastrous economic policies. For young people this Budget has been particularly irresponsible because their needs and plight have been totally ignored.

At a time when rural communities are struggling under extreme hardship, this Government is treating them with contempt by making $56m available to the building better cities program in the first year and $800m over the next five years. I find it particularly distressing that this Government has done this while rural Australia is in the midst of the worst depression for generations. It is obvious from this that this city oriented Government is totally out of touch with the hardship that rural Australia is experiencing.

However, unlike the Government, rural communities are actually doing what they can to help each other through the depression. Nine days after the Budget was announced, I attended a one-day workshop in Riddells Creek in my electorate. This workshop, called Recession Problems Day, was organised for people having difficulty coping with the recession. A variety of speakers gave those attending practical information about how to cope with the financial pressure and stress of being unemployed and hints on how to stretch the Budget dollar further. The overriding concern of those who attended was that they wanted to get a job. This is what this Budget fails to address.

The Government's decision to legislate for compulsory superannuation is certain to increase the number of people unemployed. The Government's special deal with Bill Kelty and the ACTU to legislate for compulsory superannuation will cost 100,000 jobs and add to inflation. It is a tax on business and a tax on employment.

The coalition supports the idea of extending superannuation coverage, but not without due regard for capacity to pay or increased productivity. The Budget ignores both these criteria. It is totally unrealistic for the Government to expect employers to provide superannuation at this time. Small businesses are struggling to keep afloat and this superannuation deal could be the one to sink them. The Government just does not seem to realise, or maybe care, that small businesses simply cannot afford this added cost. The numbers of small businesses going to the wall will increase and, with these numbers increasing, so too will the level of unemployment.

It is a glaring omission in this Budget that there is not one single mention of youth unemployment. This is what I specifically want to address. Australia's young people feel abandoned by this Government. This feeling is best summed up by the words of Michael Wilkinson, a year 12 student from Assumption College, Kilmore, in my electorate. He sat in the public gallery and listened to the Treasurer deliver the Government's Budget. His comments after witnessing that say it all. He said:

As a young Australian who will be looking for work next year I was particularly upset to note that there was not one mention of ways to combat the problem of youth unemployment in the Government's Budget.

A letter I received just yesterday from another year 12 student in my electorate details further the despair and heartache young people are experiencing, especially those who live in rural areas. Jackie Cardwell from Seymour requested that I try to make the Government understand how she and her peer group feel. This is what Jackie had to say:

My name is Jackie Cardwell and I'm currently studying year twelve...I wish to carry on my studies in 1992 at tertiary level. I would like to study law, but unfortunately due to my family's financial situation I will be unable to attend university next year. If I wish to take up a course in the following year. . . it is absolutely necessary that I seek employment now. With the current unemployment levels as they are, it is unlikely that any business is going to accept me for a position as I have no experience and I am straight out of school. Although I will try my hardest. I ask you Mr Hawke, what am I supposed to do? You seek to have an educated society, but how do we at 17 years of age, afford the costs of university? Then the budget comes out and you've increased student costs by $140 a year. I come from the country and wish to complete a five year course--this means HECS will cost me over $10,500. You want to raise revenue, you want an educated society, but now only the rich can afford to be smart. . . I'll have to join the dole queue or stay on at Safeway--
where she apparently works after school--
I can't see a very stimulating future in either of these alternatives.

It is signed, `Student without a future, Jackie Cardwell'. I frequently receive letters like that from my constituents, crying out for help and relief from the pain this Government has caused them. Unfortunately, this Budget does not signal an end to the pain, only more of it.

It is time to ignore the Government's rhetoric and look at the facts. The unemployment levels for youth say it all. The latest seasonally adjusted figure for youth unemployment is 28.5 per cent. This is almost three times the rate of adult unemployment. Over the last 12 months, 130,000 young people have lost their jobs and, as if that is not bad enough, things are predicted to get worse. The Budget has forecast an increase in total unemployment to 10.75 per cent, compared with the present rate of 9.8 per cent. This ultimately means that the youth unemployment figure will increase and almost certainly hit 30 per cent.

Young Australians are facing bleak employment prospects and are being denied the opportunity to develop their skills and talents. They are obliged to take what little is on offer, whether or not it suits their ambitions or skills. There is no choice of opportunity, no variety of apprenticeships or traineeships.

In the rural areas of my electorate, where the youth unemployment rate is much higher, the situation is even more desperate. Many of the jobs that used to be available to teenagers, such as apprenticeships, farm work, et cetera, are no longer available. Many teenagers are being forced to leave their home towns, to look for work in larger centres, but because they often lack training and qualifications they face the prospect of being unemployed and homeless. They have little choice. They either stay at a home without work and place even more demands on their families and on the town's meagre welfare services, or they move to the cities and swell the ranks of the urban unemployed.

This Budget is the culmination of eight years of mismanagement by this Government, and nowhere is this more evident than when examining the problem of youth unemployment and the failure of the Government's policies to solve it over the past eight years. In the International Year of Youth in 1985 the Government declared youth priority one. However, they were not considered priority one for very long, and the fact that there was no mention at all of youth unemployment in this Budget makes me think that they are no longer even considered a priority by this Government. The 1988 inquiry into homeless youth, which condemned the Government for failing to help Australia's young homeless, was proof that the Government's measures to help Australia's youth were a dismal failure.

In response to that inquiry the Government committed $100m over four years in the 1989-90 Budget. The now Deputy Prime Minister admitted recently in an article in the Melbourne Age that this decision was a failure. He said:
Federal Government policies to combat youth homelessness were a fuzzy response to political pressures in the `hope' that things might get better.
He further went on to say that there was no way of knowing whether the money had done anything to help because, as he says:
. . . we weren't all too clear what the problems were at the beginning.
What an admission! He further added:
. . . when a problem arose, governments usually added another program and spent some money without focusing on the causes of the problem.
He said that government must change its approach and tackle causes rather than use cash as a bandaid for problems.

The Government has obviously ignored his advice as this Budget is full of bandaid solutions and has failed to go to the core of the problem. This Budget was the opportunity for the Government to address the problems in our society and address the high unemployment levels, but instead it has chosen to ignore them. The announcements in the Budget are piecemeal and will do nothing to equip young people with the relevant training for work or help them to find a job. In fact, in many cases all it will equip them for is learning how to live on welfare.

The Government has made changes to youth homeless allowance, rent assistance and Job Search allowance in the vain hope that it will assist Australia's homeless. The young homeless allowance will be available on a weekly basis and rent assistance will be extended to single people under 18 years. These measures do absolutely nothing towards getting those young people into secure full time employment.

While welfare may be needed to help people over their difficult times, it should not be a substitute for rational and well developed economic policy. It appears to me that, instead of trying to tackle the problem of youth unemployment head on, the Government has decided to help our youth onto welfare. This is not the way to go about solving the problem of youth unemployment or our economic problems.

In the 1987-88 Budget the Government decided to place its emphasis on training programs. The Government has embarked upon a similar course of action again this year. It announced that it is going to increase spending on training and labour market programs by $260m this year, a 50 per cent increase over last year. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker: training for what? This is just more bandaid therapy. This Government should give No. 1 priority to and should be focusing its attention upon the real problems at hand--the state of the economy, our massive foreign debt and falling living standards--because it is only when our economic problems are overcome that Australians will be able to find secure and stable employment. No amount of training programs can compensate for that lack of action by this Government.

These schemes which the Government has implemented, changed and modified over the past eight years have all failed, because today young people are finding it impossible to get a job, and that is what it comes down to. This Budget is a final indication of this Government's lack of commitment to young people. It has given up trying to help them because it just does not know what to do. It is in fact the last episode of a sad and sorry saga of failed policies.
