It is one thing for this Budget to ignore the massive problem of youth unemployment and not to reform Australia's economic structure to allow young people the chance of gaining employment, but it is another thing to ignore completely the human tragedy of youth unemployment and its consequences.

The unemployed suffer from a variety of physical and mental problems. Work has both manifest and latent functions. The manifest function is income. The latent functions are time structure, enlarged social experience, engagement in collective purposes, identity and activity. These functions need to be satisfied for positive mental health to be attained. Young people who are unemployed are more likely to have poor mental health because, unlike their employed counterparts, they have no imposed time structure, no involvement in collective purposes, no socially ascribed identity and low levels of activity.

Studies have shown that psychological maturity is the result of a successful transition through a series of development stages. One of the most important stages is work. There are solutions to these problems. Australia needs to undergo a massive reform program if it is to become an economically prosperous and healthy nation. High on the agenda must be taxation, industrial relations, and transport and waterfront reform. These reforms will change the direction in which we have been heading for the past eight years. They will turn this country around on the road to economic recovery and towards lower levels of unemployment.

This Government has abrogated its responsibility towards our young people. It has failed in this Budget to come to grips with the fundamental economic problems that Australia faces--the problems that offer no hope to our young. No amount of money being poured into training programs will help the unemployed if there are no jobs for them to go to when they have finished the program.

The Government needs to encourage investment and adopt and pursue economic policies which will pull Australia up off its knees. But this Government does not have the fortitude to implement the reform which we need to be able to do this.

In 1985 the Government tried to implement taxation reform, but could not get it past the ACTU. It has been far too slow with privatisation and waterfront reform. It claims that it is implementing reform in the areas of industrial relations and transport, but we all know that that is simply empty rhetoric. The Government has failed and is now not even trying. This Budget is testimony to that fact and to the fact that the Government has lost direction, lost responsibility and lost the will to lead.

Only when Australia is allowed to become a competitive and productive nation will unemployment be lowered. It is in that sort of environment that our young Australians will be able to look to the future with confidence and have the opportunity to find a job which is suited to their talent and ambitions. It is also an environment in which small businesses will have the opportunity to flourish and students the opportunity to continue their education.

This Budget offers no hope, no new ideas and no fresh policy approaches--it is uninspired and uninspiring. It has been labelled `Kerin's do nothing Budget' and `Kerin's hang on and hope Budget'. Those labels are indicative of the reception this Budget has received in the community far and wide.

This Budget will do absolutely nothing to improve our living standards, our high levels of unemployment and our high levels of foreign debt. It has been called `the nothing Budget' because that is exactly what it is. This Budget has failed and this Government has failed Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It was very interesting to listen to the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey). There was very little constructive input in that speech. In 1983, when the Australian Labor Party came into government, those opposite had the onerous distinction of having the trifecta: double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and double digit interest rates--yet the honourable member comes in here castigating the Government. I notice that she is now leaving the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member is also one of the great promoters of the goods and services tax. I am surprised that she, as a person representing a country area, does not realise the extra costs--freight costs, goods and services costs, and charges--that would be imposed on country and regional people if those opposite had the opportunity to introduce that sort of policy. Fortunately, the Australian people will not have a bar of that.

It is also very important to say that every Anglo-Saxon country is in recession. Many conservative governments--such as those of America and England--have the same difficulties and problems. There is no doubt about that whatsoever. This is why Margaret Thatcher is out and why John Major is on the nose in the United Kingdom.

But there is no doubt that unemployment is a real cancer in our society. The Government's strategy, in these hard economic times, is to get the economy right. We ought to pay tribute to the Government: inflation is at its lowest level for 30-odd years and interest rates are coming down.

I am pleased that interest rates have come down one percentage point. I certainly hope that the banks do the right thing. They have a responsibility in our society to bring down their interest rates also. Of course, once the economy picks up, morale picks up within the community and confidence comes back. Then, of course, people will start reinvesting and opportunities will arrive for young people to get employment.

Earlier my colleague the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) spoke about superannuation. Many people overlook the fact that previously we had to borrow money from overseas if we were going to build some massive industry in Australia. This superannuation scheme--I must say that I am a wholehearted supporter of superannuation and I most certainly would like to see a national superannuation scheme--creates a pool of wealth within our country so that we do not have to borrow money overseas. We have this huge pool of resource that we can call on and it is funded on a local basis. Who could argue with that concept? This is what it is really all about.

Australia should be responsible for and have authority over its financing. It should not have to borrow money from overseas to fund necessary projects. It is a great thing to have a pool of resource money funded from a national superannuation scheme. We are heading in the right direction. Because of our unemployment problem, we have a responsibility to seek views from all sections of the community. I pay tribute to an Anglican priest within my electorate, Father Gordon Hewitson, who is very concerned about unemployment. He has a tremendous track record in social work. He looks after underprivileged people--people in desperate straits and those less fortunate in the community. In Whyalla, he has come up with the LETS scheme, the local employment trading system, which is a bartering system. His philosophy is that everybody should have a reasonable standard of living and that everyone must have creative work to do for and in the community of which he or she is a part. I wholeheartedly agree with this.

The Commonwealth Employment Service and departments such as the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Labour and Industry should look at the sort of scheme that he is trying to initiate to see whether we can get young people to do something positive and constructive within their community so that they feel they are making some worthwhile contribution to society. It is very important that departments and Ministers try to liaise with these people to see whether we can come up with something positive to overcome this horrific problem of unemployment.

I am also delighted that the Government has seen fit to get a committee together to have a look at Medicare. In my area alone there are very few doctors, if any, that bulkbill. In one particular community there is a cartel of doctors who get together and charge $9.50 above the schedule fee. If one takes this $9.50 and then adds the $3.50 less that people get back from their Medicare, one sees that people are paying $13.00 for a visit to the doctor. This imposes a tremendous burden on families.

It is pleasing to note that a Caucus committee has been set up to have a look at the Medicare legislation. There is no doubt at all that the fees for medical services have blown right out of proportion and that there are obviously too many doctors. It is a terrible indictment of many doctors that they see the way to make a quick quid as going into country areas, making their fortunes and returning to the cities. That does not apply to all doctors, but many of them have this type of philosophy.

I turn now to the tremendous response by Senator Graham Richardson to my representation for assistance for people in regional and rural areas. Far too often it is too easy to kick Ministers, particularly during harsh economic times. However, I must say that Senator Graham Richardson is possibly at the forefront of Ministers who are prepared to listen to backbenchers, take on board any constructive suggestion, argue it in Cabinet and come up with a solution. I acknowledge the tremendous work and support that he has given me in a number of areas, particularly the area of family allowance supplement to farming families and funding for assistance to rural and regional businesses.

For the first time the Government is addressing the problem faced by the farming community in gaining access to support benefits. As I have said many times in this place, many farming families are income poor but asset rich. Extending the eligibility for FAS means that many farmers who were previously excluded from getting benefits will now qualify. I acknowledge the support of Senator Graham Richardson in having that brought about.

Other measures included the allocation of $450,000 to the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics towards the cost of conducting a survey of rural areas to identify specific regions affected by the rural downturn. Student assistance through Austudy and the assistance for isolated children's scheme will be improved and simplified, including the introduction of a hardship provision so that the present assets test--effectively $695,000 for farm and business assets--will no longer apply if a student's parents or spouse are receiving a social security or veteran's pension or benefit or household support under part C of the rural adjustment scheme. Funding for existing or already announced new programs includes the rural access program, the rural counselling program and countrylink information services.

Turning to economic development--there will be $2m from 1992-93 for the rural industries business extension service; a program to assist with the development of successful agriculture and related businesses, especially in export markets and greater value adding; $1.8m for business advisers for rural areas; and a program to provide business advice to assist rural people to develop new and more diversified enterprises. It is incredible how many people who live in rural areas unfortunately have not had accounting or cash flow experience in running books and have in many cases left that to the banks and accountants and have fallen short. So this is a real boost to rural people.

Provision is made for an increase of $500,000 a year for the local government development program and the broadening of the eligibility criteria to assist selected key regions to diversify their economies. Continued funding will be provided for existing programs such as the innovative agricultural marketing program and marketing skills program.

I am pleased that funding for RAS will be increased by $100m to $160m. This will give the Commonwealth the capacity to support up to $1.4 billion of rural debt during 1991-92. Also of major importance is the national soil conservation program, which will receive $24.9m for 1991-92. This compares with $21.5m in 1990-91. Within that program additional funding will be available for landcare groups to facilitate farm and district planning and to develop better approaches to risk management for factors such as drought.

Of paramount importance to South Australia is the funding for the Murray-Darling Basin initiative, which will be increased from $9.93m to $11.29m. This includes $7m for a program of works under the national resource management strategy, including revegetation schemes, farm planning projects, community education programs and community participation projects to combat water logging and salinity.

This is extremely important to South Australia, as we depend very much on the River Murray. South Australia being the driest State in the driest continent, it depends very much on the River Murray. So these positive financial supports are imperative. The Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation is to receive $10.8m for the second year of operation.

In the short time remaining, I will outline some of the positive steps announced in the Budget designed to alleviate the problems being faced by some who are disadvantaged in our community, such as those young people who are State wards in foster care. As from 1 January 1992, young people who are State wards in foster care and who are not in receipt of any other allowance by the relevant State authority will be eligible for the independent rate of Jobsearch allowance, sickness allowance and special benefits, where applicable, at a cost to the taxpayer of $520,000 in the 1991-92 financial year and $920,000 in a full year. These changes will assist approximately 1,400 young people throughout Australia.

Another positive aspect of the Budget is the changes to eligibility for the special benefit, which has been extended to include unemployed school leavers aged 16 to 20 years from low income families during the 13-week education deferment period. This is a step which will assist 500 additional special benefit recipients, at a cost of $570,000 in a full year. This move will be applauded by my constituents in Grey, who have found this 13- week period of deferment of benefits very difficult financially. I have no doubt that most of those 500 will be in my electorate.

As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I look after 86.2 per cent of the land mass of South Australia, and under the redistribution proposals which have just been announced, I will soon have all but 8 per cent of South Australia to look after. It makes me wonder what the rest of the pollies from South Australia on both sides of the House are going to be doing.

To continue--in addition to this access to Jobsearch allowance, sickness allowance conditions for certain special beneficiaries under 16 years of age have been extended, allowing these young people access to labour market assistance including training. This measure will apply from 1 January 1992 and will improve the employment prospects of disadvantaged early school leavers and help reduce unemployment. It is expected to increase the number of Jobstart allowance recipients and reduce the number of special benefit recipients by around 3,700 in a full year, at a cost of $80,000 rising to $160,000.

The plight of the young homeless has also been addressed in this Budget by establishing pilot projects which will make it easier for homeless young people to get both social security payments and complementary services from other agencies. One of the aims of this initiative is to cut through the bureaucracy that homeless youth have to deal with. The estimated cost to the Commonwealth of this initiative is $1m each year.

Another measure to help our young homeless is that the young homeless allowance will be available on a weekly basis from January 1992. Some may say this is not enough, and I would agree that more needs to be done. However, I believe this initiative is a step in the right direction. The plight of our young homeless is a matter which each and every one of us must concern ourselves with. Our young people are our future, and as a parent I find it heartbreaking to see the life that many of these young people are forced to live.

There is a reduction in the waiting period for rent assistance, from 26 weeks to 18 weeks, and reductions in the waiting periods for the Jobsearch allowance, the Newstart allowance and the sickness allowance. The special benefit provisions for recipients without children will be welcomed by approximately 153,600 beneficiaries aged between 18 and 60 years who for too long have been sideswiped because they had no children.

Those pensioners and retirees who require financial advice also benefit from the Budget decision to increase the staff of the Financial Information Service by 75 officers Australia- wide over the next three years. This service will be expanded to provide advice to other Department of Social Security clients, including Jobsearch and Newstart allowance recipients and sole parent pensioners. Financial Information Service officers will give greater assistance to people from non-English speaking backgrounds. There will be a more active outreach to disadvantaged groups, increased training for staff, and more intensive promotion to advise pensioners of the pension loans scheme and home equity conversion.

The changes to the existing voucher scheme for telephone rental is also welcome. I receive numerous complaints from pensioners that they forget to take the voucher with them at the time of paying their account and subsequently cannot use it to reduce their next account. The implementation of this cash-in- hand payment or telephone allowance from July 1991, still to be made payable four times a year and currently worth $51.80 per year, will enable pensioners to exercise their full entitlement without fear of using the wrong voucher on their accounts, as happens at present resulting in the loss of the concession.

Child disability allowance is another area which has received attention, with 43,000 current recipients benefiting by $2.15 per week from 2 January 1992. There will be 2,000-plus recipients of the disability support pension aged 16 to 20 years, and approximately 3,000 new grants in this category will be made in subsequent years at an estimated cost of $2.73m in 1991-92 and $5.7m in 1992-93, restoring the real value of the child disability allowance.

Another matter of concern for my constituents, and one which I have first-hand knowledge of through the loss of an aged relative, is the arrangement for the bereaved pensioner or beneficiary. A death in the family leads to a trying and traumatic time, and it is not a time when those left behind are thinking of worldly matters such as finance. It is not a time when one wants to have the added burden of the red tape of bureaucracy, and anything that can be done to ease the burden at such a time should be done. I am glad to say that this Government has taken the necessary steps to ease the burden in relation to social security beneficiaries. The Government had already made improvements in January 1990 to assist pensioners and beneficiaries with dependent children for a period of 14 weeks following the death of a spouse or child.

The new provisions announced in the Budget build on those 1990 changes, extending these payments to more clients and correcting a number of anomalies. Where a person makes a claim for a pension or a benefit but dies before payment, a spouse or parent will be able to receive the bereavement payments. I could go on with a number of significant things which are in the Budget to help those less fortunate in our community. However, time has run out for me. I commend again Senator Richardson and some of the people who have taken the initiative to help those who really are in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This Budget is without vision and without hope. It has failed to create any enthusiasm or confidence within our nation. Indeed, it was stillborn. The new Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in his very first test has been demonstrated to be inept. I guess that comes as no surprise to those of us who have followed primary industry over the years and have watched the way in which he presided over that portfolio. We saw the greatest exodus of farmers in the history of our nation and the greatest decline in rural prosperity. That man is now entrusted with the Treasury portfolio and he has delivered to the people of Australia a recipe for continuing despair.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the shadow of the pallbearer, the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), hangs darkly over this 1991-92 Budget. When introducing the 1990- 91 Budget the former Treasurer, with his typical extravagance, said:

Economic policy has worked and is working. The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth. . . .In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
Those are the kinds of boasts that the former Treasurer introduced in the last Budget. By contrast, the current Treasurer has been much more modest, much more restrained. He said:

It was a disappointing year for Australians; a year of lost jobs, squeezed profits and dashed hopes. . . .We were living beyond our means. We could not continue to do that without facing dire consequences. . . .The objective of stepping down to lower growth but stopping short of recession was not achieved.

Much more modest comments indeed! The extravagant boasts were gone. The current Treasurer began his Budget with an apology, a confession that Labor had got it all wrong. Gone were the phrases such as `bringing home the bacon'. Indeed, the Government did get it all wrong.

The Treasurer had good reason to be modest in his opening remarks. The Budget had much to be modest about. The past year was a disastrous one for all Australians. It was an appalling indictment of Keating's final year of economic management. An $8 billion surplus became a real deficit. There was massive unemployment, way above the levels that Labor said it could ever tolerate in government. There were record bankruptcies and zero growth. There were 12,991 bankruptcies in the year 1990-91, way up on the previous record of last year, which was 8,552.

The national debt reached a new high of $170 billion gross, with falling living standards right across the board. What an embarrassing end to the world's greatest Treasurer, to have left our great country in such a state. I guess it is commendable that the current Treasurer has at least acknowledged the past failure, that Labor has got it all wrong. Sadly, the difference was only in style and not in substance. This Budget does not address the problems.

As a financial document it has failed. Even the proud boast of the former Treasurer of balanced Budgets has been abandoned. A $4.7 billion deficit is the bottom line of this year's Budget. The Government again will borrow to pay unemployment benefits, social welfare
and foreign aid. This will continue to place upward pressure on interest rates.

As a document that should have offered hope for a better future, this Budget has also failed. There is no hope for the 830,000 unemployed, or the 1.3 million or more who are underemployed. There is no hope for a more efficient economy. The reform agenda has been abandoned entirely.

As a planning document for the future, this Budget has been a failure. Its central features are in tatters. The Medicare reform package was rejected by Caucus. The superannuation package is probably unconstitutional and the better cities program is completely uncosted and unplanned.

It is a stagnant Budget with a central theme of hopelessness--not that the Budget had nothing to do with jobs. It was particularly concerned with one job--the job of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It was prepared against the background of the leadership crisis in the ALP. The Budget provided rewards to the Left for its loyalty in the last leadership crisis, bringing back memories of the dying days of the Whitlam regime.

The present Treasurer has now come to use the `d' word. We could not get the previous Treasurer even to acknowledge the `r' word. The present Treasurer has gone so far as to accidentally spill the `d' word, depression, which of course will lead to despair, defeat and degradation--plenty more `d' words.

However, this Budget contains no measures to boost productivity, to cut industry costs, to relieve the tax burden, to create job opportunities or to develop optimism. The Left has extracted only more welfare measures--cotton wool and bandaids for those injured. It contains provision for more public servants and more social services. The ALP Left has never learnt that, when one man gets something without earning it, someone else has to earn something without getting it.

This kind of philosophy has given birth to the better cities program. It provides for $800m over five years, with $56m allocated for this year. There is plenty that needs fixing in Australian cities. Thousands of people are moving to the country to escape the social degradation and despair that is so much a part of life in our urban areas these days. However, that social despair has been caused by the Government's economic and social policies. The better cities program will do nothing to restore the well-being and the quality of life in urban areas. The Budget contains little or no detail. Yesterday, the Prime Minister admitted during Question Time that there were no projects in mind, and it seems that many in the ALP Caucus were prepared to trade the whole program in on some improvements for Medicare.

There can be little or no doubt that the better cities program is a pre-election slush fund for Labor marginal electorates. Better footpaths for the unemployed to queue on; better parks for the unemployed to sleep in; and better drains for the unemployed to lie in. This will not solve the problem and will do nothing to address the social ghettoes and the welfare mentality that this Government's economic policy has created.

The great crime of the ALP Government has been the way it has destroyed the will and the need to work in this country. When we return to government, how are we going to restore the ethic of working, the ethic of being constructive and productive in our society? People have come to rely on this welfare mentality that has destroyed incentive and productivity in our nation. A better cities program, a better park bench, will do nothing to resolve those fundamental structural difficulties.

Many people are moving to provincial areas and rural residential estates to opt out of city life. They want to get away from the pollution, the crime and the social despair. How much better it would have been if this $800m had been allocated towards a worthwhile and carefully thought out decentralisation program, because people leaving the city areas are leaving for areas where there are no jobs, no services and no facilities. They move to new hopelessness and despair. They enjoy a better lifestyle, and these new provincial areas provide wonderful opportunities for business and for people to enjoy a better lifestyle.

We ought to encourage industry to locate in rural and provincial areas. There will be major savings not only for industry but for our nation. Industry will enjoy the benefits of a skilled and cooperative work force and of a supportive community where the local authorities will not put obstruction in their way. There will be no protest groups, but there will be encouragement and support, away from the union bosses who would do nothing but try to destroy a productive industry. For our nation, there will be a better utilised infrastructure and cheaper land; social and welfare measures would not be needed in the urban areas; there will be less pollution and a much more wholesome lifestyle for all.

Cities are costly places. Land for schools, hospitals and roads is expensive. Urban public transport annually chalks up huge losses--something like $2 billion for the city rail system alone--and most of it is in Sydney and Melbourne. There is much that we can do to improve the urban lifestyle, but this money would be far better spent and far better used if it were devoted to well thought out regional development programs to ensure a better lifestyle for all Australians.

While the Budget has this grand plan to squander $800m on froth and bubble and tinsel and lights in the cities, it does very little to confront the crisis in rural Australia. The Budget clearly acknowledges the severe hurt in the rural sector. The Treasurer has just moved from the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, so he should have known the position. After all, he helped to create much of the trouble that currently exists. However, he soon forgot his old ministry. There is very little, and certainly nothing of substance, to help revitalise the rural sector; indeed, much of what is contained in the Budget under the banner of primary industry will provide little or nothing for farmers.

For instance, the primary industry budget provides $26.4m for new flood warning systems in Sydney, Brisbane, Newcastle and Wollongong. There are not too many wheat paddocks in Wollongong, yet there is a new flood system under the primary industry budget for those cities.

Of course, there is the ever increasing primary industry bureaucracy. On 21 February this year, I asked a question on notice about the staff levels of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister confirmed that the Department currently has 4,600 staff. One thousand five hundred of the 4,600 staff are in the middle management level and 1,200 of these 1,500 staff are located in Canberra. In addition, there are some staff in senior management. One does not need to go beyond grade two mathematics to figure out that that is approximately one person in middle and senior management for every two workers in the Department. In addition, something like three-quarters of all those staff are located in Canberra. There are not too many farmers in Canberra and yet we have this enormous primary industry bureaucracy located in the national capital.

It seems to me that this burgeoning national bureaucracy associated with primary industry, not only at the Federal level but also at the State level, is biting deeply into what little rural income there is in this day and age. I suspect that the take home pay of all of the farmers in Australia this year will be less than will be spent on the primary industry bureaucracy. Clearly, we need to look at our priorities in this regard.

In amongst the fine print, the Budget announced that this year the Industry Commission's work program will include a review of primary industry policy and regional policy. My immediate reaction to that was: surely there are no primary industry policies left that have not been reviewed?

The Industry Commission has successfully destroyed most of the farm industries in this country. It is currently reviewing the dairy and sugar industries, and there are not too many left. Yet we are to have another review of primary industry policy. The farm organisations despair at the amount of time they have to spend responding to these bureaucratic inquiries, when seemingly the commissioners take no notice of the real facts, yet there is to be another inquiry into primary industry policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Jobs for the bureaucrats.

—-No doubt many more jobs for many more bureaucrats. In addition, there is to be a new review into regional policy. I admit that I did not think the Government had any regional policy; if it did, it was probably left over from the Whitlam days, the dreadful regional concept that the Left promoted at that time. I suppose the rise of the Left within the Labor Party has led to a rebirth of regionalism also within the Labor organisation. Is this inquiry to try to resurrect that old skeleton? Certainly thousands of people around Australia deeply hope that is not the case. Or is it again to review what small level of service is left in the rural sector around this country? Is it another guise to try to axe services to country people? Will Federal Labor follow in the same footsteps as the Goss Labor Government in Queensland?

SPEECH.PARA: The Goss Labor Government has employed half of all of the new public servants appointed in Australia over the past 12 months. Half of those employed by Federal, State and local governments around the country have been engaged by the Goss Government. It has gathered together a collection of failed bureaucrats from the southern State regimes to ensure that Queensland is unable to prosper into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They will probably get a few from Gorbachev.

—-They have employed them from all over the place, but they are all failures. They have gone to Queensland to burden the bureaucracy of that State. In spite of that, the Goss Government has axed jobs ruthlessly in provincial Queensland. Twenty- six court houses have been closed and hundreds of rail sidings and stations. There has been a loss of 174 staff in just one section of the Department of Primary Industries. The Queensland Minister for Transport tells us that in tomorrow's Budget he will axe 900 road construction jobs--all in areas of critical importance to the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Industry Commission now to be used by the Federal Government to follow in the same footsteps and to axe regional services? If the Industry Commission has got nothing to do, why does it not look at Medicare? The Labor Government does not know what to do with it. The Caucus is going to have another try at it. Let us give the Industry Commission a go at fixing up Medicare. What about looking at the Government's industrial relations policy, or its policy on the arts and the environment, or its policy on the social welfare industry? What about looking at the Government itself and its gross levels of incompetence?

If the Government could apply the same principles to those areas which I have just mentioned as it has applied to primary industries over the years, our country would be a much more productive place. The Government's only new rural measures have been in some small areas of welfare. There has been nothing to address the causes of the degradation of rural areas. There is no tax relief, substantial structural reform or industry support.

Under the measures that have been announced many families will be worse off. The Government is making a third attempt to reintroduce an assets test on the family allowance. It tried at $300,000, and it compromised at $500,000. Fortunately, the coalition parties rejected that assets test. Now the Government is trying again at $600,000, and thousands of Australian families will be denied the family allowance. Thousands of families will be worse off and most of those will be in small business and on the family farm.

There have, of course, been a few concessions. There will be some hardship provisions, but amongst the conditions attached to those hardship provisions is one that will mean that anyone with more than $10,000 in working capital will not be eligible. I know that we have a new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and that he does not have much of a record in agriculture, but I would like to ask him when he last planted a paddock of wheat or bought a load of feed for a piggery or filled the farm fuel tanks. One cannot do any of those tasks for less than $10,000. Any farmer who is still in business will need to have a minimum of $10,000 working capital--and a whole lot more. For that reason alone, such farmers will not qualify for the new hardship provisions under the family allowance supplement or for Austudy as well. They will have to be on welfare or on rural adjustment part C. As I have already mentioned, farmers are not eligible for most of these welfare programs, so little of these concessions will have any real value for ordinary Australians caught up in the rural crisis.

I appeal to the Minister. He is new in his position, and I could understand if he did not appreciate the full economics of running a rural property. I urge him to reconsider his decision if he has any compassion or any sincerity and if he meant his promises to the rural sector that he would do something about ensuring that those on farms have equal access to welfare and other benefits. I appeal to him to reconsider that decision and to make those hardship provisions meaningful and worth while.

Just two weeks after its presentation, this Budget is in tatters. All of its central planks have fallen apart. Like the Government that introduced it, it has failed. Even Caucus wants to try again, but Labor has lost the capacity to get it right. I can only hope that our country can survive this maladministration until there is another election. The Treasurer has sadly failed his first test and Australians everywhere will suffer continually as a result of this dismal Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In rising to speak in support of the Appropriation Bills, I would like at the outset to take up a couple of the points made by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss). It seems that he is suggesting, on behalf of the National Party, an approach to government similar to that of the Queensland branch of the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member criticised the better cities project, towards which this Budget has allocated $56m, not the figure he spoke about. Maybe we should adopt the Queensland branch's approach of looking at what it achieved on the Gold Coast. Maybe that would be the sort of alternative strategy that would be suggested. Another alternative would be to wheel out the pork barrel in the way that was suggested in terms of the rural issues that the honourable member talked about. I recall having the same discussion with him in a previous debate.

Above all else, what is highlighted not only by the honourable member for Wide Bay but by so many of those who have gone before him is that, on the one hand, there is this constant attack on the Government because there is too much public expenditure, too much provision of services in the Budget and, on the other hand, according to the National Party and the Opposition generally, that should be cut back. At the same time, the Opposition has got all these new programs that it suggests the Government should be funding. It says that the Government should be providing money for services in rural or other areas.

One of the difficulties we have is that at the same time as that is occurring, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), are saying that this Budget should have been balanced. I do not know how they would achieve the variety of objectives that the Opposition is talking about. There seems to be this constant sort of resorting to humbug and hypocrisy. The equation just does not balance.

The Opposition, through all its speakers, decided not to come up with any detail about policy, direction or alternatives. It does not talk about that. Opposition members do not talk about any of those things; rather, they come here and cry crocodile tears about the sorts of difficulties that many Australians are facing. Many Australians are facing difficulties in both urban Australia and rural Australia. To suggest that the problems can be isolated to one area, as the honourable member for Wide Bay sought to do, was wrong. To suggest that the Government is not addressing the problems, as the honourable member for Wide Bay sought to do, was wrong. Also, to suggest that the Budget strategy that underpins the process that we are following through is not going to the heart of those issues is totally fallacious.

The Budget process this year shows a recognition that the country is facing very serious economic difficulties. It is a recognition that there has to be a sustained passage out of that recessionary period and it is a recognition that what we need for Australia is long term low inflation and, at the same time, a sustainable, outward looking country, which we could never achieve in the decades that the Liberal and National parties ruled Australia.

This Budget goes to the very heart of those problems. There is no doubt that the move of the Budget from surplus to deficit was critical to help to provide the sort of basic stimulus that is needed at the same time. The ongoing interest rate strategy adopted by the Government is important. It is worth noting that the process of lowering interest rates started in February 1990.

On every occasion that there has been adjustment in the easing of monetary policy since February 1990, the Opposition said it was inappropriate. On every occasion the Opposition has condemned those initiatives that have been taken to ease monetary policy, believing, as it has said all the way through, that this was a political sort of response; that this was the Government and the Reserve Bank operating in a political way. On each occasion the Opposition said the adjustment either would fuel inflation or was not recognising the underlying trends in the economy. At different times, it has said that, rather than a continuation of the low inflation strategy that had been adopted, we would see the boom and bust sorts of symptoms that have occurred in the past when the Opposition parties were running monetary policy in Australia.

That has not happened, so the change in monetary policy yesterday was appropriate because it recognises the continuing need to promote business investment and to provide the stimulus that is needed. I do not believe or accept that it is going to cause the fuelling of inflation that people have talked about. One only has to talk to the people in the community to recognise that it is appropriate to have a modest easing in monetary policy now and to ensure that it is fully passed on to consumers and, particularly, the business investors. They deserve to have the full 8 1/2 per cent cut in official rates which has occurred since February 1990 passed on to them. The responsibility of the banks and financial institutions to do that should be recognised by all.

Underpinning all of that process to try to ensure that we move out of the economic difficulties that the country faces is a recognition on the part of the Government that it must maintain the low inflation strategy and also its commitment to the well-being of ordinary Australians. Unemployment is a very serious problem. It is a major concern for people across the country. The Government has recognised the problem of unemployment and is responding as it should. It is ensuring that the skills base that is needed to be maintained as we move out of economic difficulties is there with the additional funds that have been provided to training programs to the education sector and to that vital skills base.

It is worth noting that if we compare the recession today with that of 1982-83, we see a very marked change, particularly in areas such as western Sydney, which I represent. These days people are actually able to complete school; they are able to get a tertiary education. This Budget has been criticised by some in the Liberal Party for not doing enough and by others in the Liberal Party for spending too much. We have continued to increase the funding for higher education because we recognise that training and skills will be critical for the country's future and for its economic recovery. It is pleasing to note that an extra 13,000 higher education places are being funded in the Budget, on top of the 100,000 places already funded by the Federal Government since it came to office in March 1983.

We have the very real statistic that in 1983 something like 25 per cent of young people in western Sydney were unemployed. Not only do we have that dreadful statistic, but we also had the statistic of only one in three people completing secondary education, let alone going on to any form of tertiary or technical education. Those statistics have changed dramatically. Today two in three school leavers from western Sydney, which is the greatest population growth base in the country, complete higher education. That is ensuring that the opportunities and the scope for those people to get employment are a dramatic improvement on what might have been the case had the sort of non-existent policies and the lack of strategy of the Liberals been allowed to follow through.

Even worse than that, we have repeatedly heard about the level of unemployment from the Leader of the Opposition and others who have spoken in the Budget debate. They decline to recognise that when they left office in 1983 they not only had double digit unemployment but they also had double digit interest rates and double digit inflation. They achieved a unique trifecta in that regard. It was an appalling record. Their policies, as far as we can judge them to date, suggest that they have not learnt at all from that.

In his contribution, the honourable member for Wide Bay complained about the growth in Commonwealth expenditure to deal with the problem of urban flooding. I raise this particularly because the honourable member for Wide Bay suggested that somehow it was inappropriate for the Government to allocate money to deal with the problems of urban flooding. Last night in the adjournment debate I said that the Commonwealth Government had rightly increased its contribution to deal with this vital problem. Over 400 homes were flooded in the western part of Sydney in 1986 and almost the same number were flooded in 1988. Twice since then several homes have been flooded in my electorate.

In conjunction with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), we have been seeking solutions to those problems. I am delighted that the Federal Government responded, as it did in this year's Budget, by providing a special initiative to seek to deal with that problem. That is a very important and worthwhile step. It deals very much with the heart of the safety and well-being of ordinary Australians--something that governments should have been dealing with for decades.

The Federal Government has not only provided $1m for the western Sydney flood drainage initiative, it has also provided major funding under the Federal water resources assistance program. The Commonwealth Government has allocated $805,000 to the Parramatta River catchment project. That is a very timely funding allocation as well.

These issues are made even more stark for the people of western Sydney because at the same time as the Federal Government increased funding for these particular flood mitigation initiatives we have had the spectacle of the State Government refusing to cooperate in providing funding. Last year when the Federal Government allocated three quarters of a million dollars for local flood mitigation works in western Sydney, the local councils and the local community sought more funding. They were supported in that campaign by the New South Wales Liberal-National Party Government.

I attended a deputation to the then Minister responsible for water resources in New South Wales. He made the statement to me that if any extra Federal funding was provided towards these works, he would ensure that the State Government matched those funds. As a result of that, I went back with my colleagues to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and said, `We need supplementary funds in 1990-91 towards urban flood mitigation works in western Sydney'. After considerable deliberation and difficulty, the Minister was able to ensure that those funds were allocated in June this year. An extra quarter of a million dollars that had to be matched by the State Government was allocated towards these vital flood mitigation works. The announcement was made in that regard.

Following that, the New South Wales Minister--having given a public assurance as well as an assurance to me personally at a deputation and an assurance in the New South Wales Parliament--reneged. He refused to match that Commonwealth funding. As a result, the opportunity to accelerate these urgent flood mitigation works was lost. Even worse than that, the State Government is saying that it does not believe the announcement that we made about the urban flood mitigation program in this year's Budget is appropriate. It does not see urban flood relief and flood mitigation works as appropriate. It would rather see the money spent in the pork- barrelling way that the National Party is notorious for. We will not let that happen. However, it highlights the Opposition parties' complete duplicity at all levels, particularly the duplicity of the State National Party and the State Government of New South Wales, in their refusal to contribute the same assistance as was provided by the Commonwealth Government in this regard.

This matter was highlighted further last week in the State Parliament when the Deputy Premier of New South Wales criticised the Federal Government for the lack of support for this particular initiative. At the same time he said that it was writing to the Commonwealth to say that it was not going to match the Federal Government's funding for these particular works. What humbug! What hypocrisy! The spectacle of the lack of integrity in the Liberal-National parties approach to these issues is there for all to see.

Another area in this year's Budget which highlights the Government's recognition of key areas of growth and key opportunities for Australia is tourism. In this year's Budget and in the March economic statement the Government committed a massive increase in funding to tourism promotion overseas. At this stage the tourism budget now stands at $65m per annum. The great bulk of the increase in funding is going to the promotion of Australia as a tourism destination in Asia, the United States and Europe. We have already started to see the benefits of that flow through.

I have some figures that show that levels of tourism have increased significantly in the last few months. Obviously, the difficulty with the Gulf war has ensured that the growth is not as great as it could have been otherwise. Now that that situation is behind us, the scope for a massive growth in Australia's tourism industry, with the resultant employment and foreign exchange earnings that that creates, is there for all to see. It is projected that this year our earnings in foreign exchange from tourism will be 10 per cent of our total export earnings.

It is also worth noting that we expect 2.4 million visitors to Australia this financial year. This is because the Government, in conjunction with the tourism industry, has recognised the strategic value of this industry--its potential as a multiplier in terms of not only foreign exchange but also job creation and sustainable long term jobs, not only in cities but in regional Australia and in the key tourism destinations right around the nation.

What alternatives to that does the Opposition suggest? The Leader of the Opposition has refused to commit any future Liberal government to the same level of expenditure on the promotion of tourism. He has publicly refused to do that on many occasions. He has been given the opportunity by the industry but refuses to treat campaigns such as the Greg Norman tourism campaign as serious issues that should be taken up on behalf of his Party. Not only that, but the alternative suggestion of the Liberal-National Party is its goods and services tax. It is worth while considering what the effect of the goods and services tax would be on the tourism industry and to again highlight the inconsistencies in the arguments relating to these matters.

To give an example, the shadow Minister for tourism attacked councils in north Queensland because they were talking about proposing a bed tax. He said that that would be repugnant to everything that the tourism industry needs and stands for in that part of Australia. How can he attack that tax but at the same time advocate a value added tax on all the tourism services throughout north Queensland--or anywhere else in Australia?

Let us take another example of the difficulties that the consumption tax would impose on tourism. What is the situation as far as people who are buying Qantas tickets are concerned? Will the goods and services tax apply to all of those sorts of tickets? Surely, if we just apply a tax in that form the net result would be to send tourism offshore. It would not promote it. People would buy their one-way fare here and then pick up their return fare elsewhere as it would be free of the value added tax and cheaper. With the goods and services tax and this disincentive, effectively we would be destroying Qantas's capacity. Not only that, but many comparable countries applying the VAT for tourism services, particularly relating to goods, exempt foreign tourists from the VAT. Apparently, the Opposition does not believe that that is the way to go.

The net effect of a consumption tax would be to greatly harm the promotional and climatic advantages that Australia has, and it would hit the very industries that we are trying to promote and encourage. It cannot be applied effectively to the tourism industry. It would devastate the industry. As people in north Queensland have been told by the shadow Minister for tourism, any form of bed tax or any form of additional impost of that sort would be a total anathema to their natural interests. That being the case, honourable members opposite cannot come in here with any integrity and say that they believe in promoting Australian industries that are good at promoting and developing themselves, such as tourism, while at the same time advocating the introduction of a goods and services tax. The two things just do not sit together. That is the sort of dilemma that the Opposition will be faced with. That is why it will have great difficulty producing a tax package that actually does the necessary sorts of compensatory things to make up for this iniquitous goods and services tax.

This Budget is a constructive document. It recognises both the economic concerns and needs of Australia, and the need to develop a broad and impressive country which can lead to the bulk of the economic recovery that we need to have. The economic recovery does need to be in areas such as tourism. It does need to be in areas that generate export potential for us. We need to recognise that Australia must become an outward looking, competitive country. The Budget provides the mechanism, as did the March industry statement, to ensure that those things happen. For that reason, I believe it is a good document. It recognises our difficulties while at the same time it provides the right sort of impetus for Australia to go forward into the next decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Although the first Budget to be brought down by the new Labor Treasurer, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), on 20 August was more realistic than those of his predecessor, it was nevertheless a dour and dismal one over which the grim spectre of unemployment, with all its disastrous implications, loomed large. It was a Budget born of a decade of public and corporate excess, when increasingly more money was being spent than was being earned. In the Budget the Hawke Labor Government was forced to concede, if only indirectly, that the fiscal and budgetary policies of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), were not merely cavalier but also thoroughly irresponsible.

SPEECH.PARA: During the 1980s, under Labor, Australia's foreign debt increased alarmingly. When the Liberal-National coalition lost government in March 1983, the net foreign debt was $23.4 billion. In March of this year it had risen to $133.3 billion. So, after eight years of hard Labor, the debt had quintupled. Similarly, Australia's gross foreign debt last March stood at $165.5 billion whereas in 1983 it was a fraction of that figure, at $35.8 billion.

Even though interest rates in Australia have, thankfully, dropped during the past year--including the just announced one per cent reduction--overall, Labor's term of office has been characterised by excessively high interest rates compared with those of our OECD trading partners. Our average interest rate, according to June 1991 statistics, was running at 11.15 per cent. In May of this year our interest rate was 10.75 per cent. This was lower than for any time since Labor took office, but it was still clearly higher than that of any of our major trading partners. Our interest rate in May compared most unfavourably with Japan at 7 per cent, the United Kingdom at 9.9 per cent, the United States at 8.33 per cent, Germany at 8.4 per cent and New Zealand at 9.7 per cent. The figures speak for themselves.

How can Australian business be expected to compete favourably on the world market, given the significant disadvantage imposed over time by this nation's higher average interest rate? Most honourable members in this place would realise that, additionally, the Labor Government in the 1980s has been a party to and responsible for incompetently implemented financial deregulation without the balancing factor of adequate prudential controls. The Labor Party has directly and indirectly encouraged corporate excesses. Skase and Bond--and there are several others, of course--have become household names synonymous with suspect financial practice. The people know only too well that they, the taxpayers, are left to foot the bill. Who in this place has not heard of Tricontinental? Who, particularly in my own State of Victoria, has not wondered why no Government Minister, no financier or no lawyer has been found guilty of fraud, impropriety or even negligence and why once more the people will have to pay that debt?

As far as I know, the only person to have been convicted in this regard was a Melbourne man, Kiang Lang Teh, a former accountant with the National Companies and Securities Commission, who as recently as 2 September was sentenced to three months gaol and ordered to pay $36,594 to the Commonwealth for insider trading. Teh used confidential and price sensitive information to trade in company shares before the information was made public. However, the trial judge, Judge Kelly, said that Teh was a `petty employee' who would not be made a scapegoat for community anger against, in the judge's words, `serious fraudsters'. In sentencing, the judge said that the community had been `betrayed by sundry large-scale manipulators of companies and financial institutions'. The judge added that to severely punish Teh would indicate that `the law was incapable of catching and punishing serious fraudsters but harsh in its dealing with petty employees'.

Recently, Melbourne-based feature writers like Kenneth Davidson and Terry McCrann have highlighted this corporate immorality. Sentiments similar to those of Judge Kelly were expressed by Terry McCrann in his article entitled `Greed rules' that was published in the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 18 July, in which he scathingly wrote:

It's easy to look back on the 1980s as the decade of greed, in which business ethics evaporated and corporate morality collapsed. Some millions of dollars were made and/or plundered--then spent in a long-running orgy of highly conspicuous consumption. . . While it was happening there were few questioning voices. Now that it's all over there appears to be little reckoning. . . The banks just write off the billions of dollars in bad loans. Nobody goes to gaol. . . and they (the corporate offenders) are still seen in polite society.

Mr McCrann later attributes the corporate immorality of the 1980s to the `glossy projection of the entrepreneur' and to financial deregulation. I would add that it was deregulation without the balancing adequate prudential controls needed to implement it effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Deakin will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—-My question is directed to the temporary Prime Minister.
—-Order!

—-I remind the Prime Minister of his election commitment that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy in the term of this Parliament. In view of the fact that the Prime Minister was rolled yesterday by Caucus on the $3.50 co-payment, does he absolutely stand by that commitment not to raise the levy or add an additional levy in relation to Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At least the Leader of the Opposition has the advantage on me in this area: he has nothing he can go back on in regard to health policy, because he has none. He cannot break any promise about health policy because he has none. Let me make it quite clear that, as far as the Government is concerned, in the preparations for the Budget we had to face up to a real issue about the problem of the increase in services being provided at a rate which would bring about a doubling in 20 years, and we made decisions in regard to that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Leader of the Opposition that, going back to 1983, this is not the first time when this Government has had to face up to hard issues and make decisions which have created problems in the community, including in my own Party. I take members opposite back to 1983. It is a period that they would not want to remember because, in the August 1983 Budget, we faced up to the question of an assets test. We inherited a position where the Opposition was paying pensions to millionaires and we decided that that was crook, so we brought it to an end.

I can see the Leader of the Opposition smiling, and well he might smile. The decision then created a bit of a problem, including in my own Party. What did we do? We did not walk away from the decision. We said to our Party, as we said to the community, `All right, it's legitimate--

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is legitimate.
—-Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—-We said, `It is legitimate that you should express your interest and concern'. We set up processes within the Caucus, within the Party, we had consultations and we stuck to our guns. We took the advantage of listening to what our people had to say, unlike what the Opposition did. The then Leader of the Opposition went around the length and breadth of the country saying that this was the end of civilisation as we knew it and that, as sure as night follows day, he would bring it to an end. Of course, what the electorate did was both respect us and re-elect us. We were respected and we were re-elected. That was in 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Budget of 1988-89, again we had to tackle a very fundamental issue, and that was in the pharmacy industry. We had an oversupply of pharmacists. In the Budget of 1988-89, we again took a tough decision. This created a lot of concern and heartburning in the community, including in my own Party. What did we do? Again, we set up the processes within the Party. We examined the issue. As always, we had against us the opportunists of the Opposition lining themselves up, as they did with the chemists, as they did with the pilots. But we did not run away from the decision and, as in 1984, in 1990 we were respected and we were re-elected--as we will be in 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Treasurer.
—-Order! The honourable member for Chifley will cease interjecting.

—-I preface my question to the Treasurer by acknowledging the news of the announcement of a fall in interest rates this week, which is particularly welcome for the business community and the farmers. I ask the Treasurer to outline to the House the process and rationale underpinning the Government's decision to reduce interest rates by one per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have been interested in some of the comments about the interest rate decision. If some commentators had their way, we should have dropped interest rates on 7 August when the quarterly figures came out and put them up again on 30 August when the housing figures came out. What I have been at pains to point out is that we are following due process and there is a lot of confusion about due process in politics. The reality is that due process required an announcement yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have already made clear, yesterday was the first time the Reserve Bank Board met since the Budget was brought down. It does not meet in August. We needed to announce--and it needed to announce--the decision before a bond tender of $1.5 billion yesterday. That is not politics--far from it. It is transparent, sensible management of monetary policy. It is the working out of due process. The opposite to having deals and perceptions as the driving force in economics and political decisions is having detailed policy, economic analysis and due process. That is what we have done.

If people really want to be critical of the decision, the Governor of the Reserve Bank has delivered an address this morning that carefully argues the case for a one per cent cut in interest rates. Again, if people wish to label this decision as political, they will need to address the arguments outlined by the Governor of the Reserve Bank.

This decision reinforces the prospects for economic growth outlined in the 1991-92 Budget. The Budget was introduced, as is always the case, with the intention that monetary policy would be set appropriately. In fact, the Budget Papers stated that monetary policy will `remain sufficiently firm to restrain inflationary expectations and not jeopardise the recovery in domestic demand'. Yesterday's decision is totally consistent with that approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is again directed to the temporary Prime Minister. In view of the fact that the Prime Minister did not answer my question the first time around, will he or will he not raise the Medicare levy during the term of this Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have already dealt with this question. The committee of the Caucus which has been set up on the initiative of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services will examine all these issues. The important thing that the Opposition needs to know in the area of health policy is this: we will stick to the policy of Medicare, which was brought into this country to rectify the obscenity which the Opposition left, where two million Australians were uncovered, and we will adhere to a position where the characteristics of Medicare are maintained.
—-Nothing you say is believed.
—-Order! The Prime Minister might resume his seat. The member for Mayo will withdraw that remark.
—-I withdraw.

—-We will maintain this great scheme, this great system, which is respected by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. Its two outstanding characteristics are its universality and its equity, and those two characteristics will be maintained. We will consider what the Caucus committee has to put to us. It will be looking at the issue that we as a Cabinet addressed--that is, how we deal with the massive increase in servicing which means that every 20 years, if nothing is done about it, we will have a doubling of servicing. That is not a situation which can be allowed to go on.

ANSWER.PARA: With the same degree of responsibility that they showed in 1983 on assets tests and in 1989 in regard to pharmacists, my colleagues in the Caucus will bring to bear the same sense of relevance, purpose and rigour which will enable us to bring down the decisions which will be appropriate for the welfare of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What factors led to the Government's Budget decision to legislate for occupational superannuation and, further, in coming to this decision, what alternatives were considered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The decisions announced in the Budget about superannuation represent a necessary and pivotal long term reform. The factors that are behind the decision are historical and they also anticipate demographic changes. As I have said on other occasions, something like 11 per cent of the population is now aged 65 or more; 20 or 30 years down the track that figure will go up to 18 per cent. Whereas today there are five people in employment for every person over 65, by the year 2021 there will be only three. So this decision being taken now, this reform, is correct, it is timely and it is fair.

ANSWER.PARA: It is all right our sitting here as politicians--and on the other side they do so very hypocritically--because we have a big, fat superannuation fund but, no, the rest of the population cannot have it. About two-thirds of the population have some form of superannuation, and the Opposition is saying the rest of the work force cannot have it. This reform is about tidying up the tail on superannuation. Award superannuation was provided for in 1986 as part of the productivity-wages trade off, and we want to tidy up the non-compliance and the non-award area. This is part of the retirement incomes policy. There are two legs to that. There is always going to be the income support part of it through the age pension and, of course, we are giving more and more scope for self-provision. Let us have a look at some of the recent comments. On 18 August the Leader of the Opposition said:
. . . I don't believe that occupational superannuation makes any sense in a country like Australia.
The next thing he says, on 22 August, with total cynicism--a bit of reverse snobbery--is:
Superannuation has been rorted for the benefit of the rich against the poor.

Just eight years ago superannuation was a joke. The situation we inherited from the Liberals was an absolute farce. It was little more than a means whereby the rich milked the tax system for all it was worth. Lump sums were virtually exempt from tax. There was no assets test on the government pension, so superannuation lump sums did not affect entitlements at all. If they had any choice, nobody took a superannuation pension, and annuities were almost unheard of. There was no roll-over mechanism to enable superannuation benefits received on changing jobs to continue and to accumulate in a concessionally taxed environment. Vesting and preservation standards were only limited and, most serious of all, superannuation was the preserve of a very small proportion of the work force. It was rorted; it was a farce; and the Opposition did nothing about it.

We have changed all that. We have put a comprehensive retirement incomes policy in place and the tax applying to superannuation has been cleaned up, placing superannuation on a sustainable long term basis. Preservation and vesting have been introduced and award superannuation has dramatically increased coverage. So with our policies we have cleaned out the rorts, we have made the system fairer, and I will just mention that access to superannuation tax concessions is limited by a person's reasonable benefit limit. The reasonable benefit limit is now also on a tapered scale ensuring more equitable distribution of tax concessions.

What we have put in place, for a range of reasons, is a major reform that is timely and fair. We have wiped out the rorts, we are making sure that the Australian population takes care once and for all for its own retirement, and we are doing it now--and only Labor could do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question again is to the even more temporary Prime Minister. In view of the Prime Minister's failure on two occasions this afternoon to reconfirm his commitment, his election promise, that there will be no increase in the Medicare levy in the life of this Parliament, are we to conclude that that promise is now in the same category as `no child will live in poverty by 1990' and `there will be no recession'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I invite the Leader of the Opposition to draw any conclusion that he wishes, but rather than engaging in such idle speculation, if I could--in my normal, charitable and generous manner--I will make this suggestion to him: rather than speculate about what we will do, he should get out his whip and make his day, make the people's day, make Australia's day by producing an Opposition health policy. There is not one. That is what he ought to be doing: producing an Opposition health policy. Then we can have a serious debate about this issue. We were denied it last time. The Leader of the Opposition knows what happened in regard to health policy: his Opposition shadow spokesman had to stand up--nothing like this had ever happened in the history of politics in this country--on the eve of the last election and say, `Australian electorate, I am sorry, we are going into this election without a health policy'. He said, `You know what our record is like, it is terrible'--and he was right; it was a terrible track record. The Opposition could not produce a policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition not waste his time speculating what we will be doing. We will be going on, as we do, doing the job of governing for this country. The Opposition should produce a policy of its own.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to his very successful visit to Queensland last week and to my electorate of Kennedy in particular. I ask the Minister whether he can inform the House of the response he received from the rural community to the proposal for a goods and services tax. In light of that response, is it the Government's intention to reconsider its position and introduce a GST?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The reality is that it was a very successful trip and the feedback I have had suggests that that seat, under the current member, will remain in Labor's hands for a long time to come. The reality is that we did have an opportunity to meet with many people, including the delegation----

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Carlton interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—-We had the opportunity to meet with many farm groups while we were there, including the delegation that the honourable member for Groom, last time we sat, suggested I should meet with. The overriding concern that consistently came through from these groups was the confusion and uncertainty associated with the Opposition policy for a goods and services tax. I make our position clear again: the Government has stated categorically that it will not be introducing a goods and services tax, essentially because it is regressive and it is inflationary.
—-So you will maintain sales tax.

—-I will come to it in a minute. Let us understand where the honourable member stands. It is regressive because it will fall most heavily on low income families and therefore will most affect farm families in this country. The reality is that it is not our policy to sell, it is the Opposition's. The difficulty is, as the Prime Minister said today in regard to health policy, that the Opposition has not yet told us what the detail of its policy is.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Tim Fischer interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—-Let us go to some of the concerns I have raised and which are reflected by these people. One of the assertions that is made about the goods and services tax is that the Opposition will exempt the tax on inputs to people on the farm.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sharp interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Gilmore!

—- The reality is we do it now. We do it now as a result of the exemptions under the wholesale sales tax and, I might add, the package of measures announced in the March economic statement totalling $200m, which the Leader of the Opposition says we should not give away. But we have done it. So what is the Opposition offering? How can it say that a goods and services tax is going to relieve those people from the input component which is already exempt? In addition to that, what does the Opposition do? Give them more paperwork to claim the exemption that they already have. That is a great package!
—-The NFF says so.
—-The Leader of the National Party!

—-Let us come to the question of fuel, because this did seem to have some attraction in the bush. The Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the shadow Treasurer, is on record as saying that the goods and services tax will produce lower fuel costs to farmers. But let us just have a look at what the policy as released by the National Party says. All it says, in relation to a goods and services tax on fuel, is that `the goods and services tax element of all fuels used in farming will be rebated'--not that excise will be abolished, but only that the goods and services component will be rebated. In other words, all the Opposition will do is give back what it put on.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is what the policy says. National Party members do not understand it because they have been conned by this mob. They do not understand it.
—-Order! The House will come to order.

—-Let me go a bit further. The fact of the matter is that there is no wholesale sales tax on petrol, therefore there is nothing to take off, except the excise tax, and to put back on this so-called rebate. But it gets worse for the farmers. The policy in fact says `rebate on all fuels'. What about diesel?

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Lloyd interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Deputy Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—-What about diesel--diesel for which we as a Government exempt the totality of excise? We already exempt it, but all that honourable members opposite are offering to do in their policy is to rebate the goods and services tax element. Does that mean they will give up the excise element on diesel fuel, which is 85 per cent of all excisable fuel used on farms? So where is the gain from this great strategy? That is the question that farmers in this country are entitled to ask because the Opposition has not come up with the details. In addition to this great strategy that produces no gain, what are honourable members opposite going to do? They will hit them with a 15 per cent hike on everything they spend. On top of the price for everything that they now purchase there will be 15 per cent. There will be no gain but all the pain. It is against that background----

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Carlton interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!

—-It is against that background that I think the farmers in Queensland and the members of the National Party are far more intelligent than honourable members opposite give them credit for. The fact of the matter is that the Leader of the National Party issued a press release, having returned from Geraldton on Sunday, saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Now all states have endorsed the principle of a Goods and Services Tax.
