Let us just understand what has happened in Queensland in this section which does understand the concerns, and has raised them. The National Party put a proposition. This is what the secretariat tried to put up:
That this conference supports the concept of a Goods and Services Tax.
What did that conference carry? The Leader of the National Party got rolled. The conference carried this:

That this conference supports the concept of a National Economic Reform Package. If a GST is to be introduced as a component of a national economic reform package it calls for it to contain the following provisos. . .
It then lists something as long as one's arm. All I am saying is that if one can read into that a unanimous endorsement for the Opposition strategy, one is doing far better than I am.
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The reality is that the conference did not support the Opposition. It does not deserve its support. There are many doubts, so why does the Opposition not get the details on the table? It should come clean, because the National Party has been conned and its constituents are being conned. As Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I will not let them continue to be conned.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—-I ask the temporary Treasurer: does he stand by the changes announced in the March industry statement in respect of depreciation rules and, if so, could he give the House and the business community here and now a clear and concise statement of how these rules are supposed to operate as from 1 July this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The 12 March statement announced changes to depreciation, and that legislation has yet to come to the Parliament. The main reason for the delay, as the honourable gentleman is aware, is that we said we would consult with industry. The changes that we announced then basically were for an immediate write-off for any investment of a three-year life or $300, asset pooling, self- assessment and definition of effective life. There are some other minor changes to what was put forward. The business community, in its various components, has various attitudes about some of these components that we announced. I am in discussion with both the business community and Senator Button, and we hope to bring that forward to the Parliament as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I would stress in all of this is that we will get a far more sensible depreciation system out of this discussion, out of this work, but in some instances we may have to make some accommodation for some specific industries. Industry itself is not agreed about all of this. The question of definition of `effective life' for some industries is quite different from others and there is simply a lot of work to do. Again, we are doing the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask a question of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has his attention been drawn to suggestions that the Budget should be in balance? Can he advise the House of the implications for programs in his portfolio of the expenditure cuts necessary to achieve such a result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I noticed in what must go down in history as probably one of the most complacent and vacuous replies given in this House to any Budget that the Leader of the Opposition advocated that this year's Budget should have indeed been a balanced one. The first consequence of a balanced Budget this year would, on the basis of the Murphy model, to which the Opposition itself subscribes, be to increase unemployment by 46,000. That is the first consequence of a balanced Budget--to directly increase unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to get to a balanced Budget, one would first have to adjust the revenue and expenditure sides. As has been pointed out on many occasions, this is one of the many areas where the Leader of the Opposition has yet to come clean, that is, how he would reduce expenditure in order to achieve this in any event incorrect objective.

But if we go back to the last election and the economic action plan we get some hints, some clues, as to where expenditure cuts would apply. First of all, the Opposition said at that stage that it would abolish Jobstart, which is worth $93m; it would abolish Skillshare, which is worth nearly $120m; it would abolish the industry training support scheme, worth $45m; it would abolish the new enterprise incentive scheme, worth $22m; and it would remove $9m from the Australian traineeship scheme. That is a reduction of $288m in precisely those programs which are designed to assist the unemployed. In other words, it would add 46,000 to the ranks of the unemployed and remove support for 150,000 of the unemployed as a result of reducing expenditure in these programs. That, of course, is without even mentioning the fact that the Opposition has this appalling policy that will remove assistance from the unemployed after a period of nine months. That is one of the most appalling policies that has ever been proposed, particularly from a party which under current circumstances is beginning to pretend to have an interest in the unemployed.
I might say that the lie was given to the Opposition's real stance on unemployment when the honourable member for Bennelong said on 26 August:
I don't pretend that if the Opposition fell into government tomorrow that overnight we could pull unemployment down. Anyone who runs around saying that is not really coming clean.

Well may he say that. The Opposition has just embraced a slogan used by Mrs Thatcher prior to her 1979 election when she ran around Britain saying that there were a million Britons unemployed and that British Labour was not working. I think the Leader of the Opposition has done us a great service in revealing his true agenda, who his true political icon is, because now we can examine what would be in store for Australia if indeed the consequences of this slogan, the work of these sloganeers, were ever to come to pass in Australia. Mrs Thatcher was elected in 1979. By 1983 the one million unemployed had become in excess of three million unemployed. She managed, in a period of three or four years, to actually treble the rate of unemployment.

Not only did she do that, she was also able to reduce the real GDP of Britain by 1.2 per cent, and--honourable members should listen to this--she was able to get inflation up to 18 per cent in 1980. Here we have the true, secret, hidden agenda of the modern Liberal Party under Dr Hewson. He does not have any compassion for the unemployed; in fact, he is so keen on the unemployed that he wants more of them. A million of them are not enough for him, he wants three million.

This is the real policy of the Liberal Party. This sham compassion is just evidence of the hollow grief coming from a hollow man. The more he is revealed as hollow the more permanent he will become; that is, permanently Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! I inform the House that this afternoon we have present in the Gallery a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of France, led by the President of the France-Australia Parliamentary Group in the National Assembly. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.

—-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Brotherhood of St Laurence is now handing out daily food parcels to hundreds of families queuing at its doorstep. Many of the breadwinners of these families have lost their jobs because of the policies of the Prime Minister's Government. What hope can the Prime Minister give to these people, whom he has thrown onto the welfare scrap heap, while he tries desperately to hang on to his job?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-For a start, I can tell them that I would not be doing what those opposite would be doing if they had the chance. I would say to the unemployed--they would be the people most concerned in the honourable member's hypothetical question--that under the policies of this Government we have substantially increased the benefits that are paid to the unemployed in real terms.

ANSWER.PARA: We certainly would not be saying to the unemployed what those opposite would be saying if they could summon up the honesty to tell them the truth about their policies; that is, that they would be throwing them onto the street, with no unemployment benefit after nine months. Those opposite should not try to wriggle out of it by saying, `We don't really mean it' because I will remind them what was said by their--if I may fall into the trap--increasingly tedious Leader of the Opposition in August 1990:
Why not cut off unemployment, we challenge him (the Treasurer). Cut off unemployment benefits after nine months and match our policy. We are saving about $750m from that change.

I suggest that the honourable member should go along to the Brotherhood of St Laurence and say, `Under the policies of my Leader, we will deliberately increase unemployment in this country', which must be done by a savage cutting of $3 billion to $4 billion in expenditure. He should tell the Brotherhood of St Laurence that the Opposition will increase the number of unemployed. When that has sunk in, he can then say, `By the way, I also want to tell you that I am going to increase the burden on you as I save $750m by throwing the unemployed onto the street'. When he has finished telling the Brotherhood of St Laurence about that, and if it is still prepared to listen to him, he should come back and I will give him the next chapter to tell it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. In the western region of Sydney we face enormous problems caused by lack of investment as well as lack of adequate planning. How will the building better cities program address these issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Prospect for her question, emphasising her concern for the quite serious problems that are evident not only in western Sydney but also in all major cities: the high cost and the lack of suitable housing; the lack of access to services, whether it is health care, child-care or transport; the high costs of enforced car use; and the long distances to work.

ANSWER.PARA: On the subject of distance to work, research indicates that increasing numbers of people--for example, women with dependent children who are in the work force; almost 20 per cent of such people--are now travelling more than an hour each way to and from work. The honourable member for Prospect would know what that statistic means in human terms.

Clearly, the problems that are evident in areas such as western Sydney have to be faced by State governments. Governments need to provide fundamental services, whether it is water, sewerage or power and they need to improve transport and health facilities which arise as much as anything because of the lack of partnership between the different levels of government--Federal, State or local governments.

Clearly, while the Opposition would want to ignore this fact, the Commonwealth exerts great influence on the structure of cities through its migration policies; through its tax policies and the ways that they affect business and investment decisions; through its monetary and industry policies which affect the housing industry; as well as through the decisions it makes as to where its work force is located. In order to improve the cities it is vital that the Commonwealth takes its responsibilities seriously. The better cities program is an important step in developing a partnership between the different levels of government.

In Sydney the minimum cost of a three bedroom house is around $120,000. For this amount, the house is likely to be at least 50 kilometres from the city centre. Sydney will have to house an extra one million people by the year 2006. Yet the land available provides for about 75 per cent of this demand, causing price increases and housing shortages.

Sydney is one of the great cities of the world. The Commonwealth needs to work with the States to ensure that land is available so that the constant pressures of the housing industry are effectively avoided.

Regarding planning, the provision of hospital services to particular areas of cities--for example, the south-west corridor of Sydney--ought to be a matter in which the Commonwealth Government takes no particular interest. These issues are well understood by a number of commentators. For example--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where is the money coming from?

—-The Leader of the Opposition increasingly specialises, like Snow White amid a number of dwarfs, in interventions that have no political content. He says, `Where is the money coming from?' No-one has suggested that the problems that I have referred to are problems that will be solved by the Commonwealth or would be resolved simply by money. But those problems are as much problems of micro-economic reform as any of the other issues that we hear focused on in this Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note that an editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 22 August--it is interested in some substance; we get little substance from the Opposition--stated:

. . . micro-reform must also be built from the bottom upwards. And the successful deployment of the nation's considerable assets depends on the ability of all the governments to build an effective system of co-operative federalism.
. . . . . . . . . . . . If handled well, the proposal marks an attempt to integrate federal, State and local government planning in a way that could pay big dividends to taxpayers everywhere.

I have quoted from the Australian Financial Review because, essentially, the better cities program is an attempt to achieve partnership between levels of government. It is a way of approaching structural problems in the Australian economy; achieving flexibility in the labour market; and achieving a recovery in the housing industry in order to provide the necessary land. It is an attempt to deal with the quality of life of people which is essential----
Dr Hewson interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—-The interventions of the Leader of the Opposition indicate that, whatever else we can say, he does not care about what happens in western Sydney. It does not matter whether the State Government cares about it; it does not matter whether local government is concerned about it; it does not matter whether informed commentators care about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sharp interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Gilmore!

—-We can be certain of one thing; it is not a matter of care for the Leader of the Opposition. It is not part of the Opposition's agenda. When we receive--as we do--a number of inquiries about this program, we will be able to make it very clear that people should keep calling us because if they call the Opposition they will get no understanding and no attempt to deal with these problems. They will certainly not get the development of programs in cooperation with the States and with local government. I think it is rather sad that one of the great cities of the world, Sydney, should not receive even scant attention from the Leader of the Opposition.
—-Let's wind it up.

—-The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says, `Let's wind it up'. I can have a frank, very useful and very sensible conversation with the New South Wales Leader of the Government, Premier and Leader of the Opposition about how we might have cooperation in relation to Sydney. All the Deputy Leader of the Opposition can do is talk about how he will balance the Budget and increase unemployment.

—-Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The point of order is under standing order 145. The question that was raised by the honourable member for Prospect related to the better cities program and the benefit that would be to the people in her area. If I understood correctly, yesterday, in answer to a question, we were told that the programs that would be introduced----
—-Order! The honourable member will get to his point of order.
—-I am getting to it.
—-Get straight to it.
—-There would be----
—-The honourable member for Isaacs will get to his point of order or resume his seat.
—-Come on!
—-Order! The member for the Northern Territory!
—-I am saying that the programs were going to be part of the State meetings in November.
—-Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Isaacs will resume his seat.
—-If they have not been decided upon, how can he raise these issues?
—-Order! The member will resume his seat.

—-I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the case of one of my constituents. Raymond, a former office manager, is 45 years of age. He lost his job 12 months ago, thanks to the `recession we had to have'. He has applied for many jobs but has been told by prospective employers that he is either too old or too highly qualified. Raymond wants to work and needs the income to support his family. How is the Government going to provide jobs for people such as Raymond when the Prime Minister is interested in only one job--his own?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Let me dispense with this question very quickly. First of all, if I am going to be in this business of gratuitously giving advice, I would start off again by saying that the honourable member for Bendigo should tell his constituent what I said to the honourable member opposite who asked the previous question. He should tell him, `Do not vote for the Opposition because we are going to increase the number of unemployed'. Secondly, he should say, `Don't vote for us, because, if we get in'--which the Opposition will not--`you won't want to stay unemployed, Raymond'. I think that is what you said his name was. The honourable member should say, `Enjoy the unemployment benefit while you can, Raymond, because, when we get in, after nine months we are going to take the unemployment benefit off you'. The honourable member should tell him that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition says Raymond wants a job. He should not go to the Opposition because its prescription is for an increase in unemployment. Its own model says so. The honourable member for Bendigo should say to Raymond, `Don't vote for me because I will increase the number of unemployed. Don't vote for me because I am going to throw you on the street after nine months'. That is what he should say to Raymond.

I would say to Raymond that this Government has put in place a massive increase in the number of programs for the training and retraining of people who are unemployed at this stage. The fact is that the policies in place--as I have said before--will mean that during this financial year there will be a 4 per cent increase in GDP and there will be a significant increase in employment. It is only adherence to those policies, laced with the compassion that we have, which keeps people on benefit and does not throw them onto the street. That is the only way that the constituent of the honourable member for Bendigo can have any hope in this country. He can vote for a government which has created 1.4 million jobs in this country and which will ensure the resumption of employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You've done this to one million people.
—-The honourable member for Bendigo!

—-In real terms this Government has increased the level of unemployment benefits. That is as distinct from what those opposite will do, which is to decrease them. Those are the options that the honourable member's constituent has.
—-You don't have the guts.
—-The honourable member for Ballarat!
—-Any sane and intelligent reading of the alternatives will mean that he will cast his vote----
—-Why don't you have the guts?
—-I warn the honourable member for Ballarat.

—-Any sane, intelligent reading of the alternatives will show that we will have either a government which will increase employment in this country and keep people who are not in jobs on unemployment benefits or a coalition government which will increase unemployment and throw people off the benefit after nine months. When people know the alternatives, we will do in 1993 what we did in 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990: we will wipe the pants off the Opposition.

—-Before I call the honourable member for Denison, I might remind members on both sides of the House that if they ask a question, rather than continuing to interject while a Minister answers the question, they ought to listen to the answer. If members continue to interject on the person of whom they have asked a question, I will name them.

—-I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of criticisms that have been directed towards the Budget deficit and arguments that it is too high and should be reduced? What would be the effect of cutting programs in his portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for his question as it gives me the opportunity to respond to one or two of the points that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition in his speech on the Budget. Apparently, this morning, on ABC radio or one of the other stations, the Leader of the Opposition was asked why he wimped the censure motion yesterday. He said, `Oh, you don't need to worry about those. Today in Question Time we are going to subject the Government to rigorous cross-examination'. We have seen the enormous cannonade which has rocketed across the front benches of the Government from the dazzling cross-examiners in the Opposition but we yet await an explanation as to why he wimped it yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Carlton interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—-I have got to say one thing about the reply to the Budget by the Leader of the Opposition. While he has yet to give us specifics on $3 billion worth of cuts that he says will accompany his introduction of the consumption tax, he did in fact get specific about what cuts there would be to achieve the balanced Budget that he wanted. The Minister for Finance drew that to our attention yesterday. The Leader of the Opposition was quite specific: all the additional expenditures that were associated with those offset, plus the taxation measures that were put in the Budget to reduce taxation to the average Australian and to deal with the problems of the wheat industry--he was quite specific--would be cut.

ANSWER.PARA: Incorporated in the cuts that he would be prepared to look at, and that I assume must have been accompanied by some serious policy examination, was all the expenditure which went into the Rail Freight Authority. One of the most significant initiatives in our area--one that has been crying out for attention for 70 or 80 years and that has finally got attention by this Government and no other--would be totally jettisoned by the Leader of the Opposition, irrespective of undertakings and statements made by his various spokesmen, including the Leader of the National Party, on their attitude to the Rail Freight Authority. The National Party has not been calling for it to be cut, as the Leader of the Opposition, in his Budget response, called for it to be cut. The National Party has said that it is a sensible initiative by the Government and ought to be supported. We assumed that when the Leader of the Opposition looked at his program of micro-economic reform he decided as part of it that he would jettison the Rail Freight Authority.

Incorporated also in this particular Budget is expenditure related to reforms on the waterfront. The Opposition is a great mob when it comes to dealing with micro-economic reform. As with the consumption tax, we never get specifics. The fact of the matter is that by the end of this month, under the reforms that we have put in place, some 2,000-plus people will have left the waterfront, on the basis of serious, detailed negotiations with the people concerned, and real gains in productivity will result. Both those essential micro-economic reforms required Budget outlays to deal with the problem.

The position that is evidently being offered by the Opposition is that it cares nothing about micro-economic reform when it finally comes down to deliberating on what conceivable impact it will have on budgetary arrangements. Of course, Opposition members care nothing about what other promises they might be making at the same time as they call for cuts. The Budget contains road funding. Again it is suggested that there should be a cut. Not one month before the Opposition made that response to the Budget, the Leader of the National Party made a few comments on expenditure. One of the joys of life in politics, or at least of being in government, is that one has access to a clipping service and becomes aware that there are two coalition presentations. There is the coalition presentation in the city and before the national media, and there is the coalition presentation in the country, on this particular occasion as covered in the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin. The article states:
Coalition: Extra $1b for roads.
A Coalition Federal government would increase funds to improve Queensland roads--
we find the article has a bit of specificity here; it is $1 billion for Queensland--
by up to an extra $1 billion, National Party Leader Mr Fischer said at the weekend.
He promised Belyando Shire Council during a visit to Clermont that the Coalition realised Queensland's neglected road system desperately needed a huge injection of funds.

So the Opposition will just rock in with $1 billion worth of Commonwealth funds to make absolutely certain that the old Belyando Shire is not left out the next time old Tim comes around for a two-minute visit. I could go through a plethora of examples where robust statements are made in this place about Budget cuts--and they have been particularly robust in debate on this Budget, including a promise, effectively, that if those opposite had been in office they would have increased taxation--while outside the statements are particularly robust about increases in expenditure.

The problem for this Opposition, and it will become an increasing subject of interest to the public as an election draws closer--in 18 months time, as opposed to the three months that those opposite seem to be telling their various candidates--is that Opposition members will be subject to cross-examination. We will wish to know what it is that they intend to do with the various promises that they make so promiscuously around the country on subjects such as road expenditure. We will want to know in detail what they intend to do about health policies. We will want to know in detail what they intend to do about education policies. We will want to know what they intend to do about consumption tax policies. They will be subject to cross-examination, and it will not be a continuation of their wimpish performance in this place. It will be a great deal more robust than that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct a question to the temporary Prime Minister. The Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters was recently told, under oath, that ex- Premier Burke contacted a member of the Federal Government in connection with the Holmes a Court bail-out. Can the Prime Minister assure the House that the former Treasurer was not involved in this bail out, and will the Prime Minister undertake to report to the House on his former Minister's prior knowledge, if any, of this bail-out?

—-My recollection is that the honourable member for Blaxland, when he was the Treasurer, answered this question and answered it very specifically. I have no reason to do anything other than accept fully what he had to say about this matter.
—-I direct a question to the Prime Minister, and ask him to advise the House what the effect would be on inflation of the introduction of a goods and services tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There is absolutely no doubt that the introduction of a consumption tax would see the smashing of the gains that we have made on inflation in this country. Rather than address this question hypothetically, let us look at an example of very considerable relevance and one that is very dear to the heart of the shadow Treasurer. Let us look at New Zealand. A consumption tax was introduced in New Zealand in 1986. As a result, inflation immediately shot up to 19 per cent. It has since fallen to 3 per cent. The shadow Treasurer gleefully latched on to that figure when speaking on the 7.30 Report on 17 July. Honourable members should remember the quotes of dear Peter. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: They--
that is New Zealand--
introduced a consumption tax and now they are the world champion in beating inflation.

That is fascinating. New Zealand is the world champion in beating inflation--that is the lesson from the shadow Treasurer. Mr Speaker, as you know very well, and as most other honourable members in this place know, that is only half the story. I will complete the story about New Zealand. Since the introduction of the consumption tax----
Mr Reith interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Come on! Be quiet, Peter. You have had your go. Since the introduction of the consumption tax in New Zealand, they have been in a five-year recession. Let us look at the facts. This is the achievement since the introduction of the consumption tax in New Zealand, the spiritual home now of the tories of Australia. It has been in recession for five years and now the GDP in New Zealand, five years later, is 4 per cent lower than it was five years ago with the introduction of the broad-based consumption tax. Against that 4 per cent reduction in GDP in New Zealand since the introduction of the broad-based consumption tax, the GDP in Australia has increased by 13 per cent. In other words, there is a 17 per cent differential between the experience of Australia and New Zealand following the introduction of the broad-based consumption tax there. On our GDP aggregates, that represents a difference of about $65 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: We should also look at this world champion performance, this model to which the Opposition turns, in regard to employment in that period. Here again are the facts: in New Zealand, employment has fallen by almost 6 per cent since the introduction of the consumption tax and, in the same period in Australia, employment has risen by 8.8 per cent. That is a 15 per cent differential in employment outcomes. In Australian terms, that represents a million jobs in this country. There we have it--a $65 billion difference in the GDP differential performance and one million jobs in terms of the employment differential. That is the size of the Opposition's credibility gap and that is the magnitude of its hypocrisy.
Mr Reith interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—-It is obviously one of the reasons why one Opposition backbencher had something to complain about yesterday. Opposition members had their meeting yesterday and the shadow Treasurer apparently attempted to explain to the Opposition parties what the details were of the broad-based consumption tax. It was reported in today's Sydney Morning Herald and that article concluded with this paragraph:

ANSWER.PARA: One MP complained that after Mr Reith's briefing, he was still as much in the dark about the policy as he was before the briefing took place.

All I can say is that it is about time that the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader not only inform their own Party about the details of the tax but, even more importantly, come clean and tell the Australian people.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.
