SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—-Yes.
—-The honourable member may proceed.

—-Yesterday, in another place, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) had a few things to say about the International Labour Organisation. He drew what I would charitably describe as a very long bow on the subject. He misrepresented a couple of things that I said. In order to correct that misrepresentation, may I simply record for the benefit of the House that upon reading the ILO's recommendation in relation to strike laws and common law remedies in section 45d, I made it perfectly clear on behalf of the Opposition that we totally rejected the ILO recommendations. We will go on opposing them as totally irrelevant and unsuitable for the Australian environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I made it quite clear that, on a change of government, the incoming coalition government would examine the links of this country with the International Labour Organisation. I do not resile from that. That does not automatically mean that we are going to leave the body; but, I repeat that we will examine our links with it. I say that without any hesitation.

The other point is that the Minister, in his more extravagant moments, attacked me for having disgraced my profession--that is, my other profession of the law--simply because I had dared to disagree with the findings of other lawyers.

Let me say to the Minister that it has never been a disgrace for one lawyer to disagree with the views of another lawyer. It is typical of his authoritarian attitude to industrial relations that he should have that authoritarian view.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Bennelong has gone far past making a personal explanation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's negative approach to development proposals, particularly in the resource sector, which has cost the nation dearly in prospective jobs and opportunities.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-This country is not only gripped by one of the worst recessions in its history, it is not only gripped by the social agony created by one million unemployed, it is also gripped by a negative paralysis which is now dominating the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)--this Government's attitude--in a way that is adding greatly to the burden of the situation. Today in Question Time we saw the Prime Minister stumble again and again over the question of the Medicare policy of this Government, the Medicare decision of the Budget and its reference to the Caucus committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I now reveal to the House that the Prime Minister has also been stumbling over certain other matters--a matter of his schedule in Melbourne a few weeks ago. The Prime Minister was invited to officially open one little chink of hope, one ray of light, for the hard-pressed people of Melbourne, particularly in the area of Box Hill, at the Bowater Ltd factory in the eastern suburbs of that hard- pressed city, which is, in many ways, the epicentre of the recession.

Our Prime Minister accepted that invitation. Considerable cost was incurred and considerable arrangements were made in preparation for that opening to take place on Wednesday, 14 August. What happened? Just a few days before that opening was to proceed, the Prime Minister's office contacted that company and said, `No, we are going to remove the Prime Minister from that function, we are going to remove that one chance to give a little brighter profile to the opening up of new jobs in that part of Melbourne. The Prime Minister is now no longer able to proceed with that opening'. That reply was given at very short notice.

The true reason for that action by that Prime Minister--the temporary Prime Minister--on that occasion has been revealed. Yesterday I received a copy of a letter from the Australian Timber and Allied Industries Union No. 7 Branch, Pulp and Paper Workers Branch, addressed to the Prime Minister and dated 29 July. It reads:
Dear Prime Minister,
I understand that you have accepted an invitation to officiate at a function at Bowater Limited, Box Hill, Victoria on Wednesday, 14th August, 1991.
It goes on to talk about the situation between the union and the company and then it adds:

Accordingly and regretfully I request you to decline the invitation as your attendance would be intolerable at a time when our members are fighting to secure the delivery of an Australian Government/A.C.T.U. Accord.

So the union vetoed the Prime Minister's proceeding with his schedule on that day to that factory to the opening of additional facilities of a job generating kind. The letter is signed Chris Northover, secretary of the ATAIU.

I put it to the House, to the nation, that we have a Prime Minister paralysed by the union movement, paralysed by his own inertia, and paralysed by the negative attitude which is dominating as we go through this recession we did not have to have. I put it to the House that it has reached a stage where there can be only one solution--the early election, the change of government, and the economic reform agenda which will give some hope to the one million unemployed who exist in Australia today.

We have reached a stage where we have a stand-still mentality, a status quo approach, a Government running scared of almost each and every serious decision it should be making on industrial relations. Where is the real progress? Where is the genuine enterprise bargaining? Where is the genuine protection of the right of a person to belong to a union and the right of a person not to belong to a union? There is none.

In relation to taxation policy, it was very interesting to hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) wade into this area and get it all wrong. In any event, why did we not hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy tell the House that the National Farmers Federation supports tax reform and the GST; that the Chamber of Manufactures in New South Wales supports GST; that the New South Wales farmers in a very aggressive newsletter and column in the Sun-Herald last Sunday strongly supports GST?

The Minister did not even have the courage to admit at the Rice Growers Association conference, which he addressed in Deniliquin--which I also addressed--that the rice growers supported GST. One might well ask: what happened at the Cattlemen Union's conference? No less a dignitary than the Prime Minister--he got that schedule right; he actually made it up to Mount Isa for a few brief hours and then dashed back to that famous dinner and tete-a-tete with Senator Richardson in the Lodge on Monday night of last week, thereby denying the people of Mount Isa the benefit of a lengthy stay--addressed the Cattlemen's Union conference, and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) then addressed the conference. Guess what the Cattlemen's Union then determined and put out in accordance with its previous policy? Support for tax reform! Support for the GST! Support for the abolition of sales tax!

Let us have less nonsense from the Government with regard to tax reform. Let us have more accurate, constructive debate, and let us get on with the job. This Government is paralysed in its whole approach to a range of key projects. My colleague the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) will in support deal with some of those projects, including the very fast train--but, similarly, I want to put before the House some very key examples.

It was back in March 1989 that the Federal Cabinet approved the third runway at Mascot. Even under the mathematical ability of the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), that is now two years and five months ago. It is a delay which is unacceptable. I asked the House last March, in liaison with the shadow Minister for aviation, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), given the fact that it took six years to build the Louvre, six years to build the whole of the J.F.Kennedy Airport complex at New York, and nine years to build the Sydney Harbour Bridge, how long is it going to take to build the third runway at Mascot? The reality is that in the two years and five months since Federal Cabinet approved that key development project, the Kuwait international airport has been closed, has been partially destroyed, and has been rebuilt and reopened with additional runway capacity.

What hope is there for Australia when we have a delay to the key project, the third runway at Mascot? The sharp edge of this delay is now apparent to all honourable members with the announcement by Hazelton Airlines on Monday that it has no choice but to wreck in part the economy of so many towns in New South Wales by revoking air services to Forbes, Cowra, Young, Cootamundra, Walgett, Coonamble, Brewarrina, Bourke, Nyngan, Lightning Ridge, Gunnedah, Quirindi, Coonabarabran and Temora from next Friday. The reasons given were the recession, the delays at Mascot and the peak period charging system.

What price is the inland economy of New South Wales paying for the delay of the third runway at Kingsford-Smith airport? It is not a cost only for New South Wales, it is a cost for the aviation industry generally, a cost for the tourism industry generally and a cost in terms of inefficiency for Australians at large.

I will now refer to flights between South Africa and Australia. Honourable members might recall that the Government is ham-fisted about that matter in that when other airlines have been cheerfully flying directly from Europe to South Africa we still have a situation in which there are no direct flights between Australia and South Africa. We still have lingering trade sanctions.

I will reveal to the House yet another example of the paralysis, the negative attitude and the incredible mentality which exists in this country. When a company arranged under the interpretation of the trade sanctions policy to continue with its imports of winching cable it also arranged to import $500,000 of special drilling rods. What happened? A Customs officer arrived and gave a slightly different interpretation of the sanctions exemptions in existence at present. As a consequence, there was no facility given for those rods to be on- sold or put into bond storage until the trade sanction policy was lifted. Guess what happened? Each and every one of those drilling rods, by direction of Customs, had to be destroyed on location on the wharf. What progress can Australia expect when we have a government and a trade sanctions policy which has led to that circumstance with regard to that particular mining company?

Coronation Hill has been dealt with on a number of occasions. I simply add, by way of comparison with Coronation Hill, which I have recently revisited, that BHP's Escondida project in Chile has come on-stream. The project was commissioned seven months ahead of schedule and was $161m under budget.

The Porgera gold project in Papua New Guinea poured its first gold 14 months after construction commenced and only 26 months after approval was first sought. In other words, a gold mine in Papua New Guinea has gone from nowhere to operation and this Government is still considering the third runway project at Mascot. What hope is there for Australia with that negative attitude, that paralysis and that delay adding to the burden of the situation we face in this country?

Some $9 billion worth of projects are in limbo and have been delayed. Those projects have been drawn up not by me but my Access Economics. It is a well known list. I am sure that the Minister has seen the list. The Minister should be ashamed of the list which has come about not altogether entirely due to his inactivity--I concede that much--but certainly due to the amount of red tape, green tape, black tape and every other form of layering on the processing of these decisions in a way which has led to the collapse of investment confidence in this country with the mining sector, the agricultural sector and even the manufacturing sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not what Access Economics says.

—-It is a situation which has now got out of hand. Whilst there is an exception or two which the Minister might highlight, and whilst Woodside particularly is commencing and proceeding with investments particular to its circumstance, including the Goodwin platform, when we look at the list of projects in limbo as we speak here today--Coronation Hill, Yackabindie, Denison, Koongarra, Kintyre and so on--we see the extent of delay, decay, inactivity and lack of ability for this Government to stay the course when the tough decisions are out. That is the ultimate sin of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when we need positive decisions, at a time when we need positive development and at a counter-cyclical time in terms of economic international trends and building up our job base, we have a Government that can only talk of delays, referrals and a range of excuses for inactivity. When it eventually comes to the Cabinet table for that decisive decision we have the incredible circumstance where the Prime Minister, who did not even have a majority on the day at the Cabinet table, still extracted that no decision, that veto decision, on Coronation Hill to the absolute anger of the Minister for Resources, who is at the table. I know that this Minister is a little more in touch than some of his colleagues, although not many. That is why he went into that Cabinet room arguing for Coronation Hill. The Minister should tell me if I am wrong. The Minister did that. He went into Cabinet and argued for Coronation Hill and he got done. Worse still, the jobs which were available to so many Australians--the export income of half a billion dollars which this project would have generated over a short period of years--were lost for the time being to the ranks of the unemployed of Australia until a change of government.

I put it to the House that we have a Government entirely run by the ACTU, with a union veto circumstance which has paralysed policy decision making in a range of areas, including resources and uranium. The ACTU has an incredible policy on uranium, which the honourable member for Aston will refer to in more detail. We stand for decisive decision making, staying the course on the tough decisions, offering a true economic reform agenda and in doing that not only giving the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) the keys to the Lodge but giving workers the keys to jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), as the shadow Minister for energy and resources--this is entirely consistent with the Opposition's policies on resource matters--took 10 minutes on this alleged matter of public importance to begin to canvass the issues that relate to the resources sector. He spent five minutes speaking on resource matters. That speaks much more eloquently for the lack of insight and the lack of interest in this important sector than anything I can say.

SPEECH.PARA: Issues such as Medicare and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) not attending a factory opening might be seen by some as matters appropriate to a matter of public importance on resources. I suspect that there are very few in the resources sector who would embrace the same view. I travel around the country and I ask rhetorically a wide range of audiences who the relevant shadow Minister responsible for resources issues is. I concede that it is not always, but usually, met with deafening silence. The Leader of the National Party knows this because this issue was raised by the Chamber of Mines in Queensland where a spokesperson for that organisation canvassed these issues.

Let us move on, hopefully, to something more substantive. Whilst I do so, I offer members of the Opposition the opportunity to answer this simple proposition: in nearly three decades of tory Government can any member of the Opposition name one significant micro-economic reform during that period? I can certainly name one or two, but I would like the opportunity extended to all on the Opposition side to test their memory and the history of their own period in government. At the end of this debate perhaps the other contributors from that side can provide a comprehensive list after they have all got together.

Let me make a few brief points about the resources sector. The first thing to understand about it is that we need to have the macro- economic environment settings correct. We cannot simply go in and embrace a policy on the run or some rhetoric as a substitute for an appropriate resources sector framework. People might disagree with some of the policy outcomes, but no-one can sustain an argument that since the Government took office in 1983 there has been insignificant reform. Key policy decisions in terms of the economic framework include the deregulation of the financial market, the floating of the dollar, substantial reductions in government outlays, corporate and personal tax reform, a stable wages environment and substantially reduced protection.

Some of the features of the Government's achievements include: a disciplined approach to fiscal and monetary policy, which has been successful in reducing inflation from the double digit levels of the early 1980s, a time when honourable members opposite were in government, to the present underlying rate of just over 3 per cent; broad reform of the taxation system, including lower personal and corporate rates, making Australia now the fourth lowest taxed country in the OECD; the introduction of dividend imputation to eliminate double taxation of dividends and to add to Australia's savings base; and so on and so on.

It is interesting that there was so little debate on the March statement. It is worth canvassing for a moment the importance of that statement. As people will recall, the Prime Minister, in his March statement Building a Competitive Australia, announced significant ongoing lower tariff reductions across the board, reduced wholesale taxes for business, granted duty exemptions for minerals processing equipment, increased support for workplace reform and created a more favourable depreciation regime. All of these things mean lower input costs and greater competitiveness for industry, and particularly resource based industry.

The Government's decision to reduce general tariff levels by 5 per cent by 1996 is in this context worthy of specific mention. The dimension of those changes ought not to be underestimated. Professor Ross Garnaut, who is widely accepted in this Parliament and elsewhere as a good authority in these matters, said:
We would lack all sense of history, all sense of the tides of national life in Australia, if we let last week's announcement--
that is, the March economic statement--
pass without savouring for a moment its place in bigger schemes.
They are big changes. Bigger than the end of the British corn laws that earned Peel and Cobden a dozen pages in our high school history books, eight or ten time zones and over a century away. . .

Why is this? Just for the resource sector alone, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, again quintessentially an independent umpire and independent arbiter of these issues, indicated that the March economic statement alone would drive an increase in production volumes in the resources sector of 5 per cent, which translates into around $1 billion per annum in 1988 prices.

I think I can safely assert that in the history of the Federation there has never been in this chamber a policy statement that offered up the prospects for such significant reform to Australia's important resources sector. That is why the independent arbiters, rather than the partisan commentators from the other side of this House, described the statement in such strong terms.

In respect of the areas for which I am responsible--forestry, petroleum and mining--I make the following points. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) indicated that he had recourse to the Access Economics report and he indicated that the investment environment was never so bad. The author of the very report from which he quoted begins an article in The Economist in December 1990 in the following terms:
Investment interest in energy and metals processing is still healthy.

That is quite the opposite to the misleading observation of the Leader of the National Party. I now turn to the specifics, and let me refer to one area of the resources sector that is of incredible importance to this country, namely, the petroleum sector. It is a major player in the resources sector. It contributes over one per cent of our GDP. About 10,000 people are employed in that sector. It exports about $2.4 billion worth of product and that will increase dramatically in the years to come. It provides import replacement of about $8 billion. It is by any definition a most significant part of the resources sector.

As to Government initiatives, let me give the House a thumbnail sketch, a brief overview, rather than going through all the details. First, the Government deregulated the crude oil market and removed restrictions on crude oil on 1 January 1988. Anyone in the industry would regard that as a most significant reform. I released the offshore exploration strategy in June 1990. It has been met not only by our domestic players but by international players as well with very strong interest indeed.

The package of reforms to secondary taxation applying to petroleum production, announced in the August 1990 Budget, including company-wide deductibility, was described in part by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association in the following terms, and I must paraphrase them. When we look back from the next century at Australia's oil and gas exploration and production industry, August 1990 will be seen to be `the decisive moment'. Never has an organisation like the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association so solidly endorsed a Federal Government decision in those terms. Again, I would rather rely on them than on the partisan rhetoric of honourable members opposite.

As to the introduction of income tax deductibility for petroleum platform removal expenditures, some would think that that is not so big in the scheme of things, until one reflects on the cost of removal of those platforms. That was a very significant decision and it also of course has significant environmental implications. There was the deregulation of the liquefied petroleum gas market and LPG exports, a condition precedent to the proper development of this important industry.

In terms of achievements, there was a record number of exploration wells drilled in 1990, a record seismic survey, exploration expenditure of more than $400m, and recently BHPP, one of Australia's premier players in this area, has indicated that it is shifting money that was directed towards overseas exploration and production back into domestic exploration and production. Again, contrary to the partisan rhetoric of honourable members opposite, I think that is a fair indication, at least in this sector, of company sentiment.

What do others say about these policies? The reforms to the resource rent tax and the extension to Bass Strait have been praised in a recent article by the Business Review Weekly, which indicated that Esso and BHPP would now renew the development phase in Bass Strait, our premier oil and gas area, and that it would spark `a new boom in oil exploration'. BHPP's management is quoted as endorsing the reforms, saying that the changes to RRT make it possible to finish the work in Bass Strait and `begin the task of exploring the other more prospective basins in the southern oceans'. I am happy that those reforms have been so well received. So, that is the domestic response.

Internationally, the 1991 international new ventures survey of 66 international oil companies, conducted by the Robertson Research Group, ranked Australia as the fourth most favoured host country and fourth in terms of exploration expenditure--a jump from twentieth the previous year. It is an extraordinary result for this country. Honourable members may have read just a couple of days ago an article in the Australian newspaper by Mr Gomez, a respected resources writer, quoting a paper by Dr Fesharaki, the Director of Resources Programs at the prestigious East West Centre in Honolulu. Dr Fesharaki's views underscore earlier international surveys, as I have indicated. His proposition was that the resource rent tax proposals were of such significance that they have led a turnaround for the Australian oil industry. He said:
The Australian Government must be applauded for the implementation of this brave policy, which has proved to be very successful in revitalising the Australian oil industry.

Esso Australia recently indicated in the context of resource rent tax changes that it was going to spend some $650m further in Bass Strait. In terms of the forestry sector, again there has been a lot of rhetoric from the Opposition but very little indeed of any substance. Indeed, the premier organisation representing the timber and paper sector in this country, the National Association of Forest Industries, has criticised the Opposition's poor performance in the resource security debate, indicating that, as usual, those opposite are not prepared to put their own cards on the table. They have not done so yet. The debate is just about concluded and there is no policy. As a Minister I can tell them that it is a matter of enormous frustration for me that they will not put any material on the table so as to enable us at least to attack a sitting target.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Why should we create a sitting target for you?

—-As I travel around the country I find that people do not know who the Opposition spokespersons are for the relevant policy jurisdictions. Those opposite may laugh about that, but it is a fact of life and they know it is.

SPEECH.PARA: My time is coming to a conclusion. I have invited those opposite to reflect on their nearly three decades of government and, during this debate, to indicate to the Parliament, and through the Parliament to the people of Australia, what major micro-economic reforms they put in place in those nearly three decades. I have given them a thumbnail sketch of significant micro-economic reforms in my policy jurisdiction. That can be replicated and expanded upon by my colleagues. But I ask those opposite please to answer the question and to name one significant micro-economic reform in the nearly three decades when they were in government.
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My colleague the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has raised perhaps the key issues of today; that is, jobs and the economic mismanagement of this country. In his response the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) has given us an exercise in contortion and evasion of those key issues. Frankly, if that contortion had had to be physical rather than verbal, I think he would have been in a very painful posture indeed. He complained that my colleague the Leader of the National Party did not spend enough time talking about resources. But, of course, if the Minister had read the wording of the matter of public importance, he would know that we are talking about the impact on jobs and the financial state of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister complained about not knowing who the Opposition spokespersons are and got into the personality game again. Of course, all we ever hear from this Government relates to personalities rather than getting down to the issues. He complained about our history in government and asked what we did years ago. Of course, this is a standard technique of every Minister in this Government; they talk about history rather than facing up to the issues and talking about the lack of jobs and the debt that they have brought upon this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Name one micro-economic reform.
—-The Minister complained that we made no reference to the March statement.
—-Name one.
—-I will come to the March statement; make no bones about that.
—-One.

—-The Minister quoted selectively from a whole host of documents, trying to tell us how well we are doing as a nation. But let us look at the bottom line. All Australians know that there is something seriously wrong with the economic performance of this country. They know about the unemployment and they know about the hidden unemployment. They know about the lack of confidence. If they come from Victoria, as I do, they know about the complicity between the Kirner Government and the Hawke Government in making that even worse. They know about the lack of investment in business and industry and in resource projects. They know about the record bankruptcies. They know about the debilitating impact on the youth of this country and they know about the growth in debt, both personal and national, in this country during the life of this Government. They know recently about the failure of the Budget, which is already unravelling before our eyes. In my electorate we see it in local terms and in human terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) likes to stand up here and tell us how he relates to people. He tells us how he goes out and talks to people. Let us see him stop going to safe Australian Labor Party seats. I invite him--I ask the Minister to pass this on to him--to come down to my electorate and talk to some of the people who represent the 272 per cent increase in unemployment in my electorate in the last 12 months. I say to him, `Come and talk to some of the small businesses who represent the more than 70 per cent increase in bankruptcies in my electorate. Come and talk to some of the families and see the stress that they are under. Come and talk to some of the families who have come to me from neighbouring Labor electorates because they get no support or sympathy if they go to their own members. Come and talk to the families who come to me'. For example, a woman came to me and said, `My son is unemployed and the family is so hard up that he has had to resort to stealing within the family. With the distress and the trouble that that caused, we finally had to kick him out'. That is a human tragedy caused by this Government with its nearly one million unemployed.

I say to the Prime Minister, `Come and talk to the elderly who come into my office. They do not just ask for the Age Pension Guide that I produce as a service to my constituents, as do many of my colleagues. They do not come in for the Deeming Guide. They come in for the Unemployment Guide--not for themselves but for their children. Come and look at the `for sale' signs, the `for rent' signs and the `for lease' signs all around my electorate and the rest of the country. And do not tell me that interest rates have come down and how good a job you have done. They are still far higher than those of any of our competitors.'

Many of the 6,000 small businesses in my electorate feed off larger projects--except, of course, that there are none. We have a critical need for industrial relations reform to sweep away those archaic work practices. We need tax reform. Before those opposite ask for the details, I can tell them that they will get them; that is for certain. We need structural reform on the waterfront and in land transport. But all of those will give us benefits in time.

The big opportunity for a faster payback comes in the resources sector where we can start to break the debt cycle much more quickly. As MPs we have the privilege of travelling around this country and we have seen a lot of those projects and opportunities--from Gove to Weipa to Port Hedland and all around the country--that are stalled at this moment. The Government is not helping business to develop those projects. It is building barriers. I will borrow a phrase from my colleague the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney): paralysis by analysis. There is no consistency of project evaluation criteria.

In the 12 March statement the Prime Minister promised resource security legislation. Where is it? Has anyone seen it? Has the Minister seen it? Of course no-one has. The schedule tells us that it might come in November. Six months after the Prime Minister's statement, we have not seen it at all--as usual, no action.

Let us look at some examples of the problems of this country in terms of stalled developments. I will not go into Coronation Hill; my colleague the Leader of the National Party has already mentioned that. Let us talk about BHP Minerals. It has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in overseas projects in the last couple of years. This should send a message to the Government. Why has it gone overseas? Why has it not invested here? Obviously, we have cost problems and other problems here. But, if one talks to the managers of these companies, the main reason that they invest overseas becomes quite clear: it is the paralysis of the decision making process in this country.

Let us look at CRA Ltd. It has developments stalled everywhere. It went into Indonesia and got a coalmining project up in very quick time, which is now competing with our own Australian black coal industry. We cannot afford to lose those sorts of investments, particularly not to lose them to countries that will then compete directly with us.

Of course, the national joke, if it were not so sad and so serious, would be uranium. We do not get our fair share of that market. Of course, the rest of the world gets it. We have this Government's absurd three-mines policy, which has had the effect of transferring uranium production from Australia to Canada.

Let us talk about the VFT. I am not going to talk about the route or the tax treatment; let us just look at it as an exercise in trying to get major projects off the ground. We had a consortium that spent tens of millions of dollars on a feasibility project for a major development that would provide ongoing jobs in construction and a ripple effect into other areas. That consortium had to deal with multiple levels of government--four separate governments. It had finance and tax issues, the environmental impact process, zoning and land acquisition and the regulatory framework. I might add that it is harder to get a project off the ground here in this country, with our States, than it is to get one off the ground in Europe with all its different nations. In the end, of course, it all became too hard, especially in the current economic climate, and the consortium had to walk away from it--another lost opportunity for Australia.

Of course, this affects jobs in the metropolitan areas, where the vast bulk of our people live. We only have to go out to a lot of those remote areas and see the difficulties in which those people operate to understand that the engineering, technical and support needs are very considerable. Much of that support comes from the cities. My electorate is no different from many others. Many of the 6,000 companies in my electorate need those major development projects so they can sell the engineering parts, the oils and the lubricants, the foodstuffs, the computing support, the transport and so on. The knock-on effect in terms of wealth and jobs is significant indeed.

Of course, there are those who query the sustainability of resource development. `What about the environment?', they ask. So let us deal with that. We say unequivocally that we must have high environmental standards. We must spend money on the restoration of soils and mine sites, providing clean water and maintaining our parks. We must preserve our unique flora and fauna. We must establish targets in key areas, like soil conservation and biodiversity. In particular, we must aim to be the most reliable, cost efficient and technologically superior provider of natural resources possible. We need fast-track procedures so that major developments can go ahead. We need to establish requirements that cannot then be changed. We must encourage investment in Australia. We must create the economically sustainable jobs and the growth so necessary to restore our country.

However, above all, we must, by adopting a positive approach to development, give some hope and vision for Australia's citizens. We need to return prosperity to young and old; and we need to provide the jobs so necessary to relieve the daily distress now being inflicted on Australians to such an extent that it is destroying the very fabric of our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Opposition members had 25 minutes today in which to deal with the MPI and they failed the test and the challenge that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) put to them; that is, to name one micro-economic reform initiative in three decades of tory government. None of those on the other side of the House were able to come up with even one initiative that the tories instituted throughout 30 years of their government. I am not surprised because I am not aware of any initiative that the conservatives ever brought in.

SPEECH.PARA: The tories gave us the tariff monkey on the back of farmers and manufacturers. They gave us an over-regulated dollar. They gave us a strategy that was more applicable to the nineteenth century. But what initiative did they give us? Members opposite had 25 minutes to answer their own case, the case that they brought on with this MPI--and they failed.

The fundamental difference and the problem the Opposition has is understanding what development and resources are all about. It is not knocking down a building in the middle of the night, like the Nationals used to do in Queensland. It is not bulldozing down every sand-dune. It is actually getting the process right. We need transport and communications. We need harbour facilities. We need a low dollar, something which we instituted in the mid-1980s and which is now trading at some 20 per cent lower than it ever traded under the conservatives, so making our exports more competitive. We need micro-economic reform. We need to restructure the waterfront. All these issues we are addressing, and the reason it takes time is that it is not easy. If it were easy, someone would have waved a wand 50 years ago. But it took a Labor government in 1983 even to recognise that the problem existed and needed to be addressed.

Of course, we have heard the two speakers on the other side say `You need to fast track'. Let us look at what happened under a conservative government when it fast tracked. Three or four shady little characters in pin-striped suits would go to the Premier's Department in Queensland with a brown paper bag full of dough and they would get a fast track. But that is not what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Like Western Australia, Brian?

—-I am sure that the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) can tell us about Western Australia. It is all about a proper, sensible process. We need to work with all sections of the community--environmentalists, manufacturers, miners and the timber industry--to get that process in place.
—-Tell us how you love environmentalists.

—-There are two important initiatives I would like to comment on which were touched on briefly by the Minister. One concerns an announcement by Associated Pulp and Paper Mills. The APPM went on to say, and I think honourable members on the other side would be interested to hear this:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the progress that has been made, we believe that we have now reached a stage where we can seek out partners to be involved in the project.

In other words, the APPM has confidence in the Government and it has confidence about getting on with the job. Resource security has now been endorsed by all State governments, and the Federal Government will be implementing that legislation in this coming session. We have worked through a very hard and emotional process because there are people who are concerned about the environment, and they have a right to take part in the debate. But now we have a process that is in place that is going to work. But we are not going to have this fast track process where we have a brown paper bag and a few pin-striped mates in white shoes from the Gold Coast who will determine the way in which the resources of this country will be developed.

Another important factor in development and resources is the taxation system. It is interesting to note that the lowest level of tax is now 21 per cent, whereas it was 30 per cent under the conservatives. The top rate is now down to 47 per cent. Company tax is down to 39 per cent whereas, effectively, it was over 78 per cent prior to 1983. The Government has taken the tax monkey off the back of business, off the back of workers, so that they can become more competitive.

What does the Opposition have to say about tax? We have heard the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), and goodness knows why he wants to talk about a goods and services tax. He has about as much chance of selling that in the bush as he has of selling leprosy. But he is proposing to put a tax of 15 per cent on the retail price of all inputs right across the board, including services. That will devastate the resource sector.

I get out in the bush and talk too, as the Leader of the National Party says he does. I can tell honourable members that there is no way any primary producer wants a tax of 15 per cent on the fruit and vegetables he sells, on the beef he sells or on anything else he sells in this country because, effectively, it means 15 per cent comes out of the market. That is what it means.

Let us look at tariffs. The Government across the board has brought down tariffs. Who does that benefit? It benefits the mining industry; it benefits manufacturers. So, right across a broad range of initiatives we are putting the mechanisms in place so that we can be more productive and efficient. When it comes to manning levels and when it comes to the waterfront, instead of taking a backward step we are the ones who have taken the forward step. We have nothing to be ashamed of when it comes to the waterfront because we are addressing it. If we look at manning levels today, we can see that by 1992 we will be down to the level of the OECD.

Of course, one of the difficulties with manning levels relates to the technology of the boats. Some old boats pre-Crawford, 1978, are not able, because of their technology, to bring down manning levels dramatically. They would simply run ashore or run into rocks. So it is all relevant to technology as well as restructuring. Of course, if we look at the tugs, we will have reduced by 1992 some 300 positions and have achieved a reduction of 25 per cent for tug crewing in harbours. Again, that has been a massive cost for the export sector.

Another interesting point is foreign investment. As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) mentioned at Question Time, the National Party has two policies: one down here when its members try to sound like statesmen, and one back home in the bush where the voodoo economics and the League of Rights come out--the Ku Klux Klan without bed sheets, the blokes who run the preselection process for the Nationals. They are against foreign investment because it suits them back home. They attack anyone

who wants to invest in this country to give us a bit more capital. But down here, they try to sound like statesmen, saying we need foreign investment. This Government has set in process a Foreign Investment Review Board to manage and monitor the way in which foreign capital comes into this country. It is a sensible approach, and it is a part of the whole development of a resource sector.

I am basically saying that it is that process, a broad ranging and complex process, that helps to develop projects in this country, not something that is done with a knee-jerk reaction simply by saying, `There is a tree, cut it down; there is an animal, shoot it'. That is the redneck, hillbilly attitude of the National Party. It is something that does not work; it has not worked in the past and it will not work now.

The important thing is that we are now in a global economy and it has been this Government that has brought us into a global economy. If we are going to be competitive and develop our resources, we can only do so in competition with other nations. It is disappointing that every time we try to restructure to be efficient and to be effective it is the conservatives--particularly the National Party--that oppose it, particularly with tariffs.

The National Party opposed sugar tariff cuts. There are dozens of press releases. They say things such as `Tariff cutback hurts growers' and `Nationals split on backing tariff cut'. It is the best thing that ever happened to the sugar industry because it has given us a bit more effectiveness and competition. But it has also given us an edge in the GATT to get the tariffs and subsidies down overseas, because 80 per cent of our product is sold overseas. Of course, that is something that the Nationals have failed to understand or recognise.

Another important initiative of this Government, through the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths)--and I applaud him--has been to continue the exemption from excise on petrol produced from approved shale oil demonstration plants. This has given an opportunity for the great shale oil project just north of Gladstone to go ahead. This initiative affects my electorate. If it goes ahead, it means thousands of jobs for central Queensland and for my electorate. I certainly do not need any yuppie on the other side of the House to tell me about the hopes and aspirations of the working men and women of this country or what opportunities are in place regarding the resources sector.

It was the Minister for Resources who led the charge in this regard, and even in tough economic times he was able to convince Cabinet to make this concession, to give a shot in the arm to the resource sector. The confidence that has flowed through as a consequence of that has been fantastic--not just here but overseas in the international community. It is unfortunate that not enough people on the other side actually read what other people and other nations say about us. A lot of positive things are happening and it is a pity that it is the `poor, pitiful me' propositions that are put up by those in the National Party because they have nothing else to put up. It is no wonder that they are negative. People who read the papers will know that their biggest branch is in Boggo Road; it is growing every day.

The National Party is opposing daylight saving, something that will help the tourist industry, something that will help the commercial sector, so we in Queensland will not be one hour behind when making a phone call to Melbourne.
