PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bill was returned from the Senate without amendment:
Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1991
Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to make three minor changes to the Student Assistance Act 1973. The Act gives the legislative basis for the Austudy scheme and provides a debt management regime for the other student assistance schemes.
Appropriations clause

Student assistance schemes are demand driven, with the overall expenditure depending on the number of full time students applying for assistance. It is therefore more appropriate to provide a special appropriations clause in the Student Assistance Act than to deal with the schemes through the normal appropriation legislation.

Accordingly, the Bill proposes to insert a section into the Student Assistance Act to appropriate the funds needed to pay allowances under the Austudy, Abstudy and assistance for isolated children schemes.
Cocos (Keeling) Islands

The Bill will also extend the application of the Austudy scheme to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. This reflects the move to normalise the application of Australian laws to the territory, including the phasing in of normal income tax arrangements.
Living allowances for English as a second language scheme

A third measure in the Bill concerns the living allowances for English as a second language scheme. This is a small scheme which provides living allowances to migrants undertaking Commonwealth funded courses in English as a second language at TAFE colleges. About 1,400 students were assisted in 1990 at a cost of approximately $3.7m.
From 1 July 1991, the scheme has been integrated into the social security payment system, though the scheme is included as a separate budgetary item in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92.
In view of the new arrangements, it is no longer appropriate for the debt management regime for the scheme to be provided for under the Student Assistance Act and the Act will be amended accordingly.
Financial impact

The Bill will have no significant financial impact on overall expenditure. The extension of Austudy to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is expected to cost about $20,000 a year. The other provisions are cost neutral and involve improved arrangements for paying the same amount of assistance to students.
Conclusion
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill, which gives additional details on the proposed changes. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (QUOTA INCREASE AND AGREEMENT AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The need for the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase and Agreement Amendments) Bill arises from Australia's participation in a consensus of members of the International Monetary Fund for a general increase in quotas and a strengthening of measures available against members which are in arrears to the IMF.

The first purpose of the Bill is to enable Australia to increase its quota in the IMF. The second and minor purpose is to amend schedule 1 of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947, the principal Act, when an amendment of the IMF's articles of agreement comes into effect, since that schedule reproduces the IMF's articles.

A country's quota in the IMF represents its financial subscription and determines its rights to draw other currencies in times of need, its voting power as a member, and its share in any allocations of special drawing rights (SDRs) which may be made by the IMF.

From time to time the members of the IMF together review the size of quotas, in aggregate and for members individually. They do so in the light of developments in the world economy and the international monetary system, changes in the relative economic position of members and, related to these factors, expected demands on the IMF's resources. Last year, in what was called the ninth general review of quotas, the IMF's board of governors approved a resolution proposing a set of increases in quotas which would raise their aggregate level by 50 per cent to the equivalent of $A230 billion. The increases proposed for individual members vary around the average increase of 50 per cent, the variation being essentially the result of an updated economic ranking of IMF members. The increase proposed for Australia is some 44 per cent.

The set of quota increases will come into effect before 31 December 1991 if members accounting for at least 85 per cent of existing quotas consent to their proposed increases before that date. They must also accept the set of amendments to the Fund's articles of agreement, called the third amendment, since that has been made a condition of the quota increase. The nearness of these changes makes it appropriate for the House to consider this Bill early in the current sitting.

Quotas in the IMF are expressed in numbers of special drawing rights or SDRs, since the SDR is the IMF's unit of account. The proposed increase in Australia's quota is from SDR 1,619.2 million, around $2,800 million, to SDR 2,333.2 million, $4,000 million. The Bill authorises both the giving of Australia's consent to the increase and the appropriation needed to pay for it. However, I would point out to honourable members that payment of Australia's quota increase would have no budgetary implications as it is a financing or `below-the-line' transaction.

The method of payment is provided for in the IMF articles of agreement and the ninth quota review resolution approved by the board of governors. Seventy-five per cent of the additional quota subscription will be paid in Australian dollars and the remainder in SDRs and foreign currency.

Clause 6 of the Bill allows the Australian dollar component of the increase in Australia's quota to be paid in the form of a non-negotiable and non-interest bearing security. The foreign currency and SDRs required to pay the balance of the increase will be purchased from the Reserve Bank. Clause 7 of the Bill authorises an appropriation for the purpose of acquiring that foreign currency, while the SDRs will be purchased under the standing appropriation of subsection 5a(6) of the principal Act.

This purchase of foreign currency and SDRs from the Reserve Bank will be a financing transaction, with no effect on Budget outlays or the Budget outcome. The issue of the non-negotiable, non-interest bearing security will have no effect on the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Such a security is a promise to pay the IMF in Australian dollars in the event that the IMF should need more of our currency than it presently holds. In that event, which past experience indicates is unlikely, there would be a call on the Consolidated Revenue Fund, but again no effect on Budget outlays or the Budget outcome.

In consenting to Australia's quota increase now, we shall help to augment the IMF's financial resources. These resources have been placed under considerable pressure by the drawings made by member countries since the last general review of quotas some seven years ago. The increase in quotas will enlarge the amounts of currency which the IMF is able to call upon from members in relatively strong external positions.

That will enable the IMF to continue to provide temporary balance of payments assistance to members in weak external positions, and thereby to promote a stable international monetary system. This stability is undoubtedly in Australia's interests. By supporting the quota increase, we shall also increase Australia's drawing rights as well as protecting our voting power and our entitlement to any future allocation of SDRs.

I move now to a brief explanation of the second purpose of this Bill; that of amending schedule 1 of the principal Act to reflect a probable change in the IMF's articles of agreement. In so doing, I refer the House's attention to part 3 of the Bill. The members of the IMF, through the board of governors, have agreed upon a set of amendments to the IMF's articles of agreement, known as the third amendment. The amendments are designed to strengthen the IMF's capacity for dealing with persistently uncooperative members in arrears to it. The costs of arrears are carried jointly by the IMF's debtors and creditors through adjustments to the rates at which the IMF charges and remunerates them respectively. Australia has shared in these costs. At the time of the IMF's most recent review of its arrears on 30 April 1991, nine members had accumulated the equivalent of more that US$5.7 billion in overdue obligations.

The strengthening of the IMF's capacity represented by these amendments is intended to discourage members from falling into arrears, and to encourage those already in arrears to cooperate with the IMF in clearing their arrears. Under this set of amendments to the IMF's articles:
. the suspension of voting and associated rights of members in arrears would be a compulsory step interposed between a declaration of ineligibility and compulsory withdrawal;
. a 70 per cent majority of the executive board would be required to impose or terminate such a suspension;
. a suspended member would lose the right to vote in any organ of the Fund, on most amendments to the articles and in elections of officials;
. the governor and alternate governor of a suspended member would immediately cease to hold office; and
. the executive director representing a suspended member would lose office though, if also representing other non-suspended members, would be eligible for re-election by those other members.

Australia can be expected to benefit directly under the amendment to the extent that there would be a diminution of the arrears problem and therefore lower costs to be borne by other members. Indirectly, Australia and other members are likely to benefit from a stronger IMF which can obtain more consistent adherence by members to their obligations.

Australia has already accepted this set of amendments to the articles through the treaty making power vested in the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade as authorised by the Governor-General in Council. The amendments will come into effect when they have been accepted by the required number of members. This is likely to occur before the end of 1991. Since the IMF's articles of agreement are reproduced in schedule 1 of the principal Act, part 3 of this Bill amends schedule 1 in a parallel fashion. Clause 2 provides for commencement of that part by proclamation when the amendment of the IMF's articles has come into effect. I commend this Bill to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: General Purpose : Reference of Annual Reports

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Robert Brown) proposed:
That sessional order 28B be amended as follows:
(1) by adding at the end of paragraph (b):

"Annual reports of government departments and statutory authorities tabled in the House shall stand referred to the relevant committee for any inquiry the committee may wish to make. Reports shall stand referred to committees in accordance with a schedule tabled by the Speaker to record the areas of responsibility of each committee: Provided that (i) any question concerning responsibility for a report or a part of a report shall be determined by the Speaker, and (ii) the period during which an inquiry concerning an annual report may be commenced by a committee shall end on the day on which the next annual report of that Department or authority is presented to the House."; and
(2) by omitting paragraph (c) and substituting the following paragraph:

"(c) Each committee appointed under subparagraphs (a) (i) to (iv) and (vi) to (viii), inclusive, shall consist of 12 members and the committee appointed under subparagraph (a)(v) shall consist of 10 members, with membership of each committee reflecting the proportion of Government to non-government Members in the House, namely, 6 Government and 4 non-government Members for a committee of 10 members and 7 Government and 5 non-government Members for a committee of 12 members. Each committee may be supplemented with up to 3 members for a particular inquiry. Government members are to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and non-government members are to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips in consultation with any minority group or other non-government member. In the event of disagreement in the nominations, the disagreement shall be notified to the Speaker who shall inform the House and the House shall determine the matter: Provided that if the appropriate numbers of government and non-government members have been nominated and the committee has met and elected a chairman no other nomination or notification of disagreement other than in respect of the filling of a casual or supplementary vacancy shall be made.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Opposition supports the motion that has been moved by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) on behalf of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Price). There are two parts to this motion, as I understand it. The first is in relation to annual reports. The proposal is that automatically, when annual reports of departments are tabled, those annual reports will be referred to the appropriate House committees, and then it is a matter for the committees to decide whether or not some action is necessary. For example, the committees could decide to conduct some kind of inquiry into the activities of a department or a particular activity of a department. The Opposition believes that this is a step in the right direction. It will provide an automatic arrangement for the House committees to look at the activities of the various government departments.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I was concerned about when this was first brought to my notice has been taken care of. I was concerned initially that this might preclude a Minister's moving that the House take note of a report, which motion provides an opportunity for debate in the House. I am assured by the Clerks that this is not the case and that in fact there will be an opportunity now for committees to look at the reports while, at the same time, the House still has an opportunity to do so.

The second part of the motion, as I am advised, corrects an anomaly in relation to the membership of committees. I am very pleased on this occasion to be able to advise the House that the Opposition supports both parts of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I just want to make a couple of brief remarks on the second part of the motion. The amendment to the Sessional Orders relating to the appointment of committees is certainly appropriate. I would like to thank the Government and Mr Speaker for the recognition of the problem and the very rapid solution.

SPEECH.PARA: As currently framed, the Sessional Orders do not provide for the possibility of any disagreement within the Government and Opposition ranks on nominations to a committee. The Sessional Orders effectively assume that all interests in this House are represented by the two blocs--Government and Opposition--and that is a wrong assumption. Because the Sessional Orders are based on this wrong assumption, my recent nomination for membership of the Select Committee on the Print Media was frustrated.

It is not the case that all members sitting on the Opposition side of the House are subject to the discipline of the Opposition Whip, whether on the issue of nominations to a committee or anything else. The motion would amend the Sessional Orders to require the Opposition Whip to consult on nominations with any minority group or non- government member and, in the event of disagreement, the Speaker has to be notified and the matter brought before the House. To be completely consistent, the motion should provide for the same procedure to be observed by the Government Whip. However, that is another matter.

I certainly do not anticipate making frequent use of the new provisions. However, I certainly welcome the amendment as a small step towards the reassertion of the role of this House as a true House of Representatives--and I stress the word `Representatives'--rather than just a rubber stamp for the parties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, for Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on rice produced in Australia to raise funds for a research and development program for the rice industry. This has been requested by the Ricegrowers Association of Australia on behalf of New South Wales rice growers and on behalf of the Queensland Rice Marketing Board, which represents Queensland rice growers.

The Government will provide funding to match industry levies up to 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production in line with established policy of encouraging increased rural productivity and profitability through research and the commercialisation of research findings. The Government's rural research and development policy, which encourages increased contributions by primary industry, was established by the Government in February 1985 and reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, Research Innovation and Competitiveness.

The Australian rice industry consists of a temperate industry located in New South Wales, producing about 95 per cent of total production and a tropical industry located in Queensland. The industry produces around 800,000 to 900,000 tonnes of paddy rice per year, with a gross value of production in 1989-90 of $148m. About 85 to 90 per cent of production is exported to around 30 countries.

Domestically, sales--including value adding--exceed $60m. There is significant value adding involved, with the industry packaging and marketing its own branded product. The rice industry has a major commitment to research in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. Research has, in the past, been funded primarily by growers with Commonwealth grant assistance also provided from the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, RIRDC.

The establishment of a joint Commonwealth-industry scheme will broaden the industry's research funding base and assist in enabling the industry to achieve its full potential. The levy will apply to those varieties included in the schedule to the Bill but with provision for new varieties to be added and for varieties no longer produced to be deleted.

Under current industry research funding arrangements, both the New South Wales and Queensland rice industries fund research on a budget allocation basis. That is, the industry agrees on the total amount of contribution before the start of each financial year and, in fact, before the greater proportion of rice is harvested. This ensures a reliable flow of funds to the research program, whereas a volume based funding system would have reflected the swings in production which have occurred over the last few years. For example, production fell from 923,000 tonnes in 1989-90 to a forecast 726,000 in 1990-91.

This arrangement will continue under the new scheme. In practice then, the operative levy rate per tonne will be determined following the decision by industry on the level of its bulk contribution. This rate will be calculated towards the end of the harvest but before the start of the financial year, when production can be accurately determined.

The industry may determine different rates for different rice varieties to account for differing research requirements in each season but cannot determine a rate of more than $2 per tonne. Once the industry has determined a rate or rates, the Minister will be advised and will set those rates and have them published in the Gazette. The levy rate will be set by subordinate legislation because timing is tight between setting the rates of the levies and the first payment of levies. The levy will be collected from pool returns at the end of the season for the research program of the following year.

The levy will be payable by the grower and its collection will be in accordance with the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. Amounts equal to the levy and the Commonwealth's matching contribution will be paid into a separate sub-account under the management of the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. Based on the current level of funding by the industry, in some years its contribution will be greater than 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production, which is the maximum the Commonwealth will match for funding purposes.

It is expected that total levy collections will remain constant from one year to the next, or perhaps increase slightly. The cost to the Budget, in terms of Commonwealth matching expenditure, is expected to be $570,000 per annum in 1991-92 to 1994-95. The Bill will come into force on royal assent and the levy will be imposed on rice produced and delivered to the processor after that time. It is intended that the levy will be imposed on rice produced in the 1991-92 season and the research program under this arrangement will commence in 1992-93.
On behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: HONEY LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:HONEY LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1991HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 August, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Opposition parties support the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. The honey industry is a very small industry compared to the great rural industries of Australia--the wool, beef, wheat and dairy industries. Nevertheless, it is a very valuable and efficient industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Using the 1989-90 figures, because the annual reports containing the relevant production figures for 1990-91 are not yet available, Australia generally produces 22,000 to 24,000 tonnes of honey a year. There are about 800 beekeepers. Australia exports over half that production--12,000 to 13,000 tonnes--and gained export income of $16m to $17m. Those exports went mainly to the United Kingdom, Germany, Singapore, the United States and Japan. Beeswax was also exported.

Australia is a small producer by world standards. According to the 1989-90 annual report of the Australian Honey Board, world production was 690,000 tonnes, with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics easily the largest producer with 225,000 tonnes. China was second largest producer with 180,000 tonnes and Australia was the eighth largest producer.

Australia has certain natural advantages in the production of honey. We have long hours of sunshine and a great selection of nectar- laden native trees that have the ability to produce honey in an array, flavour and quality as good as or better than anywhere else in the world. Unfortunately, the Australian industry is not yet taking full advantage of this asset. We sell too much bulk rather than branded products.

The Australian Honey Board believes that the future prosperity of the Australian honey industry rests with its ability to recognise and pursue the unmatched marketing opportunities presented by these varieties and an ability to produce to high, objective quality standards. Traditionally, Australian honey has been valued on colour and viscosity regardless of source--a practice that ignores its many other distinct attributes and limits its potential to command higher prices and increase consumer demand. This type of marketing has led to a decline in real incomes for Australia's honey producers.

When honey is sold in bulk it must sell at whatever the world price is for bulk honey because we have only a very small percentage--about 4 per cent--of the world trade. So we certainly are not the price setters for the international market. Therefore, it is of considerable importance for the future benefit and prosperity of our honey producers that they move to a brand of product which can command and maintain that better price in a difficult marketing situation. That means that there is a need for promotion and research and development. Hence this particular piece of legislation.

At the present time the honey industry is paying a levy of 0.45c per kilogram of honey for research and development. The standard dollar for dollar arrangements have been basically bipartisan for many years, and go back well before the 1985 legislation. I refer to the points made by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) when he introduced the Rice Levy Bill earlier, because it is a similar type of legislation. We talk about such legislation a lot in this place because of all the different rural industries that have these levies. I think there are 20 or 22 and rice is an additional one. It is good to see the rice industry moving in that direction, although it means a lot of legislation. I think there might be a case, once again on a bipartisan basis, for looking at how the legislation could be simplified or rationalised, not in any way to remove the individual ability of the industries but to streamline the legislative process here.

Last year the industry provided $129,000, and that was matched by the Commonwealth. The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations wants to increase the maximum level beyond the 0.5c per kilogram to 0.75c--and that is the purpose of this Bill--so that it can increase the operative level from the present 0.45c to 0.52c per kilogram in order to maintain the research and development process. That will also get it closer to the maximum set by the Government, which seems to me to be a sensible goal. All of these rural industries have a maximum level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production at the present time, while the actual levy or operative rate is about 0.4 per cent.

The last annual report of the Honeybee Research Council was for 1989-90. It has since been replaced by the Honeybee Research and Development Council, which is in line with the Government's policy. I note that we will be presented during this debate with some figures for the financial year just ended. Certainly having those figures will add to the debate because it is better for us to have the up-to-date figures. Where possible, when the Government is introducing legislation of this type, it would be helpful to have the most recent information attached to it so that we can gain a better understanding. I have here the 1989-90 figures, although I know they are now out of date. I have just been presented with a copy of the later figures for approval for incorporation. That is sensible, but there is no time to look at them in detail.

There are some questions that arise concerning the operation of the Research Council and the expenditure of money. Firstly, it appears that a high percentage of the total expenditure of the Council has been spent on administration. If possible, it would be better if we could be provided with a better break-down of those figures and also of the total expenditures. Additional figures I have for 1990-91 show that $77,000 was spent on administration, which is 23 per cent of total revenue--a very high percentage.

I understand that that figure comes down to 18 per cent when a workshop that was conducted, and considered to be worth while, is removed. I would then suggest that the people who present the figures would be wise to exclude those costs, where there is some form of legitimate activity that should be under research and development, from expenses or administration because it conveys the wrong message. It conveys the message that there is a body which is top-heavy and that the money of the beekeepers of Australia, the honey producers, is not getting through for the purpose intended.

I make the same comment on the figure of $55,576 for directors' fees and expenses. That is a pretty exorbitant percentage when compared with the total revenue of $343,424. I am told that that amount includes $14,694 for that same workshop. If it was a workshop for the industry, once again it would be better if it were excluded. That then brings directors' fees and expenses down to around $36,000. That certainly looks a better figure. I am saying that there should be some work done in this area. It may be evident in the 1990-91 report--when we have had a chance to look at these figures--that it is presented in a better way. It is important that the taxpayers of Australia can see--if they care to look--that their dollar for dollar contribution has been wisely spent and spent in the area that it should be, and that the apiarists are also relaxed because their money is being efficiently spent.

It raises the question, for some of the smaller industries: what is the best way to have these research arrangements so that the dollar for dollar arrangement continues? That is important. It means that that industry is contributing for research when many non-rural industries in Australia do nothing for research, and that there is some stability in the dollar for dollar basis with the Government. In good times or bad times, that rural industry provides the money. It is a very valuable concept which I believe we should maintain. I am saying that for the smaller industries there may be more efficient ways of delivery. I know there is the general Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, and I understand the honey people are becoming part of that. But is there included in the figures, as distinct from their own costs, the cost of membership or shared overhead costs of that board or body? If there is, what is it and how efficient is that total arrangement? That would certainly help me to gain a better understanding of the costs and benefits of this type of arrangement for the honey industry and, from that, other similarly sized industries.

Perhaps when this other document is presented we will be able to see that in greater detail. If it is not there, then when the Minister is replying he may be able to answer. I put those as genuine questions as a supporter of the industry. A percentage of the industry is in my electorate. We have some very good honey coming out of northern Victoria because of the different trees that are there--box honey and so forth. I have a desire to see this industry strengthened because it is one which has a natural advantage in Australia. In the future it should be able to become a bigger and better industry in the sense of not only providing more in quantity but also being able to upgrade its quality image and maximise its return in the market. As I said earlier, we support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to support the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. Honey is important to New South Wales because that State produces about 43 per cent of Australia's honey. It is important in the electorate of Eden-Monaro and south-eastern New South Wales because a high proportion of New South Wales honey is produced in that area. I appreciate that many honey producers are nomadic in their existence and quite frequently move around the State and the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will allow for more funding for research and development on honey and on honeybees. The Federal Council of the Australian Apiarists Associations endorsed an increase in the operative rate, which requires an increase in the maximum levy rate and that is what we are doing today. The Council requested an increase for R& funding to 0.75c per kilogram. An increase is needed for research, and I compliment the Government, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the industry on reaching the agreement leading to the legislation.

The Honeybee Research and Development Council has the vested funds to administer a shoestring budget of $350,000, including Commonwealth matching contributions. I believe that the five member council and Anne Kowalski, the executive officer, are to be complimented on the management of those funds. I appreciate that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has queried the 1990- 91 budget of the Honeybee Research and Development Council and I acknowledge that listing needs to be carefully made. In fact, the 1991-92 Budget indicates a reasonably high percentage being spent on research and development. As the honourable member for Murray has said, the designations need to be properly appropriated. The Council has said that $286,000 of the $350,000 has been spent on projects, workshops and reviews--that is 81.5 per cent of its budget. That seems to me to be pretty good.

Let us look at the priorities of the Honeybee Research and Development Council through its annual operational plan. There are 14 projects, of which five relate to nutrition and disease. These are not only important to honey production, but are vital to agricultural crops. There are paid and incidental pollination services available which assist farmers throughout this nation. The work of the honey producers is very important to other people involved in agriculture throughout the country. Increasing numbers of farmers and growers are appreciating the advisability of using honeybees.

Some of those projects involve techniques for the control of the American brood disease, work on diseases and disorders of the queen honeybees, investigation on oxytetracycline in honey and on workshops and work on pollination. For instance, the University of Queensland at Gatton, which has a great record in apiculture, is being provided with part funds for a project on the results of foraging in entomophilous crops. Pesticide monitoring is also important. We need to maintain the high standards that we have. I understand that the Council is considering
research on pesticide monitoring. Honey is seen as a natural product, rich in essential minerals, and the Council wants to keep that reputation.

The bee-breeding programs will keep going until 1994. This gives a very real opportunity for providing beekeepers with quality stock. As well as that, there is expenditure which will lead to better production in other ways. For instance, the Council is looking at the problems associated with loss or potential loss of useful nectar and pollen sources in the Ngarkat Conservation Park in South Australia. There is an investigation on banksia for that purpose. It is expected that there will be increasing demands on the nectar and pollen sources which could become a decreasing resource.

I have with me a table of expenditure of the Honeybee Research and Development Council, which indicates research totalling $286,000 for 1991-92, Council expenses totalling $20,000, and administration totalling $44,000. I believe that is a reasonable breakdown of expenditure. The Council should be complimented on achieving that during this financial year. I seek leave to incorporate the table of expenditure of the Honeybee Research and Development Council in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Council also looks for development opportunities for Australian honey. The Honey Board, a statutory authority operating on a small budget, currently about $500,000, is also involved in development opportunities; for instance, domestic promotion, overseas promotion in conjunction with importers, the licensing of exporters, setting the minimum export price and the provision of an information service. The previous Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the present Treasurer (Mr Kerin), stated that the Honey Board could continue to operate until 11 May 1994. However, I understand that the Federal Council of the Australian Apiarists Associations accepts that the Board should wind up eventually and requests that the Board be terminated earlier, by 31 December 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government now has to consider whether to incorporate the Board into the Australian Horticultural Corporation, a larger umbrella organisation, or get out of marketing altogether. The industry could become a larger cooperative. Admittedly, the present cooperative is fairly large with 60 per cent of producers now in the Honey Corporation of Australia, which produces the Capilano brand of honey.

The Australian export of bulk honey has reached 13,000 tonnes a year, with our principal markets being in the United Kingdom, Germany, Singapore and Spain. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party said, it would be better if that bulk honey was exported as prepacked honey. That fact makes our industry very important, and we do send prepacked honey to Malaysia, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, for instance. Our honey represents about one per cent of the world trade and we need to compete, along with many other primary industries, with prices in other countries. The United States has its price support scheme and the European Community has its ad valorem tariffs on imports of up to 27 per cent.

This is a $35m industry in Australia. New South Wales is the main producing State and the electorate of Eden-Monaro produces a significant proportion of that 43 per cent of Australian honey. I am delighted that there is overall support for this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to be able to speak on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill because it is a very important industry throughout my electorate. The industry wants this legislation. It is good to see that it recognises the importance of research. I have a large number of beekeepers throughout my electorate. The Bendigo-Maryborough area in central Victoria is a focus for the beekeeping industry. There is a large industry in Maryborough which trades under the name of Capilano Honey. I am sure that it would be well known to honourable members in this chamber; the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) may even have visited that plant at some time.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister has not visited that plant, I am sure an invitation will be forthcoming to him to visit it. It is an employer of 30 people in Maryborough and a lot of its product goes for export. This is very important from Australia's point of view. During 1989-90 Australia exported 12,637 tonnes of honey, with an f.o.b. value of $16.4m. One of the biggest years we had was in 1988-89 when we shipped 13,502 tonnes of honey in bulk out of Australia.

One of Australia's advantages in producing honey is that it has long hours of sunshine and a great selection of nectar-laden trees--particularly native trees--and those two factors combine to produce honey in an array, flavour and quality unmatched in the world. I have had the opportunity to experience the taste of many of these varieties of honey, as has the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who enjoys it also. We have here a very good export earner for Australia, if only we can develop this market fully. We can take advantage of exporting brand name products rather than exporting in bulk.

The Capilano name is becoming better known worldwide. I believe that, if we add further value to the honey product, we will see a greater export market for Australian honeys, particularly into the near Asian market and the market in Japan.

I believe that, traditionally, Australian honey has been valued on colour and viscosity, regardless of the source--a practice that ignores many other distinct attributes and limits its potential to command higher prices and increase consumer demand. There are some pretty big markets to the near east of Australia that we should be developing.

I think that the background to this legislation is very important, and I will quote from the Honey Research Council annual report 1989-90, put out by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It is important that the base for this is established. The report states:

The Rural Industries Research Act 1985, provides funding, administrative and organisational arrangements for rural research trust funds and councils. The arrangements provide for council members (other than the chairman and government member) to be selected against objective selection criteria by an independent selection committee.

I am delighted to say that I have a representative who lives very close to my electorate, Mr Robert McDonald, who is a member of the Honey Research Council. He is a commercial apiarist and comes from Castlemaine. He is a member of the Australian Honey Board as well as the Honey Research Council and has a very great knowledge of the honey industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Very well respected in the industry.
—-Yes. The report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Councils are required to prepare five-year research and development plans and annual programs in consultation with the industry and research organisations. They are also required to prepare an annual report which provides industry and government with information on, and an assessment of, the operations of the council. The arrangements provide significantly increased autonomy and responsibility for research councils.

The objectives of its research are very important. It gives very good value for the dollars it spends on research. It has done some extremely good research projects and obtains extremely good value for the dollars spent on those research projects. I will quote a couple of them.
The honey research projects 1989-90, priority area 1, `Bee nutrition and disease' was a very important program. It only received $2,600 in funding. Its purpose was:
To evaluate the quality of honey bee collected pollens so as to assist in the honey bee nutritional management.
The report goes on to say that it also had a project on diseases and disorders of the queen honeybee. Its objective was:

To determine the types of diseases and disorders affecting all life stages of the queen honey bee and to ascertain the causes and possible control of those diseases and disorders determined to be most severe or common.

The report continues with another project on the evaluation of the spread and present and future pest status of the European wasp, which is a potentially significant economic threat to honeybees and honey production in Australia.

The honey industry is a very decentralised industry. It mainly comprises small apiarists who travel long distances. They are mainly small producers and sell their honey to people like Capilano at Maryborough. They are experiencing great difficulty with the cost of fuel. Most of them are small operators, as I have said, and the cost of petrol over recent times, which has seen an escalation fluctuating through the 60c range up to the 80c range per litre, has been a significant factor in the viability of the small apiarists in collecting honey. Much of that honey ultimately finds its way onto world markets.

The previous Federal primary industries Minister, now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), recently confirmed that the value of honeybees to the Australian economy exceeds $800m per annum. This includes honey and beeswax products and pollination to other forms of agriculture. The Honey Corporation of Australia, which is the trading name for Capilano at Maryborough, employs 30 people on a full time basis. When we take into account the large number of small apiarists who operate in the forests and throughout central Victoria and southern New South Wales, we see that there are a great number of people involved in this industry. It is very important that something be done to assist them in relation to the cost of fuel. It is one of the major costs associated with their industry.

Apiarists believe that they are contributing to the economic well-being of this country by gaining valuable export dollars with the sale of honey overseas and also by providing it to the local domestic market. I have had correspondence at various times from Mr Trevor Tonkin, the President of the Central Victorian Apiarists Association. He raised this issue of the high cost of fuel and the detrimental impact that it is having on the industry.

One of the areas that has been underestimated and neglected in Australian agriculture is the value of bees as pollinators. There is quite a bit of research being done in this area regarding the pollination services sector of the Australian beekeeping industry. Currently, it has been undertaking an economic evaluation of that. One of the components of the study was the estimate of the social contribution of honeybee pollination. Honeybees pollinate a diversity of crops, pasture species and even private gardens. Most of this pollination is unremunerated, although it is of significant value to all sections of society.

It is particularly good to be in Canberra at this time of the year when the Floriade festival is being held. We are able to see the wonderful display of flowers here and know that the bee population is out there working on behalf of Australia and gaining export dollars. I am encouraged by that.

One of the preliminary results of the Honey Research Council's survey, which forms part of its study, would place the social value of the pollination market at between $600m and $1.2 billion. The results of this part of the project have already been widely reported. There is much more to be gained on the export market, as I mentioned earlier, by doing more for value adding to the product. I have heard the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), talking about value adding to products. I hope that he will give the Council every encouragement to continue its research.

I am pleased to be able to support this Bill which he has brought before the House. I trust that he will be able to give greater encouragement to the apiarists who perform this valuable role and particularly to the processors. I hope that he will encourage them to diversify and add value and will give them marketing encouragement overseas so that they are able to market under brand names specific types of honey collected from specific areas of our native vegetation which gives Australian honeys such a distinctive flavour on world markets. I believe that a bit of marketing in South East Asia would considerably increase the capacity of Australia to export into those areas and would establish a much larger export market than we already have. With those few remarks, I am pleased to support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There are three Bills being debated cognately today--the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1991, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill 1991. It is pleasing that both sides of the House support these amending Bills. The purpose of these Bills is to amend the Honey Levy Act (No. 1) 1962, the Honey Levy Act (No. 2) 1962 and the Honey Export Charge Act 1973 to provide for an increase in the maximum rate of the levy for research and development purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: This is in line with amendments in many other fields of primary industry where leaders in those fields are requesting the Government to expand levies to spend more money on research and development. It is one of the positive aspects of agriculture. It indicates that, even in tough times such as this, there is a recognition of the need to spend money in R&. If we are going to be competitive in the real global economy we live in, that is the main game. It is pleasing to see that the industry itself has requested the Government to move in this regard.

To give some background, the Bills cover, respectively, levy imposed on honey produced in Australia and sold as honey, levy imposed on honey produced in Australia and used in manufacture and an export charge on honey exported and not already levied. The levy charge is used to fund the operations of the Honeybee Research and Development Council in accordance with the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The Honey Levy Act (No. 1) 1962, the Honey Levy Act (No. 2) 1962 and the Honey Export Charge Act 1973 set the maximum levy charge rate, while the operative rate is set by regulation. The maximum rate is currently set at 0.5c per kilogram for research and development, with the operative rate also set at 0.5c per kilogram. As I have said, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations, the FCAAA, the recognised body representing levy payers, has endorsed an increase in the operative rate to 0.52c per kilogram, which is not possible unless the current maximum levy rate is increased. The FCAAA has requested that the maximum allowable levy rate for research and development purposes be increased to 0.75c per kilogram to facilitate further increases as part of its program for progressively increasing its contribution to R&.

Basically, increasing the maximum rate will give industry the flexibility to increase the contributions to research over an extended period and thus avoid the need for frequent amendments to legislation every 12 months or so. That is very sensible. I commend the industry for that. The amendment to increase the maximum rate of levy for research purposes is consistent with the Government's objective of encouraging rural industries to increase their contributions to research to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. The Commonwealth matches the industry levies for funding expenditures on research and development up to 0.5 per cent of GVP. The Australian honey industry is currently contributing approximately 0.4 per cent of its GVP to research and development.

Australia produces annually approximately 25,000 to 28,000 tonnes of honey, valued at approximately $35m. As the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) pointed out, it has a broader aspect than that because the humble little bee has a massive impact on horticulture, in my area in particular. It is interesting to note that this afternoon the speakers in this debate come from many States, including Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. This industry is widespread. The contribution overall that the honeybee makes to agriculture is much larger. I think it is estimated at something like $1 billion in total value at the very least.

There are approximately 2,000 apiarists producing commercial quantities of honey and some 30 to 40 packers and exporters. As I have said, apiaries are located all around Australia. Domestic consumption amounts to around 15,000 tonnes of the crop. Consumption has been static at around 0.9 kilograms per head in recent years. There is an increasing trend to floral species of honey rather than blends. Prices have been volatile but increased in 1990-91 to return about $1.25 per kilogram to producers, which we can regard as moderate. I would like to see it a little higher but there have been moderate returns. The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations, through its State affiliated bodies, represents the bulk of producers.

Australia exports between 12,000 and 13,000 tonnes per annum, either in bulk--which accounts for about 90 per cent--or in pre-packed form. Our principal markets are the UK, Germany, Singapore and Spain for bulk honey and Malaysia, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates for pre-packed honey. That indicates that there are still small market niches in the EEC. While we see the Europeans as a massive trade bloc--which they are--corrupting world markets, we have to try to get every market niche that is available. If we are able to get honey into these markets and if we are able to get another product into these markets, we have to work hard at it and, while we are still in the main game, try to get some sense through the GATT. We represent about one per cent of world trade. Clearly, Australia is a price taker. World production of honey is about one million tonnes per annum. The major producers are China, USSR, the United States, Mexico and Argentina.

The Honeybee Research and Development Council was established on 2 July 1990 under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, although it has existed previously with slightly reduced functions as the Honey Research Council. The HRDC is a subsidiary, although relatively autonomous, body under the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation.

The majority of issues in these Bills have been canvassed. I think another speaker wishes to speak on this Bill before the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) resumes. I would like to say that, while the honey industry is small, it is a very important industry. I emphasise the role that bees play, not only in producing honey for Australia but in horticulture. Bee-keeping is one of the most ancient of primary industries, going back thousands of years.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) made an important comment about the ongoing need to ensure that chemicals do not get into the whole process of producing honey, whether it be through aerial spraying or drift. Bees are very susceptible. One producer in my area lost all his hives because of a problem with aerial spraying. Someone who was spraying a crop of another type inadvertently wiped out his bees. That is a problem that we need to address at all times. Bees are very susceptible to chemicals, particularly pesticides. I commend the Bills to the House. It is pleasing that both sides of the House support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am delighted to have this opportunity to speak to the Honey Levy (No. 1 ) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill, as I was when I spoke in the debate when the original Acts passed through the House, again in a bipartisan way, in April 1988. I remember on that occasion there was a lot of banter about different connotations concerning honey, and so on. There was all sorts of talk about honey-toned words, sweet talk and so on, as we joined together on one of those all too rare occasions to speak on Bills in a bipartisan fashion. It is a pity that there are not more of these sorts of Bills around. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) indicated that there are Bills coming up for debate in relation to the rice industry, and it is to be hoped that we will also have a bipartisan approach then.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was coming into the House earlier, someone said, `Make sure you get up and make a 3B speech on the honey levy'--meaning that I ought to be upstanding, be brief and be seated. However, before I am seated I have quite a few things to say with regard to this wonderful industry that we have in Australia, which accounts for a considerable amount of export income for this country. We export something in excess of 13,000 tonnes of honey each year--which is a lot of honey. I shall mention a little bit about that later on when I say a word on behalf of the bees and do a little bit of promotion of the honey itself. It is easy to forget just what a significant part the bees play in this whole operation. In fact, if they were not there, as the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) would know, we would not have this industry.

As all honourable members would know, my electorate of Macquarie has a considerable amount of beauty and magnificence because of the abundance of trees and gardens. Some of the most famous gardens in Australia are at Leura, Lawson, Hazelbrook, Katoomba and other areas in the Blue Mountains. I am quite sure that the bees feel that it is the bees' heaven when they get up there and enjoy the succulent nectar that they are able to extract from those magnificent trees and flowers. Within Macquarie electorate there are many apiarists engaged in what is a quite profitable and large industry. Also within my electorate is the Hawkesbury campus of the University of Western Sydney. It is a very famous campus in Australia. It was formerly known as the Hawkesbury Agricultural College. As a matter of fact, it is celebrating its centenary this year. A significant part of a faculty within that campus is playing a very important role in the apiary industry, and it has done so for many years.

These Bills before us are the result of a request by the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations to increase the operative rate to 0.52c per kilogram from 1992, as a part of its program of increasing the producer contribution to research and development. Research and development is very significant in terms of the University of Western Sydney. As has already been indicated, the Opposition supports this request, and the industry is to be commended for its commitment to the continuing provision of adequate research and development programs. In the context of this debate one could almost say that research and development are buzz words--not only in association with this industry but indeed throughout the rural sector and the manufacturing sector in general. The importance of research and development for all of Australia's industries cannot be underestimated, especially in the light of today's economic climate.

These three Bills cover a number of specific areas, including the levy imposed on honey produced in Australia and sold, the levy imposed on honey produced in Australia and used in the production of other goods, and an export charge on honey exported not already levied. Since the research and development levy was introduced in 1980, the industry has endeavoured to keep abreast of increasing costs by regular upward adjustments to the levy. As a levy ceiling is stipulated in the Act, the industry has now sought amendment to the legislation in order that the contribution to research and development may be maintained in real terms.

This approach by the honey industry must therefore be seen as a major input in this area and provides an example to other Australian industries. The honourable member for Murray made the pertinent comment that unfortunately we are not seeing enough funding for R& from the private sector and other industries. The Honey Research and Development Council has a number of objectives, including increasing commercial returns to the members of the honey industry and to the community in general and making more effective use of the resources and skills in the community in general and of the scientific community in particular.

Bee breeding and generic improvements of bee stock have always been a priority in research and development funding in this area and will assist in achieving the objectives that I have just mentioned. Of the two stock improvement programs that have been running for some years now, the University of Western Sydney, Hawkesbury campus--as I said, formerly known as the Hawkesbury Agricultural College--has played a major role. The Hawkesbury campus is located in a rural setting at Richmond, New South Wales, which is one of the historic Macquarie towns. Originally established in 1891 as the Hawkesbury Agricultural College, it produced the first agriculturalists in New South Wales and rapidly developed as a leading centre of agricultural education in Australia. Under the guidance of Professor Graham Swain, the Hawkesbury campus of the University of Western Sydney continues to maintain a high level of academic achievement and has complemented its horticultural and agricultural studies with the faculties of business and land economy, nursing and community studies, science and technology and the centre of commerce.

The Hawkesbury network has a long tradition of applied research and has strengthened and extended its post-graduate work and research with the guidance of a full time research coordinator. It is nearly 100 years since Hawkesbury commenced an apiary with 12 swarms of hybrid and Italian bees. Commercial queen rearing has been a feature of the apiary department of the university. The university plays a vital role in development and research for the honey industry. In addition to that, the apiary department conducts schools and seminars for beekeepers and apiarists. It has had substantial influence over the years with regard to bee breeding and in the distribution of breeding stock throughout the world.

Two recent programs undertaken by Hawkesbury that are of particular interest in regard to development and research are the eastern Australian bee breeding program, which involves research with Italian honeybees, and a project entitled `The Evaluation of Honey Bees', which involves research into the establishment of honeybee stock imported from the USSR, which is very interesting news in this present day when we are hearing so much about the Soviet Union. We hope that further similar cooperation will become the order of the day.

The apiary manager, the gentleman in charge of the apiary at the University, Steve Johnson, reports that each year four or five research submissions that would ultimately benefit the industry are put forward from the actual apiary on the Hawkesbury campus. Unfortunately, funding limitations will always have a bearing on their approval, which is to be regretted. Nevertheless, with the increase in this levy and with the dollar for dollar contributions, we may see more of these submissions put into practice with regard to research and development. I hope that these Bills will assist research institutions such as Hawkesbury to continue to undertake their special work.

I mentioned that I also wanted to say a few words on behalf of the bees because, when one starts to read about them and thinks about what they achieve, one cannot help but be staggered. As I said earlier, not much has been said in this debate or in any debate in this House on their behalf. Of course, if we did not have them, we would not be here and engaged in this debate. But before I talk about the bees, I want to say a word or two about honey.

Honey has been described as one of the purest foods available to humans. There are a great number of varieties of honey. There are many colours, all sorts of aromas, different flavours and varying densities. Some of the honey in Australia comes from over 600 varieties of eucalypt, which means that we get over 600 varieties of eucalypt honey. Honey is a wonderful food. I will give some details of just how good it is as I summarise a couple of points made by Fred Bailey in his excellent book Bee Keeping in Australia: for pleasure and profit, written in 1982. He says that honey does not need refrigeration and that, if it is kept sealed, it will keep indefinitely. He mentions that, when honey is eaten, it is easily digested, readily absorbed into the bloodstream and provides new energy, warmth and a feeling of general well-being which is brought on quickly and naturally. It tends to regulate the system without the aid of drugs or laxatives.

Fred Bailey also mentions that, even though the basic components of honey are carbohydrates--they account for about 80 per cent of it--those carbohydrates are in the form of natural sugars and are non-fattening. Those people listening to this debate who are on diets may care to take note of that. Honey can be ingested directly into the bloodstream of the human body. It is said that athletes find honey very valuable as a training food as the energy released by natural carbohydrates is immediately available to the body; that cannot be said of a great deal of the other foods that we eat today.

The content of natural sugars varies in different honeys depending on the floral source of the original nectar. Fred Bailey goes on to talk about the very complex nature of some of the sugar--glucose, fructose, sucrose, laevulose and so on. Of course, that does not mean much to us here today. But it reveals a little of just how complex this marvellous food is. He says that it contains significant minerals and that the lightness or the darkness of the honey often indicates the degree of minerals in the honey that are beneficial to human beings. The darker the honey, the more minerals it contains. Some of the minerals found in honey that he mentions are iron, calcium, copper, sodium, manganese, potassium, magnesium, nickel, silicon, phosphorous, cobalt, aluminium and chromium. A lot of people will be very surprised to realise just how many minerals are in this wonderful food. All this is gathered by that little bee that we see buzzing around in our gardens and do not take much notice of.

Mr Bailey says that honey contains amino acids; in some varieties, as many as 17 different amino acids have been detected. It contains vitamins B1, B2, B6 and C in varying quantities depending on the degree of ripening of the honey within the hive. He mentions--and I agree with him wholeheartedly--that we can feel quite proud of the marvellous industry that we have and the honeys produced in this country when we go to the Royal Easter Show and see the displays there in various competitions. Those honeys are rated amongst the best in the world.

One or two other things can be said about honey; for example, it is aseptic and bactericidal. Tests carried out by bacteriologists prove that organisms and germs which affect the human body cannot live in honey because it withdraws the moisture necessary for the survival of the bacteria.

I will not dwell on this for long but, in saying a few words about bees, I want to point out to the House and to those people listening just how much work is involved in bees producing one kilogram of honey. Mathematicians have calculated that to place one kilogram of honey on our breakfast table--let us remember that we export over 13,000 tonnes--the bees have to carry almost 80,000 loads of nectar. In doing so, they would fly a combined total of 160,000 kilometres, or approximately four times around the world. That is just to produce a kilogram of honey. It is almost impossible to believe, but it is proven. It is quite an amazing achievement that we take for granted when we have a teaspoon or a tablespoon of honey on our toast every morning.

Bees may visit as many as 300 flowers or florets to obtain one load of nectar--one load of nectar being a very light weight indeed. These little creatures set us a great example. They live in almost complete harmony within their hive--something that perhaps in our parliamentary hive we have not learned to do. In fact, I noticed that Marcus Aurelius said:
What is not good for the hive is not good for the bees.
There are quite a few other comments and statements that could be made about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thought you were going to say, `Here comes another bee'.
—-I notice that the honourable member for Franklin is here. The island of Tasmania is very famous for the honeys that it produces, some unique to that island.

SPEECH.PARA: There are lots of things that one can say. We have a wonderful example in the bee. Madam Deputy Speaker, the last time I spoke in a similar debate I made the mistake of mentioning the worker bee in the masculine form, saying that he did this and he did that, when in fact the workers are female. I was spoken to resoundingly at the conclusion of that debate in 1988 and I remember it very well. So I am not making that mistake today, Madam Deputy Speaker.

In conclusion, I just want to say that it is a good idea for people to try to find out more about these creatures. There is a great film called The City of Bees, put out by the Moody Bible Institute. It is quite remarkable and ought to be seen by everybody. It describes the marvellous life that these creatures live. There are lots of books, such as National Geographic, which tell us a lot about them.

It has been very good to be able to speak on this legislation and I would just like to quote from the book of Proverbs, which contains sayings which are supposed to be from the wisest man who ever lived, Solomon. It says:
Kind words are like honey, sweet to the taste and good for your health.

As I started out by saying, it is very pleasant to be in this House and to be able to speak in a bipartisan way on a Bill which a lot of people would not consider an important Bill. But when we start to really look into the products, the producers and, indeed, the people who take these products and develop and sell them, we see that we have a very significant Bill before us and a very significant industry. I commend these amending Bills to the House. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate's message No. 290.
Consideration resumed from 3 September.
Motion (by Mr Robert Brown) agreed to that:
That

(1) the House of Representatives, having considered message No. 290 of the Senate relating to amendments to the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, does not concur in the Senate's modification of the resolution transmitted to the Senate by the House in message No. 272; and
(2) a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Those factors to which I made reference earlier today in this debate have all resulted in a slow-down in business activity and a consequent spread of business failures. Every day in newspapers throughout Australia, ominous headlines tell their various versions of the same grim story.

SPEECH.PARA: A business survey carried out during the months of February to May of this year from my Deakin office gives a particularly accurate picture of Victoria's devastated economy. One thousand businesses were randomly surveyed over 11 industry sectors by my office staff and voluntary workers, 67 per cent of businesses being from the Melbourne metropolitan area and 33 per cent from country Victoria. It was alarming to discover when the results were collated that only 33 per cent of businesses were working at full capacity and businesses generally throughout the State were functioning only on average at 63 per cent capacity. A total of 54 per cent of respondents reported that sales were down in comparison with last year, while 52 per cent had decreased staff numbers and 24 per cent thought their businesses would not survive the coming 12 months. A staggering 94 per cent thought that the Federal Government was not adequately addressing the problems of small business.

Some of the individual industry sector results were even more damning. In the Melbourne metropolitan area, manufacturing industry was found to be working at only 53 per cent capacity; in the transport sector, a third of country businesses were not expected to survive; construction, transport and general industry were working at only 57 to 58 per cent capacity. The metal products sector was working only at an appallingly low 46 per cent capacity.

Some of the anecdotal information collected by interviewers as they conducted the survey was just as significant. Comments such as these were frequently made: `Get rid of the 17.5 per cent holiday loading'; `Bring back the 40-hour week'; `Banks should help businesses more'; `The cost of money is too high'; `The economy needs a kick-start with a new government'; `Penalty rates are too high'; `Unions are too powerful'; `It's not worth being a small business employer'. Other comments, frankly, were unrepeatable in this place. Perhaps the saddest comment came from one person interviewed in the manufacturing sector who said:
This business is closing down. It was opened in 1929. It's the fault of the Government. I've no faith in politicians.
Another respondent in the recreational and personal services sector ended simply with the words:
Closing down on 11.4.91.

As a direct flow-on from the widespread business failures already alluded to, Australia has now reached crisis levels of unemployment. Currently running at 9.8 per cent, unemployment is sadly expected to rise to 10.75 per cent. Some people believe in fact it will be much higher before it finally eases. The Melbourne Age on 21 August stated:
The Budget has little but the dole to offer the jobless and nothing in the way of stimulus to offer employers or business investment--
The Australian comment on the same day was:
His--
that is, Mr Kerin's--

key prescription is simply to bear down on inflation and accept the inevitable unemployment . . . The superannuation levy . . . will act like a new payroll tax making it harder for business to employ new workers . . . The cost of the levy is unemployment at a higher level, for longer.
Kenneth Davidson's comment in the Melbourne Age of the same day perhaps best sums up the criticisms of the 1991 Kerin Budget, as follows:
If this is truly the best the economy can do, then it is a fearsome indictment of everyone with responsibility for the economic policies of this country over the past decade.

However, as well as the economic costs of the excesses of the 1980s, there are dangerous social costs, the latter of which are now threatening the very fabric of Australian society. Bankruptcies, high interest rates and rising unemployment are impacting very severely on Australian families. The divorce rate has risen by 8 per cent since 1986. In 1990, there were 42,635 marriage break-ups, compared with 39,417 in 1986, according to the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The pressures and tensions of current economic conditions are likely to have had a considerable effect on contributing to this appallingly high figure.

The number of abortions has risen to the chilling figure of approximately 85,000 per year, according to figures from the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health. The fact that the recession is having an impact on whether families can afford to have more children was brought out in a series of very disturbing articles earlier this year. These articles suggested that doctors were observing an increase in the number of young middle-class women who wished to terminate pregnancies because of financial pressures, particularly because of difficulties in paying high mortgages--although it also has to be conceded there are no precise figures to support this. However, in March of this year, a spokesperson for the Sydney abortion clinic, Preterm, claimed that the number of abortions performed by the clinic had risen by 31 per cent since the recession began.

Furthermore, all types of crimes are increasing from burglaries to the most horrendous of violent crimes, like rape and murder. We have even reached the stage where women in supermarkets are warned not to leave their handbags on shopping trolleys while they buy produce because of the high incidence of handbag snatching. People are stealing to buy food now, not just drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Out of desperation.
—-Out of desperation. An article in the Time Magazine of 12 August is entitled `Are We Safe?' After reading it, one has to come to the conclusion that in fact we are not. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: ...Mundane crimes - that catalogue of burglary, robbery, serious assault and rape so routine to police and such a violation to the victim--has rocketed in the past decade--and increasingly, a major venue is the family home.

The same article contained statistics illustrating that cases of serious assault in Australia had almost doubled in the last 10 years. In 1982-83, 52 people per 100,000 of the population suffered serious assault, compared with 103 in every 100,000 in 1989-90. In addition, the number of burglaries reported to police were up by 40 per cent during the same period.

In our cities now there is a pervading sense of fear. Not only women living alone, but families feel unsafe. Citizens are preoccupied with security, so much so that in the more affluent suburbs some homes resemble medieval castles with high walls and padlocked gates, while inside the ramparts are to be found incredibly complicated and costly electronic devices, ensuring complete surveillance of house and garden. Others, who cannot afford such precautions, for the cost is high, install deadlocks on doors, metal grilles on windows, automatic light switches to feign occupancy, or whichever alarm system fits their income. Watchdogs are not as popular as they were because the rarest and most fiendish of intruders easily brutalise animals as they do human beings.

Another appalling consequence of this recession is a growing incidence of child abuse, which has to be a matter of great concern. The Sunday Herald-Sun of 18 August carried an article entitled `Child Abuse Widespread'. This contained the findings of a survey conducted by the Victorian Community Services Department indicating that 10,000 Victorian children may have been abused during the past year but only 10 per cent of cases were in fact reported. The only accurate national figures available were those from the Standing Committee of Social Welfare Administrators (WELSTAT) for 1987-88, which quoted a figure of 42,116 reported cases of child maltreatment in Australia, but it should be pointed out that this figure excluded Western Australia, where data was not available. Certainly, media reports would suggest that child abuse, as well as child abduction, is increasing as part of the recessionary pressures that Australia is facing.

The 1991 Budget addresses neither the causes of our economic and social decay nor its results. There is nothing in the Budget to give any incentive to the private sector, which employs, or used to employ, two-thirds of Australia's work force, to get it moving again. In the Budget there are no tax incentives--none whatever--for industry or individuals. There is a complete absence of any encouragement for industry to invest in plant and equipment which is fundamental to economic recovery. Nor is there any attempt in the Budget to implement other areas of reform so sorely needed, as indicated in the answers from respondents to the business survey conducted from my Deakin office. In that survey, tax incentives, labour market reform, a reduction in Government regulation and interest rate cuts were high priorities among respondents when asked what was needed to get business moving again. This Budget makes no provision for any of these initiatives.

The symptoms of our disintegration are not being tackled in the Budget, either. What is being done in this Budget to strengthen the family? Other than a small and very recent commitment by the Victorian State Government not to make any further cuts in its police force, what is being done to make citizens feel safe in their homes? Why is it that we never hear that most Australian of Australianisms `She'll be right' any more?
