The only Budget reaction to our malaise is the provision in the appropriations for further unemployment relief. So it is obvious that `She won't be right' if Labor continues in office. The 1991 Budget lacks both practical solutions to our problems and any sense of national purpose whatever.

Australians are looking for a vision as to their future. They--I might say `we', because I include myself in this--earnestly want to fulfil our full potential as a nation. The next coalition government will provide the vision and the purpose that are so vitally necessary to achieve that potential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I entered last year's Budget debate on the optimistic note that the neo-classical economic fixation of the Hawke Government was but a phase. I hopefully predicted that eventually political pragmatism and relentless criticism from Labor's rank and file would turn Labor back to economic policies of government intervention to achieve price level stability, output growth, full employment and a balance of payments equilibrium. I have to confess that on reading the usual pre-Budget series of inspired media leaks and fulminations by the gurus of the financial press, I began to believe that my predictions were likely to become true far earlier than I had previously expected.

SPEECH.PARA: The editorials around the nation were telling us that this was going to be a left wing Budget. Mr Hawke, we were assured, was a captive of the Left faction, whose bloc of 29 votes had saved him from the Keating challenge. The leader of the Left, Brian Howe, was now the Deputy Prime Minister and in the driving seat to impose radical changes in the Budget's formation.
I refer to a very intelligent article in the Age of 5 August by Michelle Grattan headed `Howe's cut and thrust behind new policies' in which she said:

If John Kerin is the central character in this month's Budget performance, Brian Howe, Minister for Community Services and Health, Deputy PM and top man in the Left, is a leading support player. The budget will see Howe, a zealous reformer, chalking up some more ambitious achievements.

Howe is active on both sides of this budget's ledger--making savings and initiating new policy. There will be big cuts in health. Howe has already announced pathology and radiology will be hit. On the spending side, Howe has won support for a substantial program to create `better cities', a hobby-horse of his for years.

We were also told that the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin) was not in the pocket of the Treasury bureaucrats as his predecessor was. He had developed a healthy dislike for those bureaucrats during his sojourn as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and he would be taking a fresh independent line.

All of this was reinforced on the eve of the Budget with a series of stories revealing that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Deputy (Mr Howe) had set aside the usual democratic processes of Cabinet to force through the economic review committee of Cabinet and then Cabinet itself a radical plan to rebuild our cities.
I refer to an article by Paul Cleary in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 August, headed `A policy triumph for the Left's deal-maker', in which he said:

Brian Howe will have good reason to smile on Tuesday. He may not want to appear smug, but while this Budget will be the ninth for the Hawke Government, it is the first in which the Left has had a clear-cut policy victory.
Then he went on to say:

The win in the ERC by Brian Howe, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, may well be written off as the payback for the Left support for Hawke. There is no question that the Left is more powerful in the Keating-less Government.

I have been around long enough not to be fooled by that sort of media hype; but hope springs eternal in the breasts of the Labor Party faithful, and I certainly wanted to believe that there would, at the height of this harsh recession, be something in the Budget for Labor's traditional constituency. Needless to say, the financial press was as surprised as everybody else. There were few reforms, let alone left wing ones, in the first Kerin Budget, which the Age editorialists so cruelly described as a `do nothing, be patient' Budget, and which the Prime Minister prefers to label as a responsible Budget.

In fairness, the Press Gallery could not be said to be completely wrong when it predicted that the Budget would wear the stamp of our Deputy Prime Minister and, by extension, the faction he leads. The fact is that two of the three memorable features of an otherwise modest and dour document were the Deputy Prime Minister's Medicare co-payment impost and his better cities program. The other feature was of course the excellent extension of superannuation benefits.

Every Budget has to be judged in its economic climate. We are currently suffering a cruel recession, with official unemployment heading towards 11 per cent, real unemployment already past that point, and the work participation rate rapidly declining.

Those of us committed to traditional Labor philosophy find no joy in a Budget that presents us with a strategy which will suppress growth, give no encouragement to investment and tolerate growing unemployment.

The recent national conference of the Labor Party made it clear that solutions to joblessness must become the Government's major Budget priority. The Federal conference called upon Cabinet to devise an integrated strategy. The first objective of the strategy would be to reduce unemployment through initiatives, to establish infrastructure projects compatible with low inflation and growth in the traded goods sector. The conference was referring in particular to projects improving the efficiency of our roads, railways and ports; housing; and development of our telecommunications and education export markets. Secondly, the conference called on the Government to expand our labour market programs to protect Australia's skills base and to provide training for the long term unemployed. It is a matter of considerable disappointment to me, and no doubt to most members of the Australian Labor Party, that only the job training scheme received any recognition in the Budget.

The national conference also resolved that an integrated strategy required the implementation of an effective trade and industry policy and suggested that the Government take several initiatives to that end. Firstly, the conference asked the Government to set up a national development fund to support the development of medium sized companies. It also suggested strengthening the national network of industrial supply offices which give direct assistance to import replacement projects. Next, the conference argued for a sectoral industry development strategy to enhance exports. A good example of the success of such policies can be seen in the current steel industry television advertisements.

The Labor Party also argued that we should be giving our trade strategy an Asian emphasis. Asia already provides our major markets and, given our geographical position, the greatest potential is obviously in that region. Finally, Labor's governing body emphasised the need for funded programs to accelerate take-up and effective utilisation of advanced manufacturing technology. It also called for the exploration of financial initiatives such as tax exemptions on special savings accounts, similar to those in the United Kingdom, to mobilise savings of small investors. The outstanding success of the recent Commonwealth Bank float indicates the potential here.

For my own part, I would have hoped that Cabinet would have explored even bolder initiatives such as the phased abolition of all or part of payroll tax in the traded goods sector. I know we are talking about large sums here but, at this time of high unemployment, surely we must be taking a second look at what is in reality a tax on employment. The phased abolition of payroll tax would give a boost to the competitiveness of our exporters and would have the dual effect of creating jobs and reducing the current account deficit. To achieve this end we may have to forgo reductions in income tax or even increase some income and company taxes. However, this may well be the price Australians have to pay for jobs.

Another initiative we could be examining is legislation to require the superannuation funds to invest part of their massive liquidity in major job creating infrastructure projects. Any concerns about trustees' liability or returns to beneficiaries could be met by the Government guaranteeing the return. The sorts of major projects I am talking about are the construction of Sydney's second airport, the modernisation of our sea ports and major rail and road projects. Such projects not only are highly labour intensive but also use Australian materials and greatly enhance our export potential.

The response to all these sorts of propositions is, of course, already to be read in the Treasurer's Budget Speech. The Budget was framed under the dark cloud of fear that any expansion of our economy could see the loss of the undoubted gains in the areas of controlling inflation and the current account deficit. The Treasurer justified this frugality on the basis that it was maintaining the underlying integrity of the Budget. What that amounted to in practice was the application, in the economic review committee of Cabinet, of the unreasonably inflexible mechanism of insisting that any new or increased outlays had to be offset by reductions in existing programs. A mild expansionary Budget, paid for by some tax increases and a larger deficit, might have been a courageous political step and no doubt would have offended our political opponents and the right wing members of the business community who are demanding billions of dollars of cuts in welfare spending. It is a far easier alternative to wearing the wrath of one million unemployed and their families at the next election.

While I am talking about electoral wrath, I would like to turn to the matter of the proposed changes to Medicare which have been given the thumbs down by all peak welfare and health organisations in Australia, including ACOSS, the Consumer Health Forum, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Australia Consumers Association and the Australian Council on the Ageing. It has also been bagged by the AMA and State health Ministers, who are concerned about its effect on hospital casualty services. It has also received a vote of no confidence from the architect of Medicare, John Deeble, who has spent the last 24 years developing, introducing and administering our national health scheme.

The welfare groups saw the change as a consumer tax on the sick and the first nail in the coffin of Medicare. Deeble described it as `ill advised, unjustified and ultimately destructive'. The two great principles underpinning Medicare, those of a universal health service and bulkbilling, are certainly compromised by co-payments. Medicare was designed to treat all Australians equally. The proposal creates a charity class of beneficiaries on pensions or benefits. Ironically, it was the Minister's own consultant, Professor Richardson, who, in his strategy paper, argued strongly against using co-payments to reduce patient demand. The Professor found their effect to be negligible in deterring patients from seeking medical attention and irrelevant in preventing over-servicing.

Bulkbilling has, of course, been the key to Australia controlling health costs and making Medicare work. Deeble's expert view is that only the 24-hour clinics can sustain the almost 20 per cent reduction in fees without collecting the $3.50 and predicts that the rest will abandon bulkbilling altogether. That is a frightening prospect for the tens of thousands of pensioners and beneficiaries in my electorate. Even at the scheduled fee levels, the gap for patient billed services ranges from $7 to $12. The spectre of gap insurance immediately raises its ugly head. The aspect of the proposal, however, that most sticks in my craw is the arguments proffered to justify the decision.

The problem the Minister is seeking to address is a potential blow-out in the cost--and I emphasise `potential' because there has been no blow-out in the cost of the scheme to this point in time--created by an oversupply of doctors, some 5,000 more doctors than are required at this very moment, with more coming out of the universities every day. In other words, it is the supply, not the demand, side of the Medicare economy that is in crisis. Doctors' fees are not capped and doctors can maintain their incomes against the natural market forces in an oversupply situation by either increasing fees or overservicing their patients.

The Minister's solution is a package which starts out by doing what Professor Richardson said should not be done, and that is punishing patients by imposing the $3.50 fee. Why should the sick pay for the sins of the medical profession? The Minister says, of course, that we should look at the whole package, and that includes future negotiations with the AMA to alter practice patterns and fee structures. The AMA has already rejected that proposal, and it is looking as though the Minister will be left with a one-legged program.

The Minister rejects the ACTU suggestion that if savings need to be made then the levy should be increased. He argues forcefully that this does not address the fundamental problem of oversupply of doctors. He also rejects the option of capping doctors' fees and licensing the supply of doctors as unconstitutional. There would be no sticky constitutional problems if the States cooperated in a price fixing and practice rationalisation scheme. New South Wales, of course, would present a difficulty for any Federal-State cooperative scheme. However, the attitude of the High Court has changed a great deal since the old civil conscription cases, and it may well be that the Minister's legal advice is based on outdated legal thinking.

Like John Deeble, I take no pleasure in criticising the Minister. I am glad that my Caucus has seen fit to have the issue reviewed by a special committee. I know that that committee will explore alternative means of achieving savings which will save Medicare and come to grips with the real problem of the supply of doctors and their fee structures.

The only other matter that I wish to comment on in this Medicare context is the Minister's vociferous denial that the $3.50 patient charge has been introduced to pay for the better cities program. The credibility problem for the Deputy Prime Minister is, of course, created by the well-publicised mechanism to maintain the underlying integrity of the Budget. It is no secret that all Ministers were told that the revenue for new programs had to be found within the existing portfolios budget. That meant either cutting existing programs or raising fees and charges.

Looking at the measures table at page 3.62 of the Budget Papers we see the effect on outlays of the revised Medicare arrangement as a reduction of $164m rising to $700m by 1994. It is the only substantial reduction other than pathology benefits of $134m, a total of $834m. The only substantial increase in outlays in the Minister's portfolio is the better cities program, which is estimated to cost $800m over five years. In other words, the major cut in outlays just happens to equal the major increase in outlays and fiscal integrity is thereby maintained.

To complete my contribution, I would like to make a few remarks about the better cities program itself. The major criticisms that have been directed at it are, firstly, that the funding is inadequate and, secondly, that there is absolutely no detail of the projects it is proposed to fund.

The Minister quite properly points out that there is always a substantial lead time in launching such a scheme and $56m is a reasonable sum to get the program under way. However, the funding for the scheme is still only $800m over five years or about $160m per year. The Government's vision for the scheme is to form a partnership between State, local and Federal governments to change the cities of our nation by making capital grants to improve their infrastructure. We are talking about things like better roads, hospitals, housing and community facilities.

I do not want to sound like a dog in the manger but in city infrastructure terms $160m around Australia is peanuts. That is the cost of the new Glebe Island Bridge in Sydney--a relatively minor Sydney road project. It is about the same cost as the Gore Hill diversion on the Warringah freeway and is but a drop in the bucket of many other road projects. It would not build one modern city hospital; it would build about 800 new houses in the inner city of Sydney--only 800. I point out here that this Government has cut funding to the States for housing purposes by 47 per cent since I was Minister for Housing in New South Wales. The new program goes nowhere near redressing that loss. I passionately believe that such a program should exist but we should be looking at a much larger infusion of capital into infrastructure if it is to be meaningful.

In summary, it is fair to say that I am disappointed that the Government did not take the advice of our national conference and give unemployment the priority it so obviously deserved in the Budget. That omission has unfortunately given the talentless, policy bereft Opposition a powerful issue with which to beat the Government about the head. The way forward seems to be the evolution of an exciting, progressive yet economically responsible industry policy that will give the jobless hope for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to raise the issue of funding and the future of the ABC as indicated by the Budget. The 1991-92 Budget provides total outlays for the ABC of $502m. This is significantly less than the previous year's actual outlays for the ABC totalling $513.5m, even taking into account the fact that the ABC will not be required to pay the efficiency dividend of 1.25 per cent of allocation which the Government is requiring from its other agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: For a decade and a half the ABC has been subject to a continued round of funding restrictions, staff cuts, rationalisations and reorganisations. The decline of the ABC began under the Fraser Government and, except for the first two Hawke Budgets, it has continued ever since. In 1988 the ABC's funding was below its 1975 level in real terms and also as a proportion of total government outlays.

The move to triennial funding of the ABC from 1988 was expected to improve the organisation's position. But due to political sleight of hand by the Department of Finance and by Treasury, increases in annual funding were not fully indexed. As a result, the ABC lost about $32m in real terms in the first two years of triennial funding.

The ABC is one of our country's most important public institutions and perhaps the most significant Australian cultural organisation. It began operating in 1932 and within a year the country was benefiting from a touring ABC band and ABC schools broadcasts. Drama and music programs followed. The overseas service opened in 1939 and later developed into Radio Australia, with an audience three times greater than our whole population.

ABC correspondents reported the Second World War from battle zones and by 1945 Australia's farmers were benefiting from the ABC's rural broadcasts. The ABC gave us the Argonauts, the symphony orchestras, Blue Hills and Four Corners. More recently it gave us a blow by blow reporting, unmatched by any Australian commercial network, of the momentous changes in the USSR. More importantly, the ABC, through its national radio and television broadcasts, has provided a distinctive Australian voice heard throughout the country and is helping to build national unity and identity.

Criticisms can be levelled at any organisation, and the ABC is not immune. For example, during my recent visits to Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia, I could not help noticing the tendency of the ABC to play up to the parochial sentiment that seems to be rampant in those States.

The ABC is also vulnerable to criticism on the question of accountability. There have been calls for the organisation to be made more accountable to an independent watchdog. Commercial broadcasters have complained that, while they are subject to the discipline of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the ABC is not. There may be a case for bringing ABC television and radio under the same regulatory regime as the commercials as far as broadcasting standards are concerned, although the ABC, for obvious reasons, could not be required to meet the same media ownership requirements as private interests and it could not be subject to the ultimate sanction of licence forfeiture.

It needs to be conceded that the ABC already has a form of independent watchdog in its board. Of the nine members of the board, seven are independent of the organisation and free to take an objective and critical view of its activities. However, I share the view of the majority of Australians who have a high regard for its services, both radio and television. I also agree with Tom Molomby when he says in his recent book on the ABC Is there a Moderate on the Roof? that the ABC is now suffering from `the deprecation of public institutions which have been so fashionable in recent times'. I think that the ABC is far too important to become another victim of the extremists and the nineteenth century free market fundamentalists who are laying siege to much of Australian society at the moment.

A 1990 ANOP survey of community attitudes to the ABC's role, image and position showed that, despite the unrelenting attacks on it by its competitors, politicians and interest groups, the organisation continues to be well regarded and its services highly valued. The survey found that the ABC enjoys widespread goodwill, with 63 per cent seeing a need for its radio and 83 per cent believing that its television provides programs needed by the community. It found that the ABC is seen as quite distinct from commercial stations and that the main perceived differences are its non-commercial style and absence of advertising, and its strength as a news and information provider.

The ANOP survey exploded the myth that the ABC has a narrowly based, elitist audience, finding that in any week it reaches 50 per cent of radio listeners and 83 per cent of television viewers. Most Australians in all demographic groups and in all parts of the country listen to ABC radio or watch ABC television for some period every week.

The erosion of the ABC's funding has forced obvious cuts in services. From 1985 to 1989 staffing levels fell by 10 per cent. In 1989 transmissions by television on Saturday and Sunday mornings were cut, there were cuts to the second regional radio network affecting country centres, particularly in New South Wales, and restrictions on the proposed expansion of JJJ FM youth radio station. Not so obvious was the redirection of ABC staff and resources from production and services into commercial activities in order to make up income shortfalls.

Cuts in ABC funding forced it in 1990 to reduce its schools programs, which have been a valuable resource for teachers. The children's TV department is now looking to State education departments to fund its continued operation. More recently, we have seen wholesale retrenchments of ABC program makers. Managing Director David Hill said on a recent morning program that a further 161 program makers were to go. As the ranks of the program makers are being mercilessly thinned, the ABC is dramatically increasing the ranks of its senior management. We have had a 48 per cent increase in managers over the last three years, and no doubt massive salary increases.

In another move against program makers, management has announced its intention to put them on short term contracts, which seem to be designed to encourage creative staff to find another line of work. How many people in the work force would accept 12-month contracts? Those who support cutting back its funding argue that it is inefficient. Credible conclusions were able to be drawn from studies carried out in 1988 by media analysts Mervin Smyth and Associates. These studies showed that the cost of ABC TV per viewer was in line with the costs of commercial broadcasters. The ABC Radio National daily cost per listener was then about 10c, and this was for a service providing a range and quantity of information comparable with a metropolitan newspaper which, at the time, cost about 70c per reader per day to produce.

It is hard to escape the conclusion that the Government--or at least influential sections of it--hopes that by cutting the ABC's budget the organisation will have to turn to commercial advertising and program sponsorship to survive. While this is at present excluded by its charter, legislation of course to allow advertising and sponsorship could no doubt be introduced in the right political climate. In 1989, the then media spokesman for the Opposition, Senator Alston, confirmed that Opposition policy favoured program sponsorship. The Opposition's current spokesman on communications, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), has been a little more circumspect. However, in July this year he spoke approvingly of the Government's cutting back ABC funding. The honourable member for Bass suspects that a public broadcaster's role in the future may be more limited than now and that some element of privatisation is possible.

Champions of the ABC's commercialisation are also to be found in its senior management. Michael Shrimpton of ABC TV in May last year suggested to a meeting of the Pacific Rim Co-production Association that the ABC was moving in a more commercial direction similar to TV New Zealand and was considering spot advertising. He said that the principal avenue for survival of public broadcasters would be international co-productions.

There is some evidence that ABC management is introducing commercial sponsorship by stealth. A good example was the ABC TV broadcast on 14 April 1990 of its regular Horizon program. This one dealt with an expedition financed by the Australian Geographic magazine to restore Mawson's hut in the Antarctic. It included sequences showing an interminably long chase through ice floes by men in two rubber inflatables. The camera was mounted on the rear boat in such a way that as it filmed the front boat--which was so far away as to be barely visible--viewers were able to study at leisure the Esso and BBC Hardware logos prominently displayed on the bow of the rear boat. The credits at the end of the program dwelt on the 14 sponsors. Errol Simper, a journalist with the Australian who contacted management for a comment was told that the program had not broken any guidelines concerning advertising and sponsorship because Esso, BBC Hardware and other companies mentioned were Australian Geographic sponsors, not the ABC's. This shows a readiness on the part of management to flout its own Act of Parliament.

The introduction of commercial advertising to the ABC must be opposed. It is a little like, I suppose, airline interests expressing sympathy for the residents around Kingsford-Smith Airport, but even Senator Alston, after a visit to New Zealand, described the introduction of advertising to the national broadcaster as a disaster. Barnett and Docherty, authors of Public Broadcasting in Transition, confirm that dependence on advertising has resulted in a narrowing of the range and type of programming from New Zealand's public broadcaster.

Sponsorship involves a much closer identification with the program on the part of the sponsor than does advertising. The sponsor pays over a substantial amount of money to support the production and presentation of a particular program. In return, the sponsor's support is acknowledged in the credits. The influence of sponsorship on programming could be more insidious than advertising; it provides the opportunity to influence in a direct way the programs that would be made, when they are shown and editorial judgments.

Sudden and capricious withdrawals of sponsorship occur in the United States as a routine matter, such as when General Electric ditched Inside Story, an Emmy award winning current affairs program. A major problem with sponsorship would be the programs that are not made because they present ideas that corporate sponsors find unattractive. Unsponsored programs would remain as no more than a good idea or, if made, would be relegated to marginal viewing times so as not to affect revenue. Sponsorship cannot be seen as an inoffensive compromise which the ABC and its audience would be churlish to reject.

It has been suggested that sensitive areas of broadcasting such as news and current affairs could be exempted from sponsorship schemes. This was the thrust of the Evans paper in 1987. But it would be impossible to insulate these programs from sponsor influence. If large corporations are major sponsors of the arts and sports programs, how could their influence on the organisation fail to spread to the current affairs area if, say, The Investigators or Four Corners embarked on a damaging investigation of one of the sponsor corporation's dealings? We cannot fence off these essential activities of the ABC from influence. Pressure would be felt by the producers of these programs, from others or self-imposed, from inside the organisation or outside, direct or indirect, subtle and otherwise, to alter their editorial stance to be realistic or even to abandon some aspect of their investigations.

Pressure on the ABC to take a particular line in public affairs has always been a serious problem. During the 1960s and 1970s there were repeated political attacks on Four Corners. Even when outsiders have not intervened, middle level ABC managers, anticipating trouble, have tried to impose a form of self-censorship. Allan Ashbolt coined the term `the pre-emptive buckle' for it. How much more pre-emptive buckling will there be within the ABC's management when the pressure is closely linked to the organisation's funding through corporate sponsorships?

The 1990 ANOP survey of public opinion, which I referred to earlier, found that the Australian community is opposed to both sponsorship and advertising. It found that 47 per cent were opposed to sponsorship as against 39 per cent in favour, while advertising was opposed by an overwhelming 81 per cent. Opposition to sponsorship and advertising was found to have increased in the 10 years since ANOP conducted a similar survey for the Dix Committee of Review of the ABC in 1980.

What financial benefit can the ABC hope for in return for running the risks of corporate sponsorship? On the basis of an ABC estimate--made before the recession--it would be about $20m a year. That is hardly a worthwhile amount in an annual budget of $500m when compared with the massive disadvantages.

Commercial broadcasters' program policies are necessarily built on maximising audiences in order to attract the maximum advertising revenue. Commercial broadcasters have no choice but to concentrate on programs which, regardless of their quality, cultural or artistic values and merit, have a strong appeal to mass audiences. Public broadcasting is necessary and desirable precisely because it does not need to compromise on quality and range the way the commercial broadcasters must. The existence of public broadcasting requires that broadcasting be more than a commercial commodity. The ABC, because it does not rely on advertising revenue for its existence, can and does produce programs that are innovative, entertaining, educational, controversial and analytical--programs that explore those areas of our experience that are of special interest, that are important, but which may not in all cases be commercial.

The trend to co-productions is also a great concern. A significant part of the programming is already made under co-production agreements where the ABC either buys the program from the makers or enters into an arrangement to make the program jointly, with the ABC taking rights to broadcast it under licence. With licence fees around $50,000 and the production cost of a one-hour documentary at $250,000, co-productions offer the ABC a way out of its financial difficulties, and some fine material has been broadcast under this system. But as the current management policies of the ABC are reducing the number of in-house program makers, the ABC will rely increasingly on co- productions. Australia is a small market and the makers of co-productions will have to market their products overseas.

The ABC will be broadcasting fewer and fewer programs with Australian themes and more with either a transnational or mainly overseas appeal. The organisation will then find it difficult to honour one of the most important commitments in its statutory charter, which is to provide broadcasting programs and television programs that contribute to a sense of national identity.

The importance of public broadcasting has been reaffirmed in the United Kingdom. Even under Margaret Thatcher, England's answer to Genghis Khan, BBC funding has increased and the Peacock inquiry into the future of the BBC concluded:

We are not persuaded by the claim of advertisers that it would never be in their interest to influence program content. There would certainly be a risk that controversial drama, critical consumer programs, current affairs programs and satirical programs which challenge conventional attitudes and prejudice would not be supported by them.

I hope we never go down the road of public broadcasting in the United States, where in 1979 the Carnegie Commission said that corporate sponsorship had undoubtedly skewed the whole total schedule and where even the best public broadcasting services are battling to survive. In Boston, one of the USA's leading public broadcasters, WGBH, has had to constantly beg the public for money just to stay afloat.

It is a depressing irony that at a time when commercial broadcasting is in total disarray the ABC is being urged to follow its example. Commercial stations, both radio and television, have been grossly overvalued, owners are deeply in debt and the prospects for some organisations are gloomy. The crisis has spilled over into the advertising industry, producing instability there.

In the current shambles that is the broadcasting industry, the ABC is continuing to do its job, providing a trusted news and information service, reflecting on many aspects of Australian life and culture and doing it intelligently and with style. Australians overwhelmingly want to keep it. They want it to continue as an identifiable broadcasting voice for the nation and not just as another commercial station. They want it strong and independent, but they will not have it if the ABC becomes dependent on commercial advertising or sponsorship for its continued existence; nor will they have it if it is allowed to degenerate into an organisation with no creative capacity, an organisation peopled by administrators buying in programs from outside.

With no public mandate, great efforts appear to have been made to change the role and nature of the ABC. Funds have been cut. School programs, rural services, local sport and other services have steadily disappeared. Australian content has been inexorably reduced. Increases in joint productions and a relentless drive to corporate sponsorships and advertising have resulted in a steady attrition of independence and integrity.

The Hawke Government has established a pattern of censorship by political pressure, which does not bode well for the future. The ABC is one of Australia's most important national institutions and providers of information. Radical change of the sort now under way should not happen without a public mandate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Almost imperceptibly within the community of debate there is a slowly changing attitude to issues that affect our economic future. This has to be seen against the background of the 1980s which saw the worldwide ascendancy of neo- conservatism. Springing essentially from populist anti-big government groups and explicitly in favour of nurturing wealth, neo- conservatism found its most powerful intellectual voice in George Gilder when he said in Wealth and Poverty:

SPEECH.PARA: To help the poor and the middle classes, one must cut the taxes of the rich.

It was also found in Wanniski, who in The Way the World Works popularised the Laffer curve and the notion that tax cuts were essential for economic progress. By the mid 1980s, neo-laissez faire leaders dominated the major First World governments: Reagan in the United States, Thatcher in the United Kingdom and Nakasone in Japan, each implementing the politics of deregulation, privatisation and smaller government. Predictably, the rich got richer and inequality grew.

The wealth shift represented by the 1980s has only recently begun to be comprehensively documented, most vividly and controversially in the United States by Kevin Phillips, whose work The Politics of Rich and Poor, subtitled Wealth in the American Electorate in the Reagan Aftermath, reached second place in the New York Times national best seller list in August of 1990. Phillips said that by the middle of Reagan's second term, official data had begun to show that America's broadly defined rich, the top half of one per cent of the US population, had never been richer. Even adjusted for inflation, the number of millionaires had doubled between the late 70s and the late 80s. Meanwhile the number of billionaires, according to Forbes Magazine, went from a handful in 1981 to 26 in 1986 and 49 in 1987. No parallel upsurge of riches has ever been seen since the late nineteenth century, the era of the Vanderbilts, Morgans and Rockefellers. This was at a time when the Census Bureau in the United States reported in the 1984-88 period that the median net worth of US households--that is, assets minus debts--had decreased by 4 per cent.

Phillips concluded that, when one remembers that the Forbes 400 had greatly increased their net worth during this period, pulling up the national total, and with the top one per cent not far behind, this only underscored what was happening to the average family. A `liberal' in the United States sense of the word would probably say, `Trickle down wasn't trickling'.

There have been similar processes at work in our own country. I would not accept that Labor deserves Phillips' cruel gibe at the Democrats in the United States that, `When wealth is in fashion, National Democrats have gone along', but there is no doubt that the Hawke Labor Government and the governments that immediately preceded it were themselves influenced very strongly by the neo-conservatism that was so fashionable amongst world leaders and all First World economies. We saw implemented in this country a number of programs, supported by the Opposition, similar to policies as implemented in the United States. Rates of tax fell dramatically and were followed by a shift of wealth from those on middle and low incomes to the rich. One should simply note the following as facts: the top rate of tax has fallen from 65c to 49c, company tax has fallen from 65c to 37c and, coupled with this, we have introduced dividend imputation, which has concentrated the share of wealth held by that small proportion of the community which participates in the stock market.

In addition, we implemented the policies of deregulation although, in our case I think it is fair to say, with a far greater degree of care than was evidenced in the United States, where there was a near-fatal collapse of the `thrifts' banking which were the repositories of large amounts of national banking deposits. In Australia's case, we also saw major difficulties with some of our financial institutions, partly attributable to the difficulties of management unused to the kind of deregulatory pressures that were then being placed upon them.

Continuing through the period of the 1980s were intellectual attacks upon the very fundamental nature of equity, on the progressive tax system--arguments that are still being currently advanced by the Opposition such as that we should move further away from principle, that is, of equitable distribution of the resources of our community, and down the track of a consumption tax. Anyone with any sympathy for Labor and its traditions finds himself crying out with Peter Walsh, who said:

I may be, as David Clarke alleged, an old socialist, but for many decades vast numbers of people who were not socialists or even Labor voters believed in a progressive income tax. Has our society become so morally corrupted by Gordon Gekkos that it can no longer believe that?

I will leave that question hanging in the air because essentially at the next election that will be an issue that the Australian public will have to resolve: has our society been so corrupted by the attitudes of Gordon Gekko that it would fall for what the Opposition is putting forward by way of a further redistribution downwards from those on middle income to the rich?

In my contribution to the Budget debate I now want to look briefly at a number of issues which need to attract the attention of our government which is facing a difficult economic period. I believe that there is a need for a paradigm shift. There is no doubt that there has been a concentration of inequality in Australia similar to that which has happened in the United States. I have on the Notice Paper a motion asking that there be established an inquiry into wealth in this country to give us the raw data we need to be able to make some definitive judgments in that regard.

We are one of the few countries which does not have such information available to its policy makers. The United States does and so does Britain and most European countries--but not Australia. The best evidence that we have about the pattern of wealth distribution is the work of Professor Dilnot, who estimated, that if we look at the distribution of household wealth in our country--he was estimating it in 1986--the bottom 30 per cent of wealth holders have negative wealth. In other words, they owe more than they own. The top one per cent of wealth holders in this country--that is, the percentile 99 to 100--have in their hands 19.7 per cent of Australia's net wealth. The top 10 per cent have 55.2 per cent. We thus have a concentration of wealth in this country which parallels that which has developed in the United States through the implementation of neo-conservatist politics.

However, there is a substantial difference between the implementation of Reagan's politics in the United States and the course pursued by the Australian Government. The difference is that, even with the dominance of the neo-conservatist view of economic imperatives, the Hawke Government never abandoned a fundamental commitment to fairness.

By contrast the previous speaker, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), pointed out some of the detrimental effects that occurred in Great Britain at the same time as these macro-economic policies were being implemented by Margaret Thatcher. We heard earlier in Question Time of the way in which unemployment rose in Great Britain from one million to three million. The GDP of Great Britain was dramatically slashed as a result of these policies, at the same time benefiting the rich and the wealth holders.

In Australia however, we introduced novel policies which held back the worst features of neo-conservatism, Thatcherism and Reaganism. For example, Labor introduced the family allowance supplement, a program which provides vital income support for low wage working Australians. We were the first government ever to recognise that our responsibility does not end with those who are direct beneficiaries of government pensions and benefits.
We looked beyond that to ensure that those who get only low incomes, who earn relatively small wages, yet have families to support, can get a share of the Government's support.

I believe the family allowance supplement will be seen in decades to come as one of the landmark social policy initiatives of the last 25 years. At the same time, Labor maintained a national health scheme--Medicare--which was fair and universal. None of the other First World countries that we have spoken of were able to do that. For example there are some 30 million Americans uninsured at the moment, including, paradoxically, some of the middle class. They are finding the burden of household insurance for health to be almost unbearable unless they have it paid for by their employers.

At the same time, as well as the family allowance supplement and Medicare, Labor introduced policies to ensure the burden of old age could be supported. We have altered a scheme which was previously only taxpayer supported to one which will be largely paid for through superannuation--necessary given the fact that, in the future, instead of five working Australians supporting one retiree there will be only three.

We have recognised the need for greater self-reliance in terms of superannuation. That has been built into Labor Budgets, not just on this occasion, but in accord arrangements that we have made with the trade unions in the past five years. That is a further major difference between this Government and those that I have mentioned--the Reagan, Thatcher and Nakasone governments. This Government worked out arrangements with the trade union movement, designed to facilitate the maintenance of real living standards--not real wages, but real living standards--of all in the community.

Finally, Labor has maintained and increased the value of pensions to those who are in most need. Today, the value of the Australian pension is 26.4 per cent of gross male average weekly earnings which is at the highest real level since 1949. These are very substantial achievements at a time when almost every government was dominated by what I believe was an over-reaction to the winds of the economic imperatives which were so strongly advanced by the neo-conservatives. There is a real mood now for a paradigm shift. Indeed some of the theories which drove policy making in the United States, Great Britain and in our own country are now almost a cheap joke.

Who will remember the Laffer curve--the argument that reducing taxes would mean greater returns to Treasury? Laffer simply was proved incorrect. Who now recalls the `double deficit' theory--the argument that slashing government expenditure would improve our balance of trade? It is a late, unlamented theory. Who now remembers the J-curve? One by one the elements of the neo- conservative ideology have been discredited.

Our Government was caught up to a degree with some of those ideas. What government of its time could not have been? It was simply the mood of the times. Governments which resisted were swept from office. There is no doubt that there was a huge populist demand for lower taxes and less government. The argument that government was not the answer, but was the problem, was persuasive and attractive. Our Government was drawn into a number of measures which one might describe as neo-conservative.

At the same time, as many commentators have properly noted, we tamed the worst excesses of Thatcherism and Reaganism. We drew some of the strengths from it, we implemented elements of it--not all to the great benefit of the Australian economy, as things transpired--but we also consistently sought to act to protect the best interests of Australian working people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Fairness.

—-Fairness was the most important consideration, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, who is at the table, indicates. Now we must make a very substantial shift. This Government has to address new issues such as industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The crucial issues for us now are to confront what have always been the fundamentals--not the theories, but the real question of what Australia makes and sells, what Australia can export, manufacture and sustain. What services, what opportunities, what intellectual opportunities do we have for growth in this country? We must be continually reminded of that. We have the strength of Barry Jones in his work in both the Ministry and in the back bench committee which he now chairs so well to remind us.

In contrast to this, the Opposition is still stuck in the past mouthing the rhetoric of the 1980s. It is still in `slash and burn' mode. It is still advocating less government and the reduction of services to the community. It is still in a mode which would take more from the community and transfer the benefits to the rich. One can see this in the Opposition's commitment to abolishing capital gains taxes and its commitment to a consumption tax.

Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m. Mr KERR--So at this crucial point in time we face a paradigm shift. One only needs to look at the literature emerging from the United States and Great Britain. Everywhere now we see revisionism, apostasy and a recognition that the events of the 1980s, the bonfire of the vanities, the period of greed and bust, must be repudiated and a new language of politics developed.

Labor in Australia has never been a victim of ideology. We were influenced, certainly through the 1980s, by the dominant views which were current in all First World economies, but were never totally the prisoner of those views. I made the point earlier about the way in which Labor protected fundamental values and fairness throughout that decade, notwithstanding the dominance of neo-conservatism.

We do however face an ideological turning point now. The Liberal Party on the Opposition benches is seeking to put before the public its prescriptions for a repeat of the 1980s. On the other hand, Labor is seeking to move forward, unblinkered by neo-conservative, new right ideological prescription, looking instead to building on the fundamentals, looking to make sure that our economy can revitalise its manufacturing base, provide properly for the retirement of its elderly, and ensure that its sick can be cared for and its needy protected.

I conclude by saying that the next election will certainly be the first time for many years that such a clear ideological gulf will be apparent, because the Opposition is still locked firmly into policies which increasingly throughout the world have been discredited and abandoned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to participate in what is commonly known as the Budget debate. The matter that I am raising again tonight is one that I am forced to raise because I have a private member's Bill before the House with very distinct provisions in it to come to grips with an industry that is out of control. I am talking about the abortion industry in this country. Therefore, I am devoting the majority of my speech to this very concerning aspect of an allocation in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Abortion has been one of the most controversial moral, social, political, legal and medical issues of the 1970s and the 1980s, not just in Australia but in other developed countries with which we often compare ourselves, for example, Canada, New Zealand, Great Britain and the United States. It is impossible to go through life without establishing an attitude on the subject at a personal level, either in our own human relationships between husband and wife or in the attitudes that we as mothers and fathers convey to our children in their formative years. For many people abortion is the major issue of public importance facing Australia today. Yet, surprisingly, if we look at abortion as a major issue of public policy in Australia, it has been virtually neglected by us in our capacity as national legislators.

It seems as if we have invested all our energy in attempts, important as they may be, to solve problems involving such subjects as interest rates, imports, whales, the Antarctic, woodchipping, tertiary amalgamations or the ozone layer but have run out of energy and compassion for the unborn human life destroyed in the abortion process.

No-one can suggest that our Parliament has devoted an excess of its time to the subject of abortion. Quite the contrary. Of all the current issues of community concern, abortion must be the most neglected. On the other hand, not one year passes in the United States Congress or Senate without a major debate on some aspect of the abortion subject. There are also debates in congressional committees about public funding of abortion, international aid schemes which might involve support for abortion, and family planning projects which might be interwoven with abortion. Even the views about life issues expressed by nominees for vacancies on the United States Supreme Court are canvassed. The same capacity for debate on abortion, but certainly not the same opportunity, exists in this, our Australian Federal Parliament.

When are we going to debate the fact that the draft United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Australia signed in August 1990, has reduced the importance of its application to the child before birth, in contrast to the 1959 Declaration on the Rights of the Child? When are we going to debate the fact that Australian aid grants are funding international projects, the purpose of which is to develop the new RU-486 abortifacient drug and the new anti-hCG abortifacient vaccine? When are we going to have a say on Australia's continuing funding of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities which, by way of contrast, the United States Government has refused to fund since September 1985 because of its involvement in the Chinese population program, which includes forced abortions?

When are we going to examine the Commonwealth's indirect subsidisation of abortions performed on public patients in State hospitals through its general underpinning of hospital finances through section 23 of the Health Insurance Act? How can any Federal parliamentarian, in the face of just these few examples, roll out the catchcry `But abortion is a State matter' or that other totally irrelevant abdication of responsibility, `Leave it to the courts'?

Of all the ways in which the subject of abortion demands scrutiny by the national Parliament, that aspect which is most urgent, involves the greatest expenditure of money and is vehemently opposed by a significant section of the community is the continued funding of abortions through Medicare. Federal Parliament was never asked to vote on the original introduction of the abortion items into the medical benefits schedule. They were slipped into administrative practice under the cover of darkness.

The Bill that I have put before Parliament on an earlier occasion represents the first legislative attempt in years to correct this wrong. The main abortion item--No. 6469--was originally identified as item 5570. It was introduced into the medical benefits schedule on 10 April 1974 by way of statutory rule No. 53 of 1974. It seems almost as if it sponsors one of the statutory rules which contained the specific abortion provision in place before the next election. Either by coincidence or design they were signed into effect by the Governor-General on the same day--10 April 1974--that the Prime Minister announced a double dissolution election. The next day Parliament was dissolved. A double dissolution had been in the offing publicly since at least 4 April, when the Prime Minister had threatened one.

The important statutory rules were not tabled in Federal Parliament until three months later, on 9 July 1974, which was the first sitting day of the new Parliament after the double dissolution election held on 18 May 1974. This method of introducing a significant policy change, hidden within an administrative law change on the eve of an election, produced the practical effect of ensuring that it escaped effective legislative scrutiny. Neither its initial introduction, nor the later renumbering of item 5570 to 6469 by way of statutory rules No. 48 of 1975 and the introduction of items 274 and 275 on 1 October 1976, were debated or subject to a vote in either House of the Parliament.

There is no record of any public announcement, either in the Parliament or outside about this most significant development in 1974. There is no mention of it in the index to Hansard for that year, for either House. There is only one reference in the clippings and press statement files held by the Parliamentary Library for the subject headings of `Abortion', `Health Australia', `Department of Health', and `Minister for Health', or among the Department of Social Security set of clippings. At that time the health function was divided between two Ministers. The sole reference is in an article by a prominent New South Wales pro-abortionist that was published one month after the regulations had been promulgated. It indicates, in retrospect, that at least she knew that abortion had been listed as a distinct item for the first time, and I quote what she said:

The question of the payment of medical benefits for abortions was debated in Federal Parliament in March 1979 and, as a result of the vote taken, medical benefits continue to be payable for abortions performed in accordance with the law of a State or Territory. The Federal Government has no role in the enforcement of State laws. It is the responsibility of the States to ensure that the State laws covering abortions are enforced. The legal and ethical responsibility for determining medical need for any service rests with the individual medical practitioner operating within the framework or the relevant State or Territory law.

One could talk about extrinsic aids to interpretation--that is one of the best we have heard in a long while. The original Lusher motion was not a motion to amend statutory regulations, nor did it represent a piece of legislation of any form--even less so did the Simon amendment to the Lusher motion represent legislation as we know it. They were declaratory resolutions of the House. Had the Lusher motion been adopted, I am sure that its supporters would have then found it necessary to follow up with a specific item of legislation to implement the measure. But the result of the vote was good enough for the purpose of those bureaucrats who wanted to justify continued funding of abortions.

Despite the many occasions when bureaucrats have completely ignored declaratory motions adopted by the Parliament, on this occasion they clothed the successful Simon amendment with the aura of legislative permanence. Now that we know what has been the practical result of what happened 10 years ago in this House, inaction on our part will represent a de facto endorsement of the path chosen by the bureaucracy. There can be no danger involved in attempting, and even failing on this initial occasion, because failure will not introduce something new--I am referring, of course, to my private member's Bill.

Even if one adopts the interpretation of the bureaucrats, purely for the purposes of analysis, one reaches the inevitable conclusion that the Commonwealth has a responsibility to act. It is as clear as crystal. The bureaucrats say that it is the responsibility of the States to ensure that the State laws covering abortions are enforced. But most of the States are not enforcing their own laws on abortion. In the largest State, New South Wales, abortion prosecutions were repeatedly `no billed' by successive State Attorneys-General until the Crown Solicitors got the message: `Don't bother us with initiating cases in that sphere'.

When a community group attempted to obtain access to Medicare statistics as they related to individual doctors in New South Wales, so as to avoid initiating a stressful legal case based on an individual patient, and in order to prove that the very volume of abortions performed indicated that the doctors were abusing the law, the group was met with determined opposition before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court in a case which was spread over five years. They were opposed by the AMA, six doctors and two Sydney abortion clinics. The only ones who benefited was the phalanx of barristers and solicitors.

Some people say that it should be left to the courts, but the courts have been tried in this and in other instances and they do not provide a suitable opportunity for achieving human rights for the smallest and most defenceless human beings in our community. The law on abortion must be one of the last remaining subjects not to have been scrutinised by the High Court. In 1983 the de facto husband of a woman who was about to abort their baby applied to the High Court in Canberra for special leave to appeal but the application was dismissed by the Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs on 30 March 1983.

The very number of abortions subsidised by Medicare indicates that, contrary to the non- existence of any abortion on demand statute in Australia, Commonwealth funds are being used to underpin an abortion on demand industry in Australia. During 1990-91, abortionists were directly subsidised by the taxpayer for over 70,000 abortions, at a cost of $8.2m. This number was made up of 69,378 item 6469 abortions and 950 late term abortions--an increase of 10 per cent over the previous year--identified as item 274 and 275 claims. As well, there were other associated payments which netted the abortionists several million dollars more.

The latest figures, which were released to a Senate Estimates Committee, represent an increase of 4,800 over the previous year and an increase of 7,600 over the past two years. Any increase in the number of births has been almost offset by an increase in subsidised abortions. Abortions are increasing at a proportionately higher rate than births, which is a most disturbing development. In the years that the abortion items have been in the medical benefits schedule, the Australian taxpayer has subsidised in excess of 800,000 deliberate abortions, at a total cost of $50m which, when adjusted to constant prices, is equivalent to over $80m at today's values. The cumulative volume is so high that it is having an adverse effect on the age structure of our population. The ready availability of Commonwealth subsidised abortions has contributed to the projection that in the year 2031 the percentage of people over 50 years of age will reach almost 40 per cent, compared to 24.5 per cent today.

Medicare abortion funding is not just a one- off, occasional payment by the Commonwealth to underpin the Australian abortion industry in its provision of abortion on demand, which, as demonstrated by the volume alone, must represent a flagrant violation of the very precise and limited provisions of the abortion statutes in most States. The attitude of the medical abortionists is that the very act of asking for an abortion is sufficient reason for its performance by them. This is abortion on demand, and yet there is no statute in Australia of which I am aware that provides for abortion on demand.

This has led to the de facto implementation in the States--and its availability to ACT residents--of that which the McKenzie-Lamb Bill of 1973 sought to achieve, despite the overwhelming rejection of that Bill by this House 16 years ago, to the tune of 98 votes to 23 in a cross-Party vote. Federal Parliament, which then had responsibility for the ACT, quite unambiguously said that it did not want abortion on demand in the ACT, which is what that Bill was all about.

What resulted from the introduction of the Medicare abortion item less than 12 months after that decisive vote is that ACT residents were able to participate in abortion on demand, through Medicare's underpinning of the abortion industry, by just going into neighbouring New South Wales. How ironic that during the period 1973-75, when abortion on demand was being entrenched in the Australian community through its underwriting by the Medicare system, successful moves were being introduced in the Northern Territory, the ACT and in Victoria to abolish the death penalty.

This is the background to the private member's Bill that has been introduced under my name and which is called the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990. It is a very short Bill. Its essential purpose is to remove the current entitlement to payment of Medicare benefit in respect of certain medical services which result in an abortion. While it removes the current abortion on demand entitlement, it does not remove the relevant items from the medical benefits schedule on which the Medicare benefits are based. The Bill preserves an entitlement to the benefit where the procedure resulting in the abortion has been carried out to avert the death of the pregnant woman, and also in the case where it was carried out for a different purpose entirely and the doctor did not know and had no reasonable expectation that an abortion would occur.

There could be no other item numbers in the schedule under which benefits for abortion were claimed, but if that occurred it would have to involve illegality, deception or just plain confusion which, hopefully, would be identified by investigating officers in the Medicare fraud area. To specifically nominate these items in my Bill simply because they have a gynaecological connection could lead to unnecessary paperwork for claimants and doctors.
There are no punitive fines in the Bill that I have proposed. False certification in relation to any Medicare claims is already covered by existing section 128A of the principal Act.

On advice, I have allowed for an ample lead-in time of six months before the provisions of the Bill would come into effect. The general intention of the Bill has been known for months, since early May 1989 when it received nationwide publicity. The text of the Bill and the explanatory memorandum were also made available for public scrutiny before its first reading in Parliament.

Legislators have both a representative and a leadership role to undertake. We have to discern what is in the best interests of our nation, its people and its future generations. On some occasions we must lean heavily in the direction of those who can least afford to protect themselves. That is why we have a range of social benefits to support people in disadvantaged, crisis and emergency situations.

Australia's unborn lack a strong voice or voices with courage to act. They are under threat from interests that are loud and articulate and supported by powerful voices in the community and even in this Parliament. Australia's unborn are in an emergency situation. Somebody said that the most dangerous place for any individual to be in the world today is in its mother's womb--and that is pretty right. It is not their quality of life that is being threatened; it is their very right to existence. Representatives and leaders in the community and in this Parliament must lean heavily in the direction of those threatened, small, innocent, defenceless human beings before it is too late because this practice that we are engaged in allowing to take place in this country, and to which we are seemingly turning a blind eye, has the capacity to destroy this nation, no matter what else we do in other areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: - Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —- I would like to use the opportunity of this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to discuss the Commonwealth Government's financial commitment to the citizens of the Northern Territory. At the same time I want to expose the speciousness of the Opposition's claims in relation to its policies, particularly its intentions for fiscal policy and the proposition that it would cut government expenditure by around $3 billion, and the conundrum in which the Opposition, and indeed the Northern Territory Government, find themselves in supporting such a policy while at the same time supporting a consumption tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition masquerades as being caring and compassionate when its real intention--this was manifestly obvious from the presentations at Question Time yesterday and today of the various Ministers--is to boot the poor and the most disadvantaged people in our community. Of course, in many respects the people who are most disadvantaged in our community are some Northern Territory residents. As I have said, in the course of my address I will seek to expose the speciousness of the Opposition and the contradictions evident in the policies of the Opposition and the position that has been adopted by the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory.

Before preparing this speech, I consulted an atlas and found that my electorate office in Darwin is further from Canberra than the electorate office of any other member. The distance of the Northern Territory from Canberra and the southern cities has encouraged a tendency for some members of the Northern Territory community, especially those in the CLP Northern Territory Government, to approach the whole issue of the Northern Territory's relationship with the rest of Australia in terms of a hairy-chested `we can do without you' mentality.

In the Northern Territory, Canberra bashing has become an accepted part of the political debate; indeed, some people in the Northern Territory community have refined it to an art form. There is an extreme unwillingness on the part of the CLP Government, and indeed, I believe, the coalition parties, to accept that the Northern Territory economy is underpinned by the Commonwealth's financial commitment to Territorians. In its most absurd manifestation we even saw at the Premiers Conference earlier this year the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory say to other heads of government that he would be quite happy for the Northern Territory to cut off its dealings with southerners and join ASEAN. He may have said it tongue in cheek but I think it underscores the attitude that dominates the Northern Territory conservative parties.

I am a staunch believer in the need for Australia generally, and for the Northern Territory in particular, to strengthen its ties with South East Asia; but this kind of statement indicates a clear failure to come to grips with the economic environment that faces the Northern Territory. I suggest that what is needed for the Northern Territory political culture is for it to receive a touch of glasnost when it comes to discussing the Territory's financial relations with the Commonwealth.

The Northern Territory Government would have us believe that the Northern Territory has been victimised in funding from the Commonwealth. This argument, used perennially by Northern Territory Ministers to explain the latest round of Northern Territory Government spending cuts or blow-outs in debt, masks the true position of the Commonwealth-Northern Territory financial relations. Firstly, it needs to be recognised that, in spite of stagnant population growth, Commonwealth payments to the Northern Territory Government will rise in real terms in 1991-92. According to the Northern Territory Government's own Budget papers, total Commonwealth gross payments to the Northern Territory will be $1.066 billion this financial year--an increase of some 4.6 per cent. With the assumption of an inflation rate of 3 per cent, this represents a very good result for the Northern Territory in a time of economic restraint and it contrasts with what is being promised in policy prescriptions from the Opposition.

This is not the full story. General purpose funds to the Northern Territory will rise by 5.8 per cent to $817.6m, representing the Commonwealth's continuing commitment to the principles of fiscal equalisation. This formula represents a per capita allocation to the Northern Territory of $5,091 compared with a national average of $813--or 6.3 times that average. I understand that the Victorian and New South Wales governments--indeed, I have had some cause to make public comment about this--have some difficulties with the application of the principles of fiscal equalisation on the basis that they allege it discriminates against their own revenue needs.

It is my firm belief that for Federal relations in Australia to be equitable the principle of fiscal equalisation must be retained and I hope and expect that officials of the Northern Territory Government, currently in discussions with the States and the Commonwealth leading up to the November Special Premiers Conference, are actively promoting this view.

Another aspect of the ledger is the question of specific purpose funds. According to the bottom line of the Commonwealth Budget Papers, specific purpose payments to the Northern Territory will fall by 13.3 per cent to $249.1m in 1991-92. Rather predictably, the Northern Territory Government has latched on to this as evidence, apparently, of the Commonwealth's alleged lack of commitment to the Northern Territory. But the figures themselves tell a very different story and it is quite clear that, whilst there has been an overall reduction in the size of payments, there are extremely good reasons for it, and the Northern Territory Government understands that because it was directly involved in negotiations with the Commonwealth which led to those reductions.

The fall in specific purpose payments to the Territory is accounted for by four separate payments. BTEC funding is down from $24m to $15.5m as a result of the phasing down of a long term agreement with the Northern Territory involving the finalisation of the BTEC program. The power and water authority electricity subsidy is reduced by $10m from $30m to $20m--again as part of the phasing down of an agreement made with the Northern Territory Government which became operational from the 1989-90 Budget--all very predictable and all understood by the Northern Territory Government. The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement moneys were reduced from $40m to $26m--again as agreed to at the last CSHA meeting.

Road funding money in the amount of $15m now appears in another part of the Budget as a result of the Special Premiers Conference agreement to untie local road moneys. This demonstrates that the Northern Territory Government, despite its rhetoric, fully appreciates, does understand and was party to agreements with the Commonwealth Government which it understood and knew would lead to a reduction in specific purpose payments to the Northern Territory. If these planned and agreed changes are taken out of the funding equations--that is, if we look at the size of funds actually negotiated in this year's Special Premiers Conference and aggregated in the Commonwealth Budget Papers--we see that the Northern Territory position is actually quite healthy.

In fact, specific purpose payments to the Northern Territory, excluding these four types of payments--which, as I reiterate, were agreed to and understood certainly in the case of the CSHA and the PAWA money and the BTEC money--were parts of agreements made with the Northern Territory Government and were fully understood by it, as was, I might say, the decision by the Special Premiers Conference on road funding. In fact, specific purpose payments, as I have said, will rise by 5.2 per cent this financial year, if we exclude those four items. That is a very healthy situation, I am sure honourable members will agree.
As to per capita payments, in overall terms, Commonwealth net per capita payments to the Northern Territory in 1991-92 will be $6,086. This is four times higher than the national average of $1,545.

The point that needs to be understood from all of this is not just that the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory community have had the tangible support of this Government demonstrated through real budgetary outlays, but that this continues a long established pattern of support from the Hawke Labor Government. The Northern Territory has special needs dictated by distance, environment, a small population, and historical reality which have left many of its citizens, particularly Aboriginal people, amongst the poorest of the poor in our country and the people who would suffer most at the hands of a coalition government if, God forbid, one was ever elected into office.

The Hawke Labor Government has responded by recognising the realities of the Northern Territory and also the huge opportunities, by investing in the growth and future of the Territory. In 1982-83, the Commonwealth provided the Northern Territory Government with a level of approved funding that was 273 per cent higher per person than the national average. By 1990-91 under the Hawke Government, this figure had grown to be 293 per cent higher than the national average.

In indicating this support for the Hawke Government's financial support for the Northern Territory, I am not suggesting that the Government can rest on its laurels. Far from it. There remains a battle to be fought to ensure that the Northern Territory remains well funded, particularly as we enter crucial negotiations in future months regarding the future of federalism in Australia.

In addition to Commonwealth funding of the Northern Territory Government, it has especially in recent years made a number of large investment decisions in the Northern Territory for its own purposes that have greatly assisted the Northern Territory economy. In the 1990-91 Budget, expenditures which will assist the Northern Territory economy include $47m of defence capital works. The following is a list of some of the major items: $30m for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment deployment; $8m for the Tindal stage 2 development; and $1.7m for the first two phases of Tindal stage 3.

In addition, the Defence Force Housing Authority is likely to make significant expenditures in the Territory as more Defence personnel are relocated north. By 1998, it is planned that 5,000 more Defence personnel and their families will be stationed in the Northern Territory than are currently stationed there. This will create a demand for in excess of 1,000 homes and have significant long term multiplier effects providing opportunities for industry and jobs for Territorians.

In terms of the environment, the Budget announced two very significant initiatives for the Northern Territory: $2m for the control of mimosa pigra to stop its encroachment on Kakadu, and $7.2m for the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute. I would have liked to spend some time talking about the importance of these moneys, particularly in relation to mimosa pigra, but unfortunately time does not permit it, at least tonight.

The factors I have outlined indicate that the Commonwealth Budget will bring substantial benefits to the Northern Territory economy. I have not addressed in my remarks so far the money which is coming in terms of specific programs to the Northern Territory quite separately from the specific purpose payments to the Northern Territory Government by the Commonwealth Government GBEs, such as Telecom and the ABC. The factors I have outlined should indicate that this Government has committed itself to sustaining a level of funding to the Northern Territory Government which has promoted growth.
