This is far different from the sort of approach which is being promoted by the Opposition parties.

As I mentioned earlier, there needs to be a touch of glasnost in the political culture of the Northern Territory--including amongst some of its media. One commentator, Frank Alcorta, who writes for the Northern Territory News, and assumes, I might say, knowledge and expertise on subjects of which often, unfortunately, he clearly has little knowledge, wrote an article on 3 September which cannot be taken without comment. Mr Alcorta, in reference to the projected Commonwealth Budget deficit, said:
This blow-out will inevitably require that private sector spending and employment continue to be stifled.

For a person with even a passing knowledge of economics, this sort of analysis is unmitigated rubbish. As the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) clearly identified in his Budget Speech, the Budget remains in structural surplus when cyclical effects of the recession are taken into account. Far from providing a deficit blow-out, the Budget has been framed with sufficient flexibility to meet the effects of the recession. The assumed preference of Mr Alcorta would apparently be a scorched earth policy of slashing government expenditure at a time of recessed demand, the sort of proposition which is being promoted by the Opposition. This of course would have a devastating impact on the private investment which Mr Alcorta and others accuse the Government of holding back.

According to the same economic model which the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has been quoting extensively in recent times, expenditure cuts to bring the Budget into balance would reduce economic growth this year from the expected 1.5 per cent to 0.6 per cent and would cause an additional loss of jobs of 46,000. So on the one hand, Mr Alcorta is accusing the Commonwealth of putting private investment at risk and, on the other, is advocating a position which would damage the economy's recovery from the recession. Perhaps it is not surprising that it is a position similar to that which, after tortuous policy contortions, the Federal Opposition finds itself in. The absurdity of those propositions is self- evident. The argument is quite obviously contradictory and says a great deal about the absolute lack of economic understanding by those who promote it.

I might also say that Mr Alcorta's vigorous and unjustified attack on the Commonwealth Budget deficit this year is complemented by his silence on the question of the Northern Territory Government's own deficit. Unlike the Commonwealth, which has a structural surplus when cyclical factors are taken into account, the Northern Territory Government has a deficit which has no explanation but economic mismanagement over a number of years. If I have time, I will come briefly to the issue of Northern Territory debt. Unfortunately, Mr Alcorta, a person whom I have known for many years and with whom, indeed, I would regard myself as being friendly, is not just economically illiterate. There is even a slight suspicion, I would think--just a hint, perhaps--of duplicity in his ill-informed observations and comment about these matters.

The Commonwealth expenditure continues to underpin the economy of the Northern Territory. It amazes me, therefore, that the CLP Government of the Territory persists in running economic policy along the lines of an economic myth--the myth being that, without the Commonwealth, the Territory might be a better place. In fact, Commonwealth allocations to the Northern Territory Government finance approximately 70 per cent of the Northern Territory Government's so-called inner budget sector--excluding, that is, GBEs and statutory authorities. Private capital is of growing importance to the Territory, especially in the tourism and mining sectors. While there is no doubt about the importance of this investment in stimulating private sector growth, the relative importance of the private sector as a source of employment or as a contributor to regional multiplier effects is sometimes poorly understood and, for some sectors, overstated.

In this respect, I was interested to hear recently an interview with Mr Geoff Stewart, of Tanami Gold, on this matter. Mr Stewart replied to a question of whether a promising new find would create many new jobs by saying:
We employ less than 100 men. . . I think we move something like 7 million tonnes of earth a year and not many people do that.
Furthermore, when Mr Stewart was asked what the impact for the Territory would be, he replied:

The chief beneficiary from gold mining at the moment is export income for Australia, not many jobs for Territorians, not much royalty for Territorians so as I say the chief beneficiary is export income to buy our Toyotas.
While mining is, of course, important for the nation, it may not have the regional importance that some might have us believe.

I contrast this with the regional impact of expenditures by Aboriginal affairs. Expenditures to Aboriginal people have very strong and localised multipliers which can contribute significantly to local income generation. In 1988 a study of the central Australian region concluded that approximately one-third of all regional expenditure was attributable to Aboriginal people and their organisations. I stress that this is not just what some would call `welfare payments', or transfers as a result of Commonwealth appropriations; a considerable proportion--an estimated 20 per cent--was derived from the commercial activities of Aboriginal organisations.

Furthermore, the contribution of Aboriginal peoples' cultural heritage would add significantly to tourism revenue in places like Kakadu and Uluru. This underlines the ever increasing importance of Commonwealth appropriations in terms of stabilising the Northern Territory and providing it with the basis on which it can grow.

The Commonwealth's contribution to the Northern Territory would be threatened by the election of a Liberal-National Party coalition with a policy not only of introducing a consumption tax but also with the twin evil of addressing the fiscal side of the Budget by cutting $3 billion from the Budget. A consumption tax would hit the Northern Territory hard because of its generally higher prices.

We heard today from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) when he addressed the issue of a consumption tax and its impact on regional Australia. Aboriginal people in remote areas are the people who have most to lose and who would be dramatically affected.

I have highlighted the conflict--the inherent contradictions--which exists in the Opposition's policies, a position which has been adopted and appropriated by the Northern Territory Government in supporting a proposition that not only would attack the weakest in our community but also would see cuts in government expenditure which would have a detrimental impact upon the Northern Territory economy. One estimate of the impact of a $3 billion cut in government outlays from the Federal sphere on the Northern Territory economy is a loss of between $200m and $250m--an enormous amount of money out of a Budget of just over $1 billion in terms of Commonwealth appropriations.
It is important to understand that those are the sorts of policies which have been advocated by the CLP, and by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) here in this House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-For much of the time this House is justifiably preoccupied with debate about the course of the national economy. The attention of honourable members is focused on key economic indicators and the larger market related structural issues affecting rates of economic activity. In the time I have available I would like to bring some specificity to this debate in respect of the place of technological change in these wider issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In itself this is a complex issue, but my particular concern on this occasion is with the role of engineering in the national economy. Generally speaking, there is something of a debate amongst economic historians as to the causal status of technology and the growth, expansion and competitiveness of economics. This debate has become clouded ever since technologies and technological skills became more diffused across the global economy in the last 50 years.

Since no-one owns or has exclusivity to appropriated technical knowledge, the issue of the technological intensity of a nation's industrial base reflects on the dynamism of the whole production process. That is to say, what determines the scope of technological advantages enjoyed by one nation's firms and companies over another's is not solely the possession of technology as such; it is, rather, the forces at work across their economies which prompt wide scale commitments to innovation and change.

In the case of engineering it is difficult to verify empirically the benefits the profession brings to the performance of companies. This is not just because the extent to which industry is able to draw on engineering skills is dependent upon its commercial incentive and managerial disposition to do so; rather, it is because engineering impacts on such a broad range of manufacturing and industrial activities that any formal analysis of its role will never do it sufficient justice.

Importantly, the Institution of Engineers placed these and other issues on the public agenda at its engineering summit held here in Canberra in July. The summit formed part of ongoing and prolific efforts by the Institution of Engineers to build a greater appreciation of the role of engineers within the community. More broadly, the summit also served to alert policy makers to the role of technological restructuring in the wider economic debate.

There has traditionally existed a narrow view of the role of engineering in the economy. At the risk of simplifying matters even more, engineers have conventionally been viewed as operating at the back end of the innovation process, that is, they apply available knowledge rather than create it. They have been more active in designing, installing and maintaining equipment essential to production processes rather than having a deeper role therein. This is a shallow analysis of the role of engineering in promoting innovation. Engineering now comprises much more than the conventionally understood fields of civil, mechanical, chemical, mining and metallurgical engineering. The skill base of engineering has both deepened and widened, as has its impact across the economy.

These conventional sub-disciplines now require even deeper immersion in core science disciplines, such as mathematics, chemistry, geology, physics and computer sciences. Moreover, engineers have integrated their skills into management processes, adding to the capacity of industry to oversee technological resources and use them effectively as instruments for achieving market advantages. I point out that Australia still does not make proper use of its engineers as do other countries. Australia has two management level engineers per 1,000 of the work force, whilst the United States of America has six and the United Kingdom, Germany and France have double Australia's rate.

Regardless of this, the burgeoning information industry has also given birth to new sub-fields such as micro-electronic engineering. This relatively new sub-field of engineering integrates engineering design skills with developments in information technology. Its main focus is on sophisticated component design and it is at the forefront of developments in micro-chip technologies and integrated circuitry. Graduation rates in electronics and communications related engineering have jumped markedly over the decade, surpassing growth in traditional sub- fields such as civil engineering.

This House hears a great deal of claims that Australia must move into a post-industrial phase of its economy which emphasises value added manufacturing and knowledge intensive industrial activities. There is a great deal of talk about the necessity for Australian companies to incorporate advanced manufacturing technology, optimal design techniques and so forth. Capabilities of this sort are at the heart of successful exports of any elaborately transformed manufactured products. But in the absence of an industrial base which is capable of cutting it with the best in the global market, adapting to rapidly shifting consumer demands and technically flexible enough to swing resources into new areas of market opportunities, this will hardly come about. Notwithstanding this, when the structural impediments to competition which drive these changes have been swept away, it will be the engineers who will be at the forefront of the new industrial era of Australia.

Generally, the spill-over effect on the economy of engineering as a generic activity increases every year. Apart from its more obvious role in design, engineering has other more critical but less visible roles in the technology transfer process. In a broad sense, while commercial forces may well guide skill and capital formation processes across the economy, the diffusion of knowledge itself--a critical factor in the innovation process--is a key responsibility of engineers.

Whether or not it is possible to transfer new techniques and processes across the economy will be a function of the existence of a suitably well-trained and available engineering capability. Engineering, then, is far from being of only marginal significance to the overall innovation process. It is not only a technological activity which applies knowledge in a rudimentary sense to create products or to make existing production processes more efficient, but product design skills and the capacity to build incremental improvements into existing production processes will also be very important, especially in respect to the general productivity gains they bring.

But engineers also provide the means by which new knowledge is effectively diffused or transmitted across the economy. This is a critical matter to which too little attention has been paid. The competitiveness of industry is greatly retarded, therefore, if its technical competency to rapidly commercialise intellectual property is restricted. Even assuming a firm can reach a position to gain a foot in a newly emerged market, its capacity to hold that ground also largely bears on technical matters. Constant improvements in product design and reliability and the lowering of overall production costs also fall at the feet of engineers; in hand, of course, with a management which is capable and able to grasp the linkages of its technology strategies with its business plans.

I would add that engineering also has an important role to play at the front end, if you like, of the innovation process. There is a great deal of untapped research potential amongst Australia's engineering community. There is a persistent belief that engineering research is poor science. That is because of its assumed exclusivity whereby its applied focus is more on design and product formation. There seems to be an assumption that engineering has no underlying research capability which could confer advantages on the community in the way that basic and strategic research does.

More specifically, it is held by some that, as engineering research emphasises invention and innovation over discovery and explanation, it does not present the same publication or academic oriented profile as other sciences. Given its other roles, as I have outlined, it is important that engineering is not excluded from consideration in respect of its research potential.

There is much higher quality engineering research carried out which is oriented to further explanation. Work on the application of mathematics and computing to solve problems in the properties of materials is a case in point. According to the 1990 ASTEC report entitled Government Funding of Academic and Related Research in Australia: An International Comparison, engineering research in Australia is seriously underfunded in comparison to research in other OECD countries. In fact, the report found that engineering related research in Australia received less than half the level of funding that it received in six other OECD countries.

There are idiosyncrasies of engineering related research which give it a profile which is difficult to reconcile within the guidelines governing the administrative bodies which allocate research grants. In some ways its positioning here is akin to the discipline of psychology which struggles to assert its research profile as being either a social science or a science. These apparent anomalies deserve attention.

If administrative mechanisms are to determine the allocation of research resources, it ought to be transparent why some research is funded and not other research. Also, it ought to be explained, in considered terms, how the balance in the distribution of the research funds, for which there is a responsibility, is determined.

In respect of the Australian Research Council, the subcommittee which has responsibility for the allocation of grants for engineering also has responsibility for grant allocations for earth sciences and applied sciences. I do not wish to take anything away from Australia's earth and applied sciences research effort, but as a percentage of available research funds under the control of the relevant committee, engineering receives little more than 16 per cent--16.3 per cent in 1990. Perhaps it is the case that there are too few researchers in the field of engineering design, or else there are too few who present appropriately high quality submissions for funding.

There is, of course, an argument here, but I would be anxious to know what philosophy guides the ARC in respect of such arguments. How, for instance, do administrative mechanisms such as those which guide the ARC account for such matters as the relative paucity of Australia's engineering research capabilities? Who determines what constitutes a suitable or appropriate level of research activity in a given field? What scope is given to the definition of the advancement of knowledge which guides the distribution of ARC funds, and where is the cut-off line between basic and applied research? I for one do appreciate the administrative difficulties associated with these matters; it is nevertheless a source of concern to me that Australia might well be failing to capture the benefits of what is presently a latent research capacity in respect of engineering.

More important than this, however, is the more fundamental issue of locking engineering research into an expanding industrial base. Given its close industry linkages, engineering research should be centred within the private sector. This is certainly the case abroad. Business funded engineering research in such areas as aeronautical engineering and microelectronics dwarfs public sector funded research efforts in universities and other agencies. It is no wonder, then, that Australia has about one-third the number of engineering researchers as Japan, one-fifth as many as the United States of America and one-eighth as many as Germany.

Yet once again significant changes in this regard will not come about in Australia until such time as it develops internationally competitive firms or industry sectors which are able to capture the commercial benefits of fundamental or strategic engineering research. Notwithstanding this, Australia does have one pocket of internationally recognised engineering research. That is in the subfield of chemical engineering, which has a significant scientific output. Here is the lesson. The chemicals industry in Australia is strong, despite its difficulties at present. The presence of such companies as ICI and Shell has provided the industrial strength, the market pull, to create an impressive and diverse research capacity in chemical engineering.

Generally speaking, the correlation between the areas of competitive industrial activity and a nation's relative research capabilities is always strong, and it is even stronger in respect of its linkages with the education system generally. There is a real need to provide greater direction to the way in which Australia approaches the training and education of its engineers. On the basis of studies carried out by the Institution of Engineers, there are good reasons to be concerned about the future availability of sufficient engineers to meet national needs. At the moment Australia recruits from abroad about 3,000 engineers annually. But future international demand for engineers is such that these sources of engineering skills will soon dry up.

The current number of qualified engineers in Australia amounts to a little more than one per cent of the work force, or some 92,000 appropriately trained individuals, which is half that of our trading rivals and half the targeted 2 per cent pursued by regional countries. The Australian figures are a little inflated. Only about 72,000 are actually part of the work force, so the number of engineers in employment as a percentage of the work force is more likely to be around 0.9 per cent. Though engineering's share of the total allocation of university enrolments has picked up from 6.9 per cent to 7.5 per cent over the decade, there is still inadequate momentum in the discipline to guarantee future supply.

As I said earlier, if this country is to elbow its way into the traded goods sector, it will not do so in the absence of a high level design and engineering capability. But this will not come about within the centralised framework of the existing higher education sector. The opportunities for close collaboration between universities and the engineering community are considerable. The major engineering professional society, the Institution of Engineers (Australia), has conducted its own close and detailed review of the educational requirements of the next generation of engineers.

It stands ready to work with universities to restructure engineering courses which reflect changes in the disciplines and to provide a match-up between student demand and industry needs in both vocational and educational respects. The Institution of Engineers has devised a restructured approach to training and education which meets the diversity of industry needs while maintaining an eye on qualitative concerns. It is positioned to build bridges between industries with heavy interests in engineering to revitalise and bring direction to the engineering discipline. In so doing the Institution of Engineers has also provided its own industry based approach to work force restructuring by providing an articulated career structure for engineers who enter the profession at different levels and for different purposes.

Initiatives such as these might sound novel in Australia but they are conventional wisdom abroad. Those countries which possess international renown and high level skill transfer capabilities are characterised by close linkages between educational institutions and industry sectors. Australia needs to provide for institutional flexibility to seize the opportunities that have come the way of our international competitors. But outcomes such as these will not be achieved within the structure of our existing higher education sector.

By way of conclusion: it must be understood that Australia has much to gain from developing a stronger engineering capacity, but equally it must be appreciated that the extent to which the nation or an individual firm can capitalise on the engineering capabilities--as with technology as a whole--is itself dependent upon the efficiencies which can be won across the chain of production; that is, the degree to which Australia's industries take advantage of engineering and invest more heavily in technology acquisition, design and development programs is profoundly affected by other forces making for innovation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is with pleasure that I speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1). This Budget, as we are all aware, was one framed for difficult economic times, and some difficult economic decisions had to be taken. However, there were many beneficial outcomes in the Budget, benefits which will have a positive outcome on all Australians. This Budget has a strong vision for the future and contains a range of new initiatives which build a better Australia for all.

SPEECH.PARA: It contains a number of significant initiatives such as the progressive enhancement of a comprehensive national superannuation scheme, additional resources for child-care, the expansion of the community cultural, sports and recreation facilities program, the enhancement of the capital works program in our tertiary institutions, considerable expansion of labour market programs, and the establishment of the building better cities program, to name just some of the visionary new projects.

This Budget is about providing restraint with equity. It is not, as some have argued for, full of pump-priming measures to stimulate the economy, nor is it, as those opposite have argued for, a balanced Budget, in which reduced Commonwealth outlays would have worsened our unemployment situation--as the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) pointed out yesterday--and reduced GDP by about one per cent. This Budget is a responsible one for difficult times which has produced many pluses.

One of the major features of the Budget was the announcement of an additional $30m to be spent over three years for the community cultural, sports and recreation facilities program. This comes on top of the $20m which has been distributed over the past three years. I take great pleasure in seeing this program extended, as earlier this year, on 18 April, I moved a motion in this House seeking an expansion of the community cultural, sports and recreation facilities program. The reason I moved that motion was to ensure that the Government had time to develop an extension of the program and incorporate it into the budgetary process, and to highlight the importance of this financial assistance in the community.

This program will assist local sporting groups to build new facilities and to upgrade existing facilities. This is welcome news to groups in my electorate such as the Brisbane Metropolitan Touch Football Association, which has recently decided to build a new clubhouse at its playing fields in the suburb of Whites Hill. I was pleased to be invited to the trophy presentation night of the Association which was held last Saturday. At the presentation night all were strongly in support of the new program. This program forms only part of the sports funding component of the Budget and that is only a small part of the overall Budget package.

The Government also announced substantial assistance for families. It has allocated an additional $124m in the next financial year and $186m in 1993-94 to family allowances. From 1 April next year the family allowance supplement income threshold will rise a further $1,300 to $19,300. This base will then be indexed from January the following year. This will provide increased assistance to more than 100,000 families in Australia.

Similarly, child-care was another big winner from the Budget. Child-care is an issue on which the Government campaigned quite heavily in the last election and it is one on which this Labor Government has delivered consistently. I know that in my own electorate of Moreton, since becoming its member some 18 months ago, I have seen the number of child-care places dramatically expand. Child- care is a major part of the Government's commitment to social justice. By providing affordable and accessible child-care, the Government is committed to maximising the opportunity for people seeking training and employment.

The Government has increased fee relief for working parents by extending long day care fee relief for those using child-care for work related purposes. The advances in child-care will have a significant effect on employment opportunities which are available for women by encouraging greater mobility within the work force. In doing so, however, the Government still recognises the family as the principal provider of child-care. Child-care will be more generous for families in receipt of family allowance supplement, as well as for working families on higher incomes. In this Budget the Government has reaffirmed its 1990 election promise of affordability of child-care with quality programs, and for this it must be highly commended.

Students receiving financial support will also benefit from the Budget. It has always been the aim of this Government to increase educational opportunities for all Australians and improved educational outcomes for disadvantaged students. The Budget has assisted in this process by improving and simplifying Austudy. With school retention rates now much higher than they were a decade ago, there is also an increasing number of people going on to higher education. These are people who previously, because of financial or social disadvantage, would not have had the opportunity or access to tertiary education.

In this Budget we have seen the raising of the personal income threshold from $4,000 to $5,000, an increase of 25 per cent. This is a measure which is welcomed by all students on Austudy. Earlier this year, as a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training inquiring into the provision and effectiveness of student financial assistance schemes, I met with student representatives from all over Australia who came before the Committee. They were unanimous in their view that the allowable personal income limit was insufficient and that it had to be increased. I am pleased to see that the Government has decided to follow through by increasing the personal income limit.

Within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, $420m was allocated to the TAFE system. This represents an increase in real terms of 5 per cent. The area of vocational training is one which clearly separates the Government from those opposite. This Government is committed to providing substantial training opportunities for people so that when the economy recovers younger people in particular will have greater access to jobs. This contrasts markedly with the position of our conservative opponents, who, in the lead-up to the last election, had a policy of abolishing Skillshare and a host of other Labor market programs.

At the same time as they had this policy, many Liberal members who had Skillshare centres in their electorates were deliberately misleading the management committees of those Skillshare programs by telling them they would be retained in their electorates. I am fortunate to have an exceptional Skillshare centre in my electorate at Mount Gravatt, managed by Mr Ross Garnett. Even in these difficult economic times Mount Gravatt Skillshare has achieved a 70 per cent job placement rate. This is an outstanding performance due to the excellence of the training and the successful partnership between local employers and the Skillshare committee.

National superannuation was perhaps the most significant long term feature announced in the Budget. The right to a guaranteed retirement income is a major priority of this Government. The Government has been concerned that low and middle income earners have been missing out on superannuation, which for a long time has been the sole preserve of the wealthy. The Government committed itself to the process of guaranteed superannuation when, in 1986, through the accord process, workers on awards were granted a 3 per cent pay rise to be taken in the form of superannuation.

The problem with a superannuation contribution of only 3 per cent is that it is not enough to provide completely for adequate retirement incomes. This, in combination with non-compliance by some employers, has resulted in the Government's decision to legislate for guaranteed superannuation. This legislation is a necessary and visionary step taken by this Government. With an ageing population and taxation receipts as a share of GDP reducing, it is essential that as many people as possible are covered by a superannuation program.

One of the Government's most positive and beneficial Budget decisions was to address the crisis facing our cities through the building better cities program. This program demonstrates vision and foresight and addresses social and physical problems of our cities and not simply the economic problems of their inhabitants.

Our cities are in crisis and, if left unaddressed, the problems will exacerbate. There are immense challenges facing all levels of government in reshaping urban environments. If we maintain our existing processes, these problems would increase and result in greater social dislocation and the resultant social problems.

During the coming decade, Australia will require substantial investment in new urban infrastructure. This infrastructure is required to enable land to be brought into urban use, to facilitate redevelopment and to replace and improve outworn infrastructure. New investment and replacement will be required if governments give more emphasis to urban consolidation and to increasing the density of land use within existing built-up areas.

Under any assumptions, a substantial amount of land will have to be newly serviced to bring it into urban use to meet the needs of the forecast growth in Australia's population. At present, approximately 60 per cent of our nation's population live in five cities. Over the next decade, Australia will need more than 1.2 million dwellings, of which 700,000 will be built on the fringes of our major cities, if the trend continues.

In the coming decade, new urban settlement and redevelopment of existing areas will be required both in large metropolitan areas of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane and in the smaller provincial towns. The financing of urban infrastructure is becoming more difficult as a consequence of the restrictions placed on public spending and borrowing at all levels of government. As a consequence, attention is being directed at the efficiency and equity of alternative methods of financing.

Efficiency means making sure that resources are devoted to socially most valuable ends, and at the same time using as few resources as possible. This involves taking account of the external effects of decisions as well as the needs and demands of users. The Economic Planning and Advisory Council estimates that it costs nearly $70,000 to provide infrastructure for each new housing block in outer Sydney. In Victoria, for 1989- 90, $200m was spent on water and sewerage in fringe areas, as was $80m on each of education and roads, and $45m on health facilities.

Although Australia is one of the most urbanised nations in the world, up to this time there has been only sporadic debate about the quality of our urbanisation and its future. The building better cities program in this Budget changes that. The last major debate on this issue occurred in the 1970s during the period of the Whitlam Government. Although efforts by Whitlam to get the issue of urban equality were debated, there is little in the way of a remaining legacy. The question should not be therefore, `Why persist with a program such as building better cities?', but, `Why has it taken so long to do something like this?'.

While the Whitlam Government did attempt to comprehend the structure of our cities and did try to consider some aspects of it, it did not change the fundamental nature of our urban environment. Australian towns and cities are facing a real crisis. With housing and land in short supply and prices for those social goods escalating, more and more people are living on the fringes of cities. The provision of jobs, services and other infrastructure is not keeping pace with the rapid growth of such communities. Even in more established areas, infrastructure is becoming more run down and has become inadequate for the needs of people. These factors have combined with high levels of social dislocation stemming from limited economic opportunities.

The Commonwealth Government, in conjunction with the States, has begun the task of rebuilding Australia's national infrastructure in areas such as road and rail networks and electricity generation and distribution. There is also at present a major restructure of our telecommunications services and the overhaul of our ports. The restructuring of industry, and with it changes in the location and type of employment, is accelerating in cities.

One of the objectives of the better cities program is to reduce the cost of infrastructure, and that would be of benefit to industry, governments and households. There is a need for urban consolidation and for a more efficient and equitable approach to the provision and financing of urban infrastructure. The growth of major cities in the past few decades has left us with under-used resources in established areas and huge costs in providing for unchecked growth at the fringes.

The continued spread at the fringes means that there is almost total dependency on the use of private cars. This results in a car oriented community with long journeys to work, education or training. Fuel consumption in Australian cities is at least double that of an average European city. The resultant high level of greenhouse gases and other pollutants has degraded our living environment and is contributing to global problems in atmospheric warming and efficient use of energy resources.

Under the building better cities program, the Commonwealth will work with State and local governments to improve access to work and services, to seek to reduce pollution and congestion with better transport systems, as well as providing innovative housing styles which better suit the changing needs of Australians.

As most Australians live in urban areas, the crisis must be addressed. The Brundtland Commission report, Our Common Future, reported that the majority of our environmental problems in the future will be urban problems. These problems must be addressed now if major social dislocation and the resultant problems are to be avoided in the future.

This Government will carry through the process of reform that will make a great difference to the quality of life in Australian cities and will help to achieve, on the basis of both new and existing infrastructure, very significant reforms in the efficiency of Australian cities which will benefit all Australians. This Budget provides the basis for allowing a sustained economic recovery, while providing new, innovative and positive programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome the opportunity to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92. I briefly want to reflect on the traumatic events of the week of 20 August 1991. We saw then red hot emotions in Moscow, a huge chemical fire in Melbourne and a Budget which went up in smoke in Canberra. The Budget has been panned by every leading editorial writer throughout this country. It does nothing to address the major problems confronting Australia at this moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget has the imprimatur of the Hawke-Keating-Kerin forces over the top of it. No-one could truly describe it as a Hawke- Keating Budget, nor could anyone describe it as being a Hawke-Kerin Budget. There are elements of both policies pervading the whole of this Budget document. What started out as a forecast 1990-91 surplus of over $8 billion has deteriorated in just one year to a proposed forecast deficit of $4.7 billion, which leads us to conclude that almost $13 billion has been turned around on the Budget in just one year.

The major issue which has not been confronted by the Hawke-Keating-Kerin Budget, particularly, is unemployment. Unemployment in this country is a national tragedy. The unemployed are the casualties of this failed policy, this failed Government. There are now 831,900 Australians officially out of work. On the Government's own estimates, this figure is expected to rise to over one million. Unemployment is now at 9.8 per cent and is predicted by the Government to rise to 10.75 per cent. In July, 44,000 Australians gave up the task of looking for a job because there were no jobs available for them. Since the last election, in March 1990, 322,000 Australians have lost their jobs.

I want to put that into context because in my own electorate of Bendigo there are extremely high unemployment levels. In the city of Bendigo, over 15 per cent of the population is unemployed and in the city of Maryborough, it is over 18 per cent. But the figure of 322,000 Australians who have lost their jobs in just over one year represents the total population of the city of Geelong, the city of Bendigo, the city of Ballarat, the city of Maryborough and the town of Kyneton. These are all major population centres in the State of Victoria, and this figure represents every man, woman and child--the total population--of all of those areas. That is what the figure of 322,000 represents.

If we want another example of what 322,000 unemployed people look like, it is more than three times the number of people who attended the AFL grand final last year, and maybe four times more than will attend the grand final at Waverley this year. We should have a look at those people on grand final day and remember that four times that number have lost their jobs since the last election.

Nearly two million Australians are unable to work as much or as often as they wish to work. More than 160,000 Australian households now have the breadwinner unemployed--an increase of 50,000, or 45 per cent, in a single year. Today at Question Time, I raised just one example of the impact that unemployment is having in my electorate. I detailed the instance of Raymond, the 45- year-old office manager who lost his job more than 12 months ago and now applies for positions all throughout the area, and right throughout Victoria, and often is told that he is too old or overskilled for the positions for which he applies.

These are the human costs of unemployment for many thousands in my own electorate, throughout Victoria and throughout Australia--and the number is heading towards well over one million. Who can say where it will end? In response to many questions on financial and economic management, the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has said, `Your guess is as good as mine'. There is a lack of direction and no attempt in this Budget whatsoever to do something to get the economy right and to assist people who are unemployed.

One of the major thrusts of the Budget has been the decision by the Government to divert more savings into superannuation in this nation. We will see a gradual progression of funds moving into the superannuation field and under a proposed superannuation guarantee levy, all employers with an annual payroll exceeding $500,000 will be required to pay 5 per cent of each employee's salary as superannuation. Smaller employers will be required to pay 3 per cent. That will transfer more and more savings into areas of superannuation. That would be fine if this country could afford it; but we have to look at where it will take those savings from.

One of the areas that I believe those savings will be diverted from is the housing area. Everyone in this country at the moment recognises how difficult it is for young people to obtain the gap--the money that they can put down on a deposit to enable them to purchase their first home. It requires a tremendous effort by a young couple, generally with both in the work force and contributing to the repayments on that first home.

The Government's proposal to divert funds more and more into the superannuation area will ultimately mean a 9 per cent employer contribution--which is its target--and almost matching contributions from the employee. That employee contribution will be directed away from the housing area and will make it more and more difficult for young people to obtain a home. They will also find that much of the available capital in this country will be going into superannuation funds and the fund managers, whoever they might be, will be attracted to higher rate investments than housing. Housing will be one of the funds' lower priorities; it will not be their top priority. The fund managers will be looking for a greater rate of return for the people who have superannuation and who have investments with the funds.

We will see an erosion in this country of savings and the capacity to divert those savings into the housing industry in Australia, and of the ability to provide homes for thousands and thousands of young Australians. We will probably be seeing in Australia that owning a home, instead of being the great Australian dream, will become a nightmare--particularly for the average workers trying to establish themselves in a home.

In March 1983 when the Government came into office, the average monthly home loan repayment was $350, or 19 per cent of the median family income. By March 1991 the average monthly home loan repayment was $906 per month, or 31 per cent of the median family income. This is a 63 per cent increase in the cost of housing for the average family and is reflected in the housing affordability index--measuring house repayments and average incomes--which has declined by 30 per cent between 1984 and 1991, making the task of establishing a home and a haven for their family an absolute nightmare for average income earners.

The transference of superannuation funds will have another impact as well because small business in this country is already reeling from the high interest rate policies which were adopted by the Hawke-Keating-Kerin Government, and the small business sector in this country has been on its knees. Now we are finding that the employers--many of them are small to medium size business owners--will be required to pay a 5 per cent superannuation contribution from 1 July this year. More and more funds will be transferred away from the small business operator who is already struggling to keep on top of the economic climate, with a downturn in sales, particularly reduced retail sales, month by month for the past 18 months. Now we see a diversion of further funds away from that business into superannuation. It will mean that many small business owners who are above the $500,000 cut-off point, where they go to the 5 per cent payment of superannuation, will reduce their annual payrolls by removing and eliminating some of their staff by retrenchments or offering them some alternative. They will move them out of the work force in a number of different ways so they can reduce that payroll and still contribute only 3 per cent.

We will find a contraction of small business throughout this country by the elimination or retrenchments of staff to bring them down to below that limit so that they are only required to pay 3 per cent. I am sure that that will have an impact--it is almost a type of payroll tax--and will force employers to look very seriously at the level of work force that they employ.

The other issue that I want to address is the matter that I understand was introduced into the Budget by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe)--that is, the building better cities program. The proposal to plough $800m over five years into a partnership with the States to improve the quality of life in Australian cities, especially through increased housing choices, better matching of housing with jobs and services and improved public transport has been attributed to the Deputy Prime Minister. If we use those criteria, the Government can only be talking about the major cities of Australia. It can only be talking about the likes of Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And the Gold Coast.

—-There are a number of points related to this. The honourable member for Moreton raised this during his contribution to the appropriation debate and said it would assist small towns. I can tell him that there is no public transport in small towns so I do not know how the Government will improve the public transport in some of these areas because it does not even have a base to start from. The Labor Party policies in this area are generally directed--I am sure that this will prove to be no exception--to shoring up its support in marginal Labor held seats in city electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has given out grand plans of spending $800m, with no details whatsoever. In fact, when the Deputy Prime Minister was asked to give some details, he could not provide any details. He said, `We'll leave that to the States and local government; they'll fix it all up'. The Government will put $800m into this program over five years. It has tremendous grand plans; it will build a couple of monuments in each of the major cities. None of the provincial cities or small country areas are likely to share in the program at all. I see that the honourable member for Moreton is shaking his head. I hope that I am wrong. I would like him to demonstrate over the next few years that provincial cities such as Bendigo, Ballarat, Geelong and smaller country centres benefit from this plan. I feel quite confident that that will not be the case. I have seen the grand plans that were laid by a former Minister in this House, Tom Uren. I am sure that the money will be spent in the capital cities.

The Government is looking at more expensive infrastructure in city areas. It is about $30,000 per block more expensive to provide infrastructure in the city of Melbourne than it is in the city of Bendigo. The Government is intending to provide expensive infrastructure in the capital cities of Australia to provide opportunities for residents of those large city areas to have improved facilities. That is all very fine, but it is neglecting the rest of Australia.

When I come to that aspect of it, what better stimulus could the Government have given than ploughing some money into the rural sector of Australia? The general economy of Australia is dependent on three factors: rural production, which is one of our major export earners; resources, and our valued added products from those resources; and our manufacturing sector. They are the three main driving forces of the Australian economy. The rural sector has been neglected in this Budget yet again. Ignoring rural sector enterprise and the rural sector throughout Australia is becoming a common theme of the Hawke-Keating-Kerin policies. The rural sector is one of our greatest export earners but is in desperate trouble at the moment through lower prices for wool and wheat production. The rural sector would have been a great beneficiary if the Government could have found some assistance, even some of the $800m which is being put into the better cities program that the Government is contemplating.

I would like to touch briefly on only one other topic. What is needed in Australia is the provision of incentive for people to get out and create enterprise. We will not be able to create any enterprise or any worthwhile business activity in this country unless we have a massive overhaul of the taxation system. I have been to a number of large public meetings recently where I have posed the question: are you happy with Australia's taxation system as it exists today? The universal answer to that is no. That is a very good point to start from. We need to do a complete overhaul of the taxation system in this country and provide some incentive for people to become enterprising again and employ people in this nation to create wealth for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to speak on the Appropriation Bill. There has been quite a wide ranging debate and there have been many useful contributions. There has been much debate in the community and in this House about the Budget. I say at the outset that it is a realistic Budget, given the current economic situation. It is a Budget that not only takes account of the current situation but also is the basis for economic recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with interest to what the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) said. He made a worthwhile contribution. It is unfortunate that he spoilt it at the end by his comment about taxation. I ask him: has he ever spoken to anyone who did not believe they were paying too much in taxation? Of all the letters that I get and the comments that people make to me, it is a universal thing. It is the only thing that people are uniformly in agreement on in Australia. Everyone seems to believe that they pay too much in taxation. He should not be too surprised that he found that there was no-one who was happy with the tax system. It is a universal thing that we all have to live with.

To hear some of the Opposition members speak and to read some of the newspaper comment about the Budget, one would think that Australia was the only country experiencing economic difficulties. Australia's current recession is part of a worldwide recession. Many of the causes are external and beyond Australia's control.

At the outset I wish to congratulate the Government for its decision to rejoin the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation. Australia's decision to withdraw was wrong. The benefits to Australia in rejoining will be considerable, not only financially, in that Australian industry will be fully involved in the activities and projects promoted by UNIDO, but also politically, in that Australia will, once again, be able to participate fully in the decision making process and contribute to charting the course of the organisation.

All our major partners have recognised the influential and profitable role that UNIDO is playing in promoting international cooperation in the industrial sector; indeed, it was quite abnormal that Australia should not be among the 150 member states of UNIDO. For those reasons, and for many others, I welcome Australia's rejoining. The decision has been taken with due regard to Australia's multilateral commitments and as part of an ongoing process to assess and evaluate Australia's contribution to United Nations organisations. It reflects the changes that have taken place in UNIDO over the past four years. As a major international forum for the consideration of issues relating to industrial development, UNIDO provides a unique channel of communication between developed and developing countries and the promotion of cooperation on industrialisation issues globally, regionally, and nationally, as well as by sector.

I modestly claim that I may have played a small part in Australia's rejoining through my questions to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett). I have also made two speeches in this House on the topic of Australia rejoining and over the past year or so I have put numerous questions on the Notice Paper. Just before I left my office to come to the chamber this evening, in my mail there was a fax from the Director-General thanking me for the contribution I had made. However, I was only one of a number of members urging the Government to rejoin this important organisation.

I am pleased that there has been a modest increase in Australia's overseas aid budget. I was amazed after the Budget to hear the comment from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) that, had the conservatives framed the Budget, they would have cut our overseas aid. The overseas aid contribution was a modest increase, but a welcome one. Despite what many in the community claim, Australia obtains many long term benefits as well as short term benefits from our overseas aid.

No member of this House, and most certainly no member on this side of the chamber, would dispute the fact that unemployment is a major social burden facing this country. It is a tragedy in economic and personal terms. I represent an area with an unacceptably high unemployment level, so no-one is more aware of this than I am. I see the unemployed and I talk with them. For too long the Illawarra has been basically a two industry area--steel and coal. The steelworks has gone from employing about 24,000 people in 1982 to 7,000 today, and that is to be reduced by another 2,000. Over recent years the coal industry work force in my area has more than halved. Then there is the flow-on impact to smaller enterprises supplying the major industries.

The Illawarra Mercury has run two editorials--on 22 August and 3 September--that have been critical of the Budget. It has taken both me and my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) to task regarding our support for the Budget. I resent the Mercury's claim that I have ignored the plight of the unemployed. Had the Mercury bothered to check with me it would have found that I have worked hard to achieve jobs in the Illawarra. One can always get a few headlines by making statements that are critical of the Government, especially if one is a member of the Government Party. The Mercury never looks at the work that is being carried out, nor does it bother to check on the deputations and other work that one does.

One of the major contributing factors to unemployment in the Illawarra is the job cuts made by the State Government. That same State Government could create work there by starting some of the important projects that have long been on the drawing board, projects such as the Maldon-Dombarton railway, which in an act of unprecedented stupidity it stopped immediately on coming to power. It could build the road that I have been pushing for for a long time, linking the highlands to the coast, as a replacement for the Macquarie Pass Road, namely, the Caloola Pass Road. Both those projects would not only generate employment in my area but would provide a long term stimulus to the economy of the area by giving better access to Port Kembla.

No local member is complacent about the unemployment level in places such as the Illawarra. We accept that it is too high. We are aware of the personal tragedy it is for people. We are working collectively to create jobs in the Illawarra. Also the Illawarra Mercury does not always publish what one says. For example, in the Illawarra there is a quaint system that if one media outlet publishes a story the other media outlets will not use it.

Only last week, for example, a firm called Heat Containment Pty Ltd of Unanderra retrenched 30 workers. The reason given was that it had lost an order to supply bricks to works at Tomaga to a French company. French bricks were being imported into Australia even though bricks were being produced in Australia. When the unions alerted me to the retrenchments at the Unanderra factory, I was concerned about a number of issues. First, more Illawarra workers were to be placed on the unemployment scrap heap. I was also concerned about information I had received that the French were engaging in dumping these bricks in Australia.

We can and do compete successfully on the international market, selling similar kinds of bricks to overseas countries, yet we cannot win a contract in our own country. Imagine the outcry in France if a company retrenched its workers because Australian bricks were being imported into France. I have taken up this matter with both the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall). I also felt, from contact with the management of Heat Containment Pty Ltd, that the company was engaged in restructuring at the expense of the workers. Although I made several media statements about these issues, because one local television station had run with the story the Illawarra Mercury did not bother to run with it.

I must say, though, that in regard to other matters that paper has been most supportive. At the Pioneer quarry at Bass Point, the company which made in excess of $150m profit last year--some have told me that it paid no tax on it because a lot of it was work from overseas--has indulged in one of the worst attacks on workers since the 1930s under the guise of restructuring. The company introduced new rosters, totally without any consultation with its staff, which it knew would be unacceptable. When the workers predictably refused to work the rosters, the company locked them out. The company deceitfully claimed that the quarry was closed and therefore sacked the workers. That was in April of this year. An Industrial Commission ruling found that the company had seriously breached the award in a number of areas and said that it was open to the workers to apply for reinstatement. The company has appealed against that decision.

The Bass Point quarry is an environmental disaster. It sits between two national parks and causes dust pollution in the nearby Shellharbour township. If an application were to be made today to establish a quarry there, it would be refused. The quarry exists because of the goodwill of the residents of Shellharbour township. They have tolerated it because it has created employment for 21 of its people. The quarry has abused and misused the concept of restructuring, to the detriment of its workers, and also my constituents in Shellharbour. This is the sort of industrial anarchy that would be the norm under the Opposition's industrial relations policies.

When one looks at the Opposition's policies, one wonders whether it has fully investigated the models that it is using. It has used the discredited and failed Thatcher policies of the United Kingdom. Even the ads that it is plastering the country with today are lifted directly from Thatcher. But have the Thatcher policies delivered jobs? Have they lowered interest rates? Are the people in the United Kingdom better off? The answer to each question must be a resounding no.

The Opposition's policies have been tried in the United Kingdom and have failed. They have also had a trial run in New Zealand and failed. In both places they have failed. They have been tried in the United States and failed. If tried here, they will also fail. Does anyone believe that the Opposition's policies would work here? Of course they would not. They are a recipe not only for even higher unemployment but also for confrontation and a divided society. They are policies without vision, without compassion and policies that would help the well off at the expense of the workers.

I particularly welcome in the Budget statement the announcement regarding superannuation. The introduction of universal superannuation will, I believe, be recognised as one of the great reforms of this Hawke Labor Government. It is aimed at guaranteeing the quality of life of those Australians who will retire in increasing numbers in the future. Of course, what is recognised by all--except, it seems, the Opposition--is that improvements in superannuation will be taken into account in future wage negotiations. That is why it is wrong to assume that increases in superannuation will be added to the wage costs of employers.

It is known that in 1986 increases in superannuation were taken instead of a general wage increase. A general wage increase was directly traded off for an increase in superannuation. Through the accord, the Government and the ACTU continually delivered on the aggregate wage outcome. The relationship that has delivered these outcomes is as strong as ever. The Government and the ACTU understand that this country has to reap the benefits of low inflation. Equally, the Government and the ACTU understand that employment has to increase. Therefore, increases in total wages will be sensitive to these fundamental requirements.

Australians have to understand what is driving the Opposition on this issue. It is ideology at its worst; it is ideology at its most vicious. The Opposition believes that market failure never exists and that the choices made by individuals on savings through time obviate the need for universal superannuation. The basic bankruptcy of the Opposition's policy is revealed more fully by its spokesperson, Senator Alston, who reckons that Australians do not need superannuation for their retirement. Instead, he believes:
Low income earners would be much better off paying off their mortgages and their credit debts than being forced to pay another three per cent.

Perhaps the good senator believes that all Australians should buy a second house as well. Presumably then Australians would be doubly secure in their retirement. It is pathetic. In their hearts members of the Opposition believe that property speculation is a safe, sensible and viable way to secure the retirement incomes of aged Australians. It is pathetic, but I guess it is only to be expected.

The Government rejects the philosophy, the ideology and the bankruptcy of the Opposition. We remain committed to universal superannuation because it is an essential reform. The employers are complaining about the contribution they will make. But has anyone ever known the highly paid executives not to cry wolf? If we had listened to their cries of woe, today children would still be down the mines.

In the time available to me I would like to concentrate on some of the very positive proposals in this Budget. Some extraordinary comments have been made about the Budget. Some people have suggested that it does not do anything for employment, that it does not do anything for the current account deficit and that it will not stimulate business. All of those things are untrue. The Budget contains policies which will make a difference to the level of employment, the skills of the work force, the level of exports and the extent of import replacement--and it does so in ways that are of long term benefit to the country.

For example, in the area of education, which must be the most important contributor to improvements in the skills of the work force, the level of real outlays on education has risen by over 7 per cent at a time when the Budget was very constrained. That increase totals $790m and will be distributed to a whole series of areas. For example, there will be increased numbers of places at universities and $20m has been allocated for additional higher education capital funding. That is a very important component.

Another centrally important area which contributes to enhancing the dynamism of the economy is increased expenditure on research and development. This financial year total expenditure on science and innovation will go up by 4.3 per cent in real terms--which is a very significant increase. This will be used in a whole series of areas. Some of it will go to the CSIRO, whose funding will go up 3 per cent in real terms. The Australian Research Council funding will go up substantially, as will funding for R& in health. Rural R& funding will go up by 23 per cent. A whole series of initiatives will be possible because of that increase in funding for science and technology. It is particularly satisfying to see that these priorities within the science budget are being addressed.

A third area of funding is infrastructure. It is not nearly as much as some of us would have liked. Nevertheless, there are some additional outlays, particularly for equity investment in the National Rail Corporation to increase the efficiency with which freight is moved around the country, and also in the better cities program. The initial $56m for the better cities program is an important new initiative that will contribute to all sorts of improvements in services in outer suburban areas--areas which have been neglected in the past--but also regional centres such as the Illawarra will benefit.

I heard what the honourable member for Bendigo said about this. He said that he wanted a checklist. I am very pleased to give him an undertaking that I will give him a running report on the better cities program money that goes into my area of the Illawarra. Although he will not be here after 1993, until that time I am more than happy to supply him with his checklist.

There is also a series of important social programs, including the family assistance package, and a very striking increase in outlays for child-care of over $100m. The Opposition has criticised the Government for the level of unemployment. But, as Ross Gittins recently said:
. . . so the Liberal Party pleads for the jobless--I think not.
That is true, Ross Gittins. The Opposition is trying to make political mileage out of unemployment, but what we have seen of its policies would do nothing for the unemployed.

I suppose that, if each of us were framing the Budget, we would do different things. More must be done, especially in reducing unemployment. An important step was taken yesterday by reducing interest rates by 1 per cent. What was the reaction of the Opposition to this? It was a very cynical reaction. Those opposite were loud in their criticism of it. This lowering of interest rates will be passed on to the business community and indeed to those paying off their homes. There could well be scope in the near future for a further reduction in interest rates. Australia has had a sharp reduction in the level of inflation while interest rates have been coming down. That means that the real level of interest rates is still relatively high--too high by international standards.

In the minute or so left for me to speak, I would like to touch briefly on the goods and services tax. There are many aspects of the Opposition's policies that should concern Australians, not least of which is the proposed goods and services tax--a tax on everything from haircuts to shoe laces to the soles of one's shoes. The tax will be inflationary and discriminatory as it will impact hardest on those least able to afford it. I read in a paper--I cannot find the cutting now or I would wave it over my head--a story that Senator Vanstone has put out a special booklet in which, apparently, all the Opposition members are asked for ideas on how to sell this unsaleable tax. This booklet has apparently found great favour; it has tanks, guns, rockets and everything on it. But let me say that the Opposition will need more than tanks, guns, rockets and all those things to sell this unsaleable tax and I wish Senator Vanstone well in her efforts. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), will probably be hit by a GST Exocet in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hollis interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-`Don't you worry about that', as someone once said. I would like to start my comments about the Budget where the previous speaker left off--not as to his comments about the prospect of a sensible tax regime in this country, but on the matter of interest rates. One of the events that took place and has to be discussed in the context of the Budget is of course the interest rate decision that was made this week.

SPEECH.PARA: There particularly needs to be some focus on what the Governor of the Reserve Bank said today to the MTIA. I think it was quite revealing. In that speech, he conceded that the economy was weaker `than had been thought', and that the assumptions on which the economic recovery was foreshadowed in the Budget were highly suspect particularly in regard to business investment and the outlook, which he described as particularly worrying. That ought to be some cause for concern to honourable members on both sides, but particularly on the other side because, when we look more closely at the Budget figures, it is clear that business investment looks set to fall by about 20 per cent in 1991-92, and that is more than double the estimate in the Budget Papers.

It is also important that the comments made about real interest rates be put into proper context because even in a deep recession, the Governor reports, our real long term interest rates--that is, the rates that are determined by the market, not the authorities--are close to double those of our major trading partners. That being the case, we have to ask the question: how many major projects will get off the ground with real long term interest rates of 7 per cent plus?

But the other point that needs to be made is that there seems to be some differing of opinion within the Reserve Bank. The Deputy Governor, at his speech at the Australian Management College last week, said that management policy should be directed primarily to the medium term and operate in tandem with adjustments to the other arms of policy.

The emphasis needs to be on the medium term. The short term fix, pushing down interest rates that are controllable by the Reserve Bank, does not address the long term economic problems unless we make the other adjustments that are necessary in the broad economy. It is one of those other adjustments that I want to focus my remarks on tonight, and it relates of course to my area of responsibility--communications.

Some other points from the Budget, though, are worth mentioning. There is an increase in Government spending of $5.5 billion to $101.5 billion. That is a 2.6 per cent increase in real terms and a total figure which represents a massive 25.7 per cent of gross domestic product. That is due mainly to the impact of the recession. There is a growing number of people dependent on pensions and unemployment benefits and as well, of course, there is the grand city plan, which we still do not have any detail about. The reason expenditure is not larger is that the Government is squeezing the States.

There is also a decrease of $1.9 billion in Government tax revenue, from $93 billion in 1991 to $91.1 billion in 1991-92--a clear indication of a falling economy and a further continuation of the economic conditions brought about by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). He must not be able to escape blame. He will go down in history as the Dracula of Australian politics; he has sucked the blood out of the economy, and we are now living with a lifeless corpse of an economy. All ordinary Australians are certainly feeling it. They are responding to those signs and slogans that are appearing on our billboards around the country. There are a million unemployed, but the interesting thing is that the problem involves more than the million unemployed. It is the underemployed who are not registered who ought to be the Government's concern as well. They are our concern.

We ought not address the problems by dropping interest rates overnight. We must have a medium term policy that responds to the long term economic needs and restructuring priorities that are plain for outside commentators to see, but seem to come within the blind spot of this Government.

The coming years will bring with them some further pain. One of the areas which is indicative of that of course is the foreign debt level and the implications of that debt. A total foreign debt of about $165 billion requires $17 billion just to service that debt per year. Interest payments of $17 billion require about $8,000 from every man, woman and child in Australia. Every time a new baby is born, that baby is already $8,000 in debt and has to produce $800 a year just to service that debt. Clearly, that is a fundamental weakness in our economic situation.

The weaknesses in the Australian economy show that we have made little progress since the 1989-90 OECD economic survey of Australia, which outlined the major weaknesses as follows: we need to have improved competitiveness, higher productivity, improved industrial relations, and increased savings. The main long term difficulty is Australia's lack of international competitiveness. This is reflected in our falling share of world trade over the past two years, as the shadow Minister for trade, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), can, I am sure, testify when he has his opportunity to make some remarks in this place.

That lack of competitiveness is a direct result of a rigid and inefficient economy which the Government has had a number of years now to address, and it has not addressed it. We are now worse off than we have ever been in the whole time that this Government has occupied the Treasury bench, yet Government members are contemplating putting back into the driver's seat the very man who has delivered this state of affairs to the community. If honourable members opposite think that that will give them a victory at the next election, they are crazy. Whoever is put forward by the Government will lose because the Australian people are tired of what it has delivered, because clearly it has failed.

The thrust of the coalition's alternative policies is to break down these inefficiencies and rigidities by deregulation, competition, corporatisation and privatisation--that is, to put in place the structural reforms necessary to boost productivity, lower costs and reduce inflation in order to allow sustained reduction in interest rates. We want to take the medium term view. It is exactly as the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank said. Rigidities and inefficiencies are found in the persistence of work and management practices that protect people's jobs in the short term. There is no vision of future environment in which more and new jobs will be created, just a Luddite preoccupation with the present--`Long live the accord'. The accord is dead in the water. It has outlived its usefulness.

Tariffs and other forms of industry protection also create inefficiencies. It will be interesting to see whether the Government will stick by its industry statement of 12 March last year in all respects. If it kowtows to the screams of the music industry, which it shows every indication of doing, what can we expect in the really hard areas? Is the consumer forever to be put last? What is the Government going to do with the telecommunications industry plan? All forms of protection flow through to the rest of the community. Even where industries are domestically orientated, their levels of efficiency affect the competitiveness of our export orientated industries.

Inefficiency is a disease that spreads its infection throughout the whole economy. No better example comes to mind than the telecommunications equipment industries in this country. Unless they are internationally competitive, there is little hope that their buyers, principally Telecom and the new AOTC, will become internationally competitive. The lack of competitiveness is a direct result of a rigid and inefficient economy. The thrust of our policies is to break down these inefficiencies and rigidities. Imports are bad, according to this Government, and that is why it has imposed such savage interest rates.

We do have to worry about import levels while our export performance is too poor to generate the income necessary to pay for those imports. But this argument is carried too far. To suggest, for instance, that we cannot have pay television because of the impact on imports denies the fact that it will provide opportunities for Australian companies to cash in on exports abroad. Clearly, this is a false argument.

Everyone knows what we ought to do to achieve a strengthened Australian economy. We must dramatically improve our productivity and we must become internationally competitive; and we all know why and how that should be done. The question is: when and where will these things be addressed? The Government knows what must be done, but industry restructuring and micro-economic reform has been patchy and its pace snail-like.
