There is not one better example than the waterfront.

The Government chose the waterfront to be its centrepiece for micro-economic reform and finally, honourable members opposite will recall, the Minister who said he would resign if he achieved nothing did not achieve anything and did not resign. I think that is an indication, quite clearly, of the hollowness of the Government's rhetoric. Let me talk about productivity. Increasing productivity means more can be produced from the same resources or less.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Why don't you listen to the Minister for transport? You never do.

—-Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will stop interjecting. I have indicated that to him several times and he has ignored the Chair. I ask him now to abide by what the Chair is saying.

—-I know the honourable member for the Northern Territory is often excited by my remarks because of the rational nature of them. Increasing productivity means higher wage growth, it means an increase in the size of the economic cake and it means higher living standards. Raising productivity and improving our competitive position must be our aim. We need to free our rural and manufacturing service industries of excessive regulation. In broadcasting, for example, the mishmash of rules and regulations has been a disaster for much of the radio and television industry. Indeed, there are proposals to bring forward change, but that change is long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to insist on a more competitive business and public sector culture. The present concentration of ownership of the print media during the 1980s--positively encouraged by Labor's policies--should not have happened, and no amount of inquiries will enlighten us further as to the cause. We know the cause. We want to know when those opposite are going to deliver the solution.

We need to encourage investment in productive enterprises, not in the high-flying entrepreneurial activities encouraged by a Labor government that did not have the vision to put in place the appropriate prudential controls. Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale and a dozen other shelved projects could not possibly have wreaked the havoc caused to so many Australians by those now discredited high fliers. Indeed, that damage has spread worldwide. They have a great deal to answer for.

We need to reform our work places. We need to move away from our traditional centralised wage fixing system to enterprise- focused employee relations. How long have we argued that in this place? I remember being acting shadow Minister for industrial relations nearly five years ago, when we were putting that view forward and were ridiculed. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the current shadow Minister for industrial relations, put that view forward then and he was ridiculed. Now we see the Industrial Relations Commission in part embracing it--not in the form that we want by any means, but the argument has finally been accepted. It has taken a depression and our slipping in the world economic order for people to realise the sense of that argument.

We need to resist any moves by the Telecom unions to have industrial coverage over both telecommunications carriers. That matter is the subject of some controversy at the present time. As the new competitor should have the right to hire and fire in accordance with normal private sector practice, so too should Telecom if it is to operate on the same footing.

What are some of the key areas for reform? The key areas for reform in the Federal arena are agreed and, in some cases, are already under way. They clearly are: telecommunications, broadcasting, aviation, land transport, and sea transport. Privatisation is part of the reform agenda. In the area of my interest--transport and communications--capital expenditure is the largest capital outlay made in Australia, representing some 3.6 per cent of GDP, or 40 per cent of all capital outlays. Transport and communications services currently account for about 8 per cent of Australia's total gross domestic product and 7 per cent of total employment.

Last year an Industries Assistance Commission submission to Cabinet estimated that structural reform in transport and communications and cuts in industry assistance could boost Australia's gross domestic product by $16 billion in 1988-89 dollars. In telecommunications alone the boost to GDP is estimated at some $1.7 billion.

The potential of the telecommunications sector is enormous, as even the Chief Executive of Telecom, Mr Ward, pointed out in his National Press Club address. The 37 million lines in service today in the Asia-Pacific region will grow to more than 300 million in 50 years. In that region total expenditure on telecommunications over that period is expected to be more than $1 trillion.

The reforms in telecommunications now under way are intended to break down the inefficiencies inherent in government monopolies. We have a total government monopoly of telecommunications in this country. We must introduce competition, albeit in the limited form of a duopoly, to drive down prices, to improve service to customers and to enhance the opportunities for increased telecommunications exports.

The irony is that to ensure that competition is real the Government has had to put in place a strengthened regulatory authority, but one that still has to be very subservient to the Minister. The questions are: has he got the legislation right and will he get the myriad of other matters outside the legislation--interconnect charges, licence conditions, pay TV delivery, industry policy, et cetera--all right? They are complicated issues certainly, but they are absolutely fundamental when one looks at the size of this industry and recognises that industry policy now in this country is not about setting up prescriptive barriers but is about lowering the input costs to businesses and visiting upon consumers savings. That is the only way we will address that fundamental requirement that our economy has to achieve, that is, far greater productivity in international competitiveness.
Also on the telecommunications side, one can only agree with a speech, interestingly, by the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications, Graham Evans, when he said in July:

In the end, of course, the relative quality of the new regulatory arrangements will have to be judged in terms of what it brings in terms of both the price of and the quality and reliability of telecommunications services in Australia, and by whether the industry is sufficiently strengthened by its domestic environment to be more internationally competitive in the provision of services and equipment.

He also said, `For a significant period the major benefits of competition to the broader community and economy will come from the performance of the new amalgamated Telecom and OTC'. That is very true, but I would certainly say this: all of us need to commit ourselves to ensuring that we do see the changes within the new organisation. We must recognise that it will be a new organisation; that it must be possessed of a new culture; that it must be possessed of a new vigour; and that once the board and the Chief Executive are appointed--and I understand that there is some discussion on that matter now, and the sooner that decision is made the better--they must focus on building a competitive telecommunications service and dedicate themselves to that task. It must be up to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) to ensure that that happens or else his whole policy will have failed.

I was going to talk about the wholesale sales tax, but I think it is important in the telecommunications area to point out some of the data that has been provided to me by the tax reform group that is looking at all of these matters within the coalition. They produced some very interesting figures which showed that there is now about $375m tax on telephone calls in this country through the wholesale sales tax. Sales tax on capital equipment alone averages out to an additional cost of almost $50 on the yearly phone bill of each of Telecom's eight million-plus subscribers. That is what the existing ramshackle wholesale tax base is doing to all of those telephone subscribers right around the nation. We have not heard much from the Government about that.

Finally, I should make the point that, whilst the Government is spending around $60m on television aggregation, it has had to forgo $117m in the form of sales tax and licence fee relief to help the stations pay the enormous sums necessary for aggregation. This is the worst possible time in the worst recession this century for television stations to have to spend the large sums necessary for aggregation.

Aggregation is a flagship issue to indicate how they have not got it right in telecommunications. They have forwarded a policy; they have started on a track; they have got halfway down; they cannot go back; to go forward only makes it worse. And what happens? A whole industry is now verging on collapse and it is right in the middle of what looks to be a long term recession. If one talks to people in the television and radio industries, one finds that their major preoccupation is to get the message through to the Government that they are under siege and that diversity and choice in programming are all suffering because of the policies that this Government has put in place--its broader macro policy settings and its specific broadcasting policy settings.

Even tonight--and I finish with these last few words--the Cabinet is meeting to discuss the whole question of additional powers that might be given to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to deal with the selling of the two largest newspapers in this country--the Fairfax newspapers, the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald. That whole matter is in the position that it is because those papers are in receivership. They cannot reach a decision tonight, I understand--the matter is still going on--because the Government again is in confusion and again is in debate.

What is happening, of course, is that the people who are employed in these enterprises, the people who are wanting to bid for these enterprises, need to know what the rules of the game are and what is going to happen. What is Minister Beazley's view? We have had three views from him over the last two weeks. There is no clear view coming from the Government. It is simply not good enough for it to persist in creating this confusion when one is talking about dealing with some of the largest newspaper assets in this country. Setting up a print media inquiry, on which I now sit, is not going to give us the answers, because that is going to happen well after the event anyway.

So the whole thing is looking very much like a charade and a nonsense. Clearly, it is time that the Minister took control of communications and focused his attentions on the needs of the communications industry in this country, for if he continues to do so, we will add further to the disasters, further to the receiverships and further to the total lack of confidence of the business community, the communications industry in this industry----

TALK.START.PARA: —-Are you blaming the Fairfaxes for the newspaper mismanagement?
—-You are exacerbating the problem. Give us some decisions.
—-You goose!
—-The industry wants some decisions.
—-Order!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There are two debates at present going on about the substance of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 now before this House flowing from the recent Federal Budget of this Government. The first is being waged in the community, and especially through the media. That debate is, as might be expected, subject to the distortions which some people make because of the need to sensationalise the issues and to beat up certain aspects for the sake of seeing where they might lead. More regrettably, that debate is influenced by the distortions which are made of the issues for the purpose of self-interest, with little respect for the real truth of the matters being discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: This House is the place where issues are considered and debated in the full glare of the democratic process, where hyperbole and distortion can be uncovered and shown to be what they are. Certainly in that regard I would have to take issue with some of the points made by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) in his speech on this Appropriation Bill. One of the things he seems to have left out when haranguing the Government for its supposed lack of action in regard to this Bill was improved competitiveness. He managed to slag the Government for the supposedly poor figures shown in the Bill. He seems to have very conveniently forgotten the increased exports, which are there for him to see. Perhaps, like some of his colleagues, he has a little trouble reading the figures.

He harangued the Government on the overseas debt and cried crocodile tears over the newly born person having so much debt that he will be in debt for the rest of his life. He will have to join the Liberal Party to get out of it! The overseas debt is not owed by every man, woman and child in this country; it is owed by the industries that created that debt. It is not the responsibility of the taxpayer; it is the responsibility of those companies and the rich mates who went ahead and ran up those bills and went into debt or went broke.

The other aspect the honourable member for Bass ran past as an issue was industrial relations. He seems to forget that over the past few years industrial relations has been a concern of the Hawke Government, whether through the accord or in other ways. It has worked. It has functioned well. He also managed to neglect the fact there are many shopfloor agreements that have been in place. They have been in place with the protection of the court. Perhaps we could say that the honourable member for Bass is proposing that we should withdraw the protection of the court from the people's workplace and let them be at the mercy of those who might take advantage of them.

It is certainly with a recognition and an acknowledgment that many people were hurting as a result of the restructuring of the Australian economy that the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) referred to the 1991-92 Budget as one which was about people. It is predictable that those honourable members on the other side of the House would dismiss any approach to the economy which embraces the concept of compassion as a fundamental responsibility of government in our democracy. That is the fundamental difference in approach which highlights the division between the Government and the Opposition parties in this chamber.

I want to underline the fact that this Budget, even in these difficult times for the Australian nation, tempers economic responsibility with compassion and understanding. The measures adopted in this Budget clearly demonstrate that this Government has compassion, that it is not simply prepared to react in a way to gain short term political advantage.

The electorate of Richmond, which I represent, and the problems it faces are the background against which I must continually measure the policies of this Government. It is against that background that I welcome not only the initiatives of this Budget but also the readiness of Ministers to respond to the needs of provincial Australia. The electorate of Richmond has by far the highest rate of unemployment in New South Wales. It also has the highest incidence of single parents and one of the lowest participation rates in the labour market in this nation.

In case honourable members think that this Government brought about that state of affairs or that matters have deteriorated significantly since the days when Doug Anthony and Charles Blunt were in this House, let me assure honourable members that even in the 1920s governments were aware of what was called the hidden unemployment of the far north coast of New South Wales. That position has not changed, except that what was once hidden unemployment, hidden in the sense that family members kept the farm going for little or no pay, is now obvious to all.

Honourable members should be aware that while the nation reels at unemployment figures of 10 per cent, even when the good times return in the capital cities of Australia unemployment in the Richmond electorate is unlikely ever to be lower than 10 per cent. At the moment it has passed the 15 per cent mark, and the participation rate in the work force stands at scarcely more than 50 per cent.

That unemployment rate has not been a cause for very much comment under past regimes. People just accepted that northern New South Wales was a desirable place to live. However, with a very small industry base, the rapidly increasing population will continue to seek employment in vain. There is little to be had. While people have been keen to relocate to what we modestly call Australia's best address, industry has not been so quick to see the benefits of relocation.

Given that background, I now wish to identify and comment on some aspects of the Budget which are set to impact positively on the quality of life of people in the electorate of Richmond as an example of what this Government is about. The first is changes to the family income package by which this Government has both recognised and acknowledged that, while people might be asset rich, they may have very little disposable income. That is true for many folk who are struggling to keep the family farm together or who operate in the small business sector.

Provision in the Budget of measures which will address this problem for the first time will prove to be of particular help to farmers in the Richmond electorate and, I am sure, in other parts of rural Australia. Honourable members know that many farmers are facing a tough time, with many of them making little or nothing this financial year. Access to family allowance and family allowance supplement under this Budget reverses the situation where farming families were ineligible for full family payments because of their high assets in spite of low or even negative incomes.

While drought is hurting many parts of this country, honourable members do not need to have a long memory to recall that, in other times, flooding rains wreaked havoc which often, with the precision that comes from years of analysis, can be predicted accurately. In the present Budget funds under the Federal water resources assistance program have once again been provided. Honourable members who do not know at first hand the ravages of floodwaters cannot really comprehend the impact on people's lives of the regular flooding which takes place in towns along the eastern seaboard.

In my first speech to this House, I referred to the levee banks which were erected in Murwillumbah on the Tweed River in the Richmond electorate. Those levees, under the Federal water resources assistance program, have kept floodwaters from the central business district during flooding of the Tweed River on all occasions except one in the last 20 years. Money allocated this year will allow the completion of the levee and compensatory house-raising for a number of properties adversely affected by the levee works. The flooding problems at Lismore, which is recognised as the regional capital of the far north coast, are acknowledged as being among the worst in New South Wales. The geography of the catchments causes a concentration of run-off at Lismore, and flooding is often compounded by water backing up into the central business district from the Wilson River. In my initial speech to this House, I urged the Minister to examine closely the study of the Wilson and Richmond Rivers which was being carried out by a firm of engineers. I said at the time:

If it can be established that a flood mitigation scheme could give a measure of flood protection to Lismore without increasing flooding in the rest of the valley, then agreement might be able to be reached among the three tiers of government for implementing the plan . . .

It is pleasing that a public airing of this matter as my No. 1 priority for the city of Lismore has brought agreement from the New South Wales Government to raise the order of priority for Lismore in submissions under the Federal waters resources assistance program for matching funds from Commonwealth, State and local government in the usual ratio of 40 per cent, 40 per cent and 20 per cent respectively. In the present State submission, Lismore was No. 3 priority after failing to reach the requirements in 1990-91.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Tonight I want to raise the question of the Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements (Prohibition) Act 1989 which, as all honourable members of this House will know, under section 5(1) says that no advertisements for smoking will be allowed in published material in Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) for smoking; or
(b) for, or for the use of:
(i) cigarettes; or
(ii) cigarette tobacco; or
(iii) other tobacco products.
Section 6 then goes on to say:
Subsection 5(1) does not apply to a print medium:
(a) printed outside Australia; and
(b) not principally intended for distribution or use in Australia.
The effect of that is that magazines printed within Australia cannot carry tobacco advertising--and that costs them a very great deal of revenue--but magazines printed outside of

Australia can carry the tobacco advertising. One has to wonder why it would be such a disadvantage for Australians to see tobacco advertising in magazines printed in Australia and yet if the advertisements are in overseas magazines it is perfectly all right to do so. This puts the Australian magazines at a very grave disadvantage.

The Government has been made aware of the problem but it has said that it is impractical to amend the Act, that there is only a limited distribution of overseas publications, and that if these do not affect the issue other nations will eventually catch up and ban cigarette advertising in magazines produced overseas.

Let us look at those excuses given by the present Government. First, let us look at practicality. We can ban advertising of cigarette products in magazines printed overseas and not allow magazines with such advertising to come into Australia. It has been done by other countries; I only have to instance Singapore. It is quite easy in the production of magazines to drop out particular pages so that tobacco advertising does not appear. The practicality of this simply is not in question.

The second argument relates to limited distribution of overseas magazines in Australia. In the year to June 1990, over 80 million magazines were imported--well above the Australian publication figures. To suggest there is only a limited distribution of magazines containing tobacco advertising is simply not shown by the facts. Most magazines that are imported come from the United Kingdom or the USA, where tobacco advertising is legal. One only has to pick up these overseas produced magazines to see the extent of the tobacco advertising they contain.

The result of the present situation, and what I regard as an anomaly within the Act, is to force Australian producers of magazines to go offshore. The simplest way to get over the problem is to print the magazines outside Australia, get hold of the tobacco advertising revenue, and import the magazines into Australia. Obviously that is a nonsense. It results in losses of Australian jobs; it puts Australian publishers at a disadvantage; and it puts a whole lot of people who contribute to the production of magazines at a very grave disadvantage.

We need to have a situation where this anomaly is reversed because the magazine production industry in Australia is a very significant one. It is very significant not only directly, for the jobs it produces, but also indirectly, for writers, photographers, and those artisans concerned with the compiling and production of high quality magazines in Australia who need the protection of a level playing field, which we all hear about when people are talking about trade and international trading relationships. Quite simply, this Government has not provided a level playing field for the Australian magazine publishing industry.

It is a straightforward case which should be addressed directly. If this was done then a whole lot of Australian magazine publishers would be advantaged and a great number of Australians who are concerned in this industry would be protected from unfair overseas competition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It may surprise some honourable members on this side of the House, but I speak frequently to honourable members from the other side of the House. I speak to them because, as a Federal member, I always feel that I should be sufficiently dedicated and conscientious to listen to people who come to me with their concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite a number of those opposite come to me with their concerns. Perhaps they see me as a father figure. They know that my advice is of great value. It so happens that an honourable member came to see me the other night after I had made reference to Canada in a speech. I listened to him because I could see he was frightened. He had good cause to be frightened because he felt he was going to lose his seat because of his Party's madness in pursuing a goods and services tax.

He said to me, `Look, I cannot speak against this tax, but maybe I can give you some ammunition which will help you change the attitude and minds of my colleagues on my side of the House'. He said to me, `Do you know how this tax came to be introduced in Canada?'. I said that I had not heard anything about that. He told me what happened. It was party brute strength. When the Government decided to introduce a goods and services tax it met so much resistance in the lower House that it had to use bully boy tactics. It had to threaten all sorts of dire measures against members if they did not toe the party line. So, cowed and beaten, all the members of the Government parties fronted up and supported the legislation. The goods and services tax passed through the lower House in the Canadian Federal Parliament.

But it met stronger resistance in the upper House because there the members are elected for life and nobody can threaten them with loss of preselection. The members of the upper House told their party bully boys that they could go and jump in the lake because there was no way that they would vote for a goods and services tax. Then the Government party, including the Prime Minister, who could not get the goods and services Bill through the upper House, went to the powers that be. Under the Canadian Constitution it is possible--of course, it cannot happen here with our Constitution--for additional members to be appointed to the upper House, just as the kings of England did in the early days of democracy. Additional members were appointed to the upper House in Canada so that the Government could get its loathsome legislation passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The people love it.

—-Of course. They found plenty of wimps who were prepared to accept a lifetime comfortable position in the upper House. These cronies of the Government repaid the favour that was given to them by voting for the passage of the goods and services tax. That is the only way that the goods and services tax came into being in Canada. Is it hated! We can guess the admiration which all Canadians hold for those loathsome people who accepted a bribe of a position in the upper House so that they could help the Government by passing a goods and services tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I sympathise with the honourable member who told me that story but I do fear for him. I hope he does not lose his seat. I hope he can convince his comrades to abandon such lunacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to commend our father figure, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), for telling us that fairy story as we wend our way off to bed tonight. I think most honourable members would prefer Goldilocks and the Three Bears; nevertheless, it was a good story and taken in good humour.

SPEECH.PARA: On a more serious matter, over the past few years the present Federal Government has made a number of changes to the way in which pharmacies are able to operate, to the detriment of many of them, particularly those pharmacies in isolated areas. I will read a letter from a pharmacist in my electorate which will explain the situation much better than I can. This letter was sent to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples). It states:
Dear Mr Staples,
I wish to bring to your attention the unfair treatment I have received from the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. (pra)
I was accepted as an Essential Pharmacy in 1990 and received the EP allowance. (EPA)
That is because this man has the only pharmacy in this particular part of my electorate. The letter continues:

When the EHPA successfully appealed to the High Court against the Government, the HIC was very quick to confirm that the EPA paid for November and December 1990 would be deducted from monies due to me for November and December 1990. This has been deducted.
With the formation of the PRA however, I was informed that I would have to reapply to be designated an Essential Pharmacy, although all the criteria for this designation had not altered.
I therefore applied to the PRT for recognition as an essential pharmacy and received back a card from the PRT giving me a ref No . . . and acknowledged my application of 15 January 1991.
After a lapse of 4 months, my application to the PRT was accepted in a letter dated 15 May 1991 and . . . I have since received EPA payment from the HIC for May and June 1991 only.

What has happened to the payments I am due from January to April inclusive? It is certainly not my fault that the PRT procrastinated for 4 months over my application, which exactly fitted the same qualifying criteria in the previous year. Why should I have to suffer financial loss because of the laggardliness or seeming incompetence of the PRA? This is certainly not within the spirit of the historic two part agreement struck between you, the Minister, and the Pharmacy Guild. . .
What happens next year when I have to reapply, on an annual basis, to be recognised as an Essential Pharmacy. Will I once again lose another 4 months remuneration due?
Is this another example of the Governments cost saving exercises, or perhaps another example of, one cannot trust the Hawke Government to keep its word.
A coherent and detailed explanation of the PRT actions is asked for and really demanded.
I am most disenchanted. It seems that the present government cannot be trusted to keep its word, let alone a solemn agreement entered into with a highly respected professional body.

All honourable members are aware of the problems faced by pharmacies in outback Australia. If someone within the Department is listening to this debate, I wonder whether he could let us know what is happening in that area.

Another matter that I wish to draw to the attention of the House relates to Medibank Private. I have received a letter from a gentleman who is in Medibank Private. He assures me that recently his payments to Medibank Private have increased by 40 per cent. He stated that over the past 10 months his contributions had risen an estimated 40 per cent--from $692 per year to $810 per year on 1 October 1990 and to $987 per year on 1 August 1991.

This gentleman receives a part pension. He is entitled to a pension from the British Navy. He has never claimed as he preferred to arrange his own cover for his wife and himself. What is getting him down is that he now realises he can no longer afford Medibank Private. I know that the Government has problems with Medicare. I think the $3.50 charge is an indication that it definitely is not working. This is another example of these increased costs. This gentleman has found that he will not be able to maintain himself in Medibank Private.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to bring to the notice of the House what I believe is a wonderful achievement by people within the boundaries of my electorate. Day after day we hear about the problems that are occurring in Yugoslavia. My electorate contains a group of people from Croatia who were born over there and whose parents were born over there. They have settled in this country and have certainly contributed to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 10 years ago, they saw a need to build a church. They acquired the land and built the church, which can clearly be called a cathedral. They realised that their people were getting older. They did not want the Federal Government to have the responsibility of looking after their elderly people, so they applied for a grant to build an aged persons village. This grant came from the Hawke Labor Government.

They had a dream of where they were going to build that village. They desired to have it near their church but, unfortunately, they did not have the land. Under the Unsworth Labor Government, they applied to take over something like two hectares of land, which was given to them at a reasonable price, and over the years they endeavoured to pay it off. Since then they have built the aged persons village. Last Sunday I had the opportunity to go and physically inspect that village.

We in Australia have a lot to learn from our settlers who have made this country their home. We have a lot to learn about their love not only of their heritage but also of their families, particularly their aged. We also have a lot to learn about what we read in the media over the conflicts that are occurring in another part of the world. It particularly affects them because it is part of their heritage, but it does not necessarily reflect on them as individuals or as Australians of Yugoslavian extraction and, most particularly, of Croatian extraction.

I can very proudly stand in this House and state that what those people have achieved in such a short time is something that no-one else would have expected of them. They have had many trials and tribulations associated with the building of that aged persons village. Many people have been able to give financial assistance and help. Surprisingly, people who have not been rich in dollars have given of their time. They have achieved a village that all of us could go through and say, `I wish we had been involved in building part of that'.

They have built an environment in which their elderly people know they are going to be looked after with a certain amount of serenity in their later life but, more particularly, they can remain with their close family contacts and the people of Croatian extraction can remain with their church. I say this because sometimes people do not realise what these people have contributed to our country.

As I speak of the Croatian people who have now settled in Australia, and as I relate what I know first-hand of how they have built and achieved such a wonderful environment with their aged persons village and their church, so too I can talk of the Serbian people who have settled in this area and have not only built their church but have also built their aged persons village. I think these people have come together united in the fact that they care for the people whom they realise will need assistance and help in later life, but who may not have immediate family to give that care. They have also come to realise that they cannot always say to the Government that they need help now.

They have been able to use their initiative and their drive and pool their resources, both financially and physically, to build facilities which everyone would be proud to have in their own electorates. I raised this matter because I want honourable members of this Parliament to realise and understand that what is happening overseas is a tragedy. It is dividing a country but, more particularly, we do not want to see it divide Australia. We do not want to see it divide Australians of Yugoslav, Croatian, Serbian or Slovenian families. I do not believe it will come to that.

I believe that what those people have achieved in the short time that they have made Australia their home has contributed not only to the growth of this country but to the growth of their own areas, their church, their aged people and their families. They have contributed their culture and their dance to their young people and as Australians of Yugoslav parents and as Australians of Croatian, Serbian or Slovenian parents they can truly say that they have been able to achieve and contribute back to this country that has offered them citizenship in friendship and given them stability to grow and prosper.

Time and again when we read in the media about the relationship that occurs at times in areas of trouble, we must also realise the contributions that this country has had from the people I have referred to, who reside within my area and have contributed not only to my electorate and the electorate of the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), but also to this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Tonight, sadly, I bring to the notice of the House, and especially the Attorney- General (Mr Duffy), an unethical and unprofessional approach by the Federal member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) to discredit the tendering process that was used by the Australian Securities Commission to locate its data processing centre in my electorate--a shady attempt to transfer 350 jobs into his own electorate. In my opinion, it is outrageous to request the Attorney-General to look at a new player after the tender has closed and the tender price is public. The ambit claim that $50m savings can be made is without foundation and totally discredited.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to put on record a brief chronological history of events leading to the data processing centre being placed in temporary premises in Morwell. In mid-1989 the Attorney-General called for registrations of interest from States for the data processing centre to be placed in regional Australia. Three States nominated, and the areas proposed were Hobart, Newcastle and the Latrobe Valley. In November of that year, an agreement was signed between the Victorian Government and the Attorney-General for the centre to be placed in the Latrobe Valley. In March 1990 the coalition shadow Minister gave his full support to the document centre being based in the Latrobe Valley.

In April 1990 Traralgon was selected as the permanent site for the centre. In August 1990 the temporary home for the data processing centre was opened with 300 employees, whose productivity and expertise are now recognised as world class and second to none. In August 1990 the Esso building in Sale came onto the market. In November 1990 expressions of interest were made for the pre- committed lease building in Traralgon, as in the original terms and agreement signed by the Federal and State governments. In December of 1990 the project team recommended that five of those who responded should be short-listed and issued with a detailed brief and lease proposals returnable and closable by 8 March 1991.

In May 1991, the ASC accepted the recommendation to continue negotiations with the preferred developer for Traralgon. On 25 July 1991 a letter was sent from the ASC Chairman to the Attorney-General seeking approval for the lease agreement for the new building. In August 1991 there was a media release by the National Party of Australia member for Gippsland suggesting that Sale be considered as an alternative for the data processing centre--two years after the horse had bolted.

On 20 August 1991 the ASC Chairman responded to the honourable member for Gippsland, detailing that the costing of the Latrobe Valley proposal over 15 years was $700,000 cheaper than the Sale proposal--notwithstanding the relocation costs of several million dollars for the staff. On 30 August 1991 Baillieu Knight Frank's agent for Esso Australia submitted a second proposal with full knowledge of the Latrobe Valley's new building costs. The Attorney- General must reject this unethical predatory pricing. If the ASC is to be a watchdog for the Australian business sector, it is totally unacceptable for it to accept a horse trader. To put it another way: what price does the Attorney-General put on the integrity of the Australian Securities Commission?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House two organisations that work in the north of my electorate. I mention first the wonderful work done by the Challenge Foundation in the Tweed region. On Friday 30 August I had the pleasure of opening the Garden Service Centre, operated by the Wollumbin section of the Challenge Foundation in Murwillumbah. This particular garden service provides full time employment and training for 15 intellectually disabled people and three Foundation staff members. It is the first of a number of supported employment projects being established by the Foundation in the Tweed region.

TALK.START.PARA: —-To yourself?
—-I would like to point out to the honourable member that that honour has traditionally gone to the member for Richmond, and in this case it was I who presented the award.
—-The previous member was a big banana.

—-That is all history. The King Banana, weighing in at 355 grams, was a fine Cavendish banana. It was presented by M. and P. Franks and Sons and it certainly deserved the accolade it received. By the way, the King Banana had the honour of leading the parade the next day. It was put on the front of a tractor. They are clever bananas up on the Tweed Coast, I point out to the honourable member for Mayo. The other activities, which were all part of raising money for charity, were: the Miss Personality contest, which was won by Miss Fran Clancy; and the Queen of the Carnival, won by Margaret Watson, who was sponsored by the Tweed Shire Council. The runner up in the same contest was Simone Frost. Congratulations to all those people and to the other girls and the organisations that supported them in the one or two weeks of the carnival and also in the months leading up to it. (Time expired)

—-In the very few seconds that are available to me, I would like to bring to the attention of the House the fact that the National Flower Show was held in Melbourne at the World Trade Centre last weekend.
—-Who was the King Pansy?

—-I wish that the pretend Minister at the table could understand the importance of flowers to Australia. In my electorate of La Trobe, the flower industry is a major industry. We grow flowers and bulbs and we export those flowers. It is a major effort for Australia. On Friday morning we signed an agreement with Japan to increase our exports of flowers to Japan by a factor of 100 per cent in the next year. That is a very significant initiative undertaken by the flower growing industry. I think that all Australians would be delighted to hear that we have an industry which is indigenous, which is doing a terrific job of advertising Australia all over the world. It provides not only good visual products for Australia, but desperately needed export dollars for our economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 4 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What does it cost to provide telephone services to persons in remote areas where these services are not commercially viable.

(2) Under the new telecommunications arrangements, what cost will be borne by Telecom by being refused application of timed telephone calls in the city and by forcing it to bear the costs of duplicated equipment.
(3) Are country residents to be charged on a timed basis but not city residents; if so, is this inequitable.
(4) Is the dominant obligation of the merged telecommunications carrier to ensure that the standard telephone service is available to all Australians.
(5) Will the same obligation apply to a second carrier; if not, (a) why not and (b) does this give a second carrier an unfair competitive advantage.
(6) Has a second carrier been chosen yet.
(7) Are the resources of any of the potential second carriers more extensive than Telecom's.
(8) When it is chosen, will the worldwide resources of the second carrier be revealed to the Australian people to enable its relative size to be noted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question, partly based on advice from Telecom, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The provision of telephone services to persons in remote areas is a major component of Telecom's universal service obligation which requires standard telephone services to be reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis.
As reported in Telecom's 1989-90 Annual Report, the avoidable cost of Telecom's universal service obligation was $237 million in that year.

(2) Telecom will be obliged to offer residential customers, whether metropolitan or rural, the option of continued access to non-timed local calls under price capped formulas. The packaging of alternative customer options is a matter for Telecom's commercial judgement, and should not impose additional costs on Telecom. Providing timed and non-timed calls on modern exchange equipment would not require the duplication of equipment.
(3) No changes to current charging and zoning arrangements for residential customers are proposed. Calls within country areas which are currently charged on an non-timed basis will continue.
(4) Yes.
(5) The second carrier will not have any obligation to deliver universal service, unless nominated by the Minister to be the `universal service carrier' for particular areas.
(a) Telecom/OTC will, in the first instance, be the only universal service carrier for Australia.
(b) No. The second carrier will be required to contribute towards the costs of delivering universal service on an equitable basis via the universal service levy.
(6) No, the process for selecting the second telecommunications carrier is still underway and is scheduled for completion by the end of 1991.
(7) Expressions of interest were lodged by potential second carriers on a confidential basis. No details about prospective bidders have therefore been made available publicly.

(8) The selection process for the second carrier will ensure that the second carrier has the necessary financial strength and management capabilities to establish and sustain effective competition and to achieve the planned rates of capital investment in facilities. I will announce details of the successful bidder once the selection has been made.
